items.title: Richard Powers ‚Äî Bewilderment (2021)
items.content_html:
Part of a series on novels nominated for the 2021 Booker Prize
NB. This post discusses the entire novel; proceed at risk of spoilers.

The thirteenth novel by Richard Powers ‚Äì his first since the Booker-shortlisted, and Pulitzer-winning The Overstory (2018) ‚Äì is a meditation on climate disaster, personal responsibility, and empathy. It is a novel that plays out at various scales, from a relationship between father and son, to the arena of national policymaking, to the circumstances of imagined life on theoretical planets. Powers is certainly a gifted writer, and he is possessed of both a vast imagination and an impressively thorough command of facts. However, I found that several elements of the novel frustrated me, from the way its characters are drawn, to the tone and manner in which its overall narrative is composed.

With the caveat that this may all be subjective to my own experience, I‚Äôll begin with the textual, stylistic elements of Bewilderment that irked me. The most common was the myriad ways in which Powers awkwardly introduces facts about the natural world (or the universe more broadly) into the text, through Theo‚Äôs narration. In contrast to his relatable concern for his son, and his grieving for his late wife, these interjections repeatedly struck me as off key. Not only did it feel unlikely that anyone genuinely thinks in these hyper-specific bursts of rational fact, it began to feel like the work of the text to convey information rather than story or feeling. It read as though Powers, in his research, had uncovered dozens of things he found so fascinating that he couldn‚Äôt stand to leave them out of the text. The result was that I sometimes found Theo‚Äôs narration unrealistic and disappointingly flat. Take, as one example, the way in which he relays a simple taxi journey:

I felt us traveling on a small craft, piloting through the capital city of the reigning global superpower on the coast of the third largest continent of a smallish, rocky world near the inner rim of the habitable zone of a G-type dwarf star that lay a quarter of the way out to the edge of a dense, large, barred, spiral galaxy that drifted through a thinly spread local cluster in the dead center of the entire universe. (p210)

It reads like a particularly erudite teenager trying too hard to impress: to overwhelm with fact. In Powers‚Äô case it is more likely an effort to reveal to the reader some of his narrator‚Äôs interior, but I found it no more convincing (and no less irritating) each time something like it occurred.

I had a similar experience with the character of Robin. Particularly in the second act of the novel ‚Äî as he is changed by his treatment away from a recognisably petulant nine year old, into someone preternaturally empathetic and knowledgeable ‚Äî he began to function in the text similarly to Leonard Stecyk in David Foster Wallace‚Äôs The Pale King (2011): a character whose flawless, self-possessed goodness is matched only by how irritating everyone else finds him. Unlike in Wallace‚Äôs novel, however, this is almost certainly not how Powers wants his reader to feel about Robin.

Similarly, I found the rendering of Aly to be cartoonishly simple. She is written as an unimpeachable font of altruism and empathy, devoid of human flaws. Her absence, which is required by the plot, nevertheless read to me as a device by which to sustain her sainthood. In the world of the novel, and specifically in the eyes of Theo and Robin, nothing short of Aly‚Äôs martyrdom will suffice. It is the impossible, impractical standard against which everyone else in the text is found wanting.

All of which brings me to the broader issues I had with Bewilderment: the ways in which it is confused by its telescoping sense of scale, and ‚Äì most strikingly ‚Äì its pervasive sense of pessimism.

The ambitious manner in which the novel moves back and forth between the scales of the family and the intergalactic is admirable, but it also works to the novel‚Äôs detriment in one important regard. By counterpointing Aly‚Äôs obsession with practical solutions to present problems, and Theo‚Äôs focus on theoretical explorations of unreachably distant worlds, the novel becomes confused about its stakes. What does it matter whether or not Theo can help his son, if Earth will be uninhabitable by the time Robin is a man? And what does Earth‚Äôs accelerating climate disaster really matter in the grander scale of the observable universe? These are fascinating questions, which I found Bewilderment willing to ask, but unwilling to venture answers to. I came away frustrated by the manner in which Bewilderment raises problems at all scales, without offering hope that they might be effectively addressed.

In fact, the novel‚Äôs repeated hammering on humanity‚Äôs failings, and the consequences thereof, becomes increasingly depressing. Bewilderment is shot through with pessimism not just in the beat-to-beat litany of personal, familial, and bureaucratic shortcomings, but also in the shape of its plot as a whole. There is certainly something captivating and bittersweet in much of Robin‚Äôs arc. His rising out of the prison of his own volatile emotions into beatific empathy, only to decline once more when his treatment becomes unavailable, reminded me of Oliver Sacks‚Äôs Awakenings (1973)1. However, Powers chooses to end Bewilderment with Robin‚Äôs death. It is presented, alongside the cancellation of the NextGen project and therefore the scuppering of Theo‚Äôs life‚Äôs work, as a one-two punch that leaves the reader in no doubt as to the message Powers is sending ‚Äì a pessimism of empathy, politics, and purpose that felt depressing to read.

In a 2018 review for The Atlantic, Nathaniel Rich noted the dour outlook of Powers‚Äô previous novel, The Overstory:

‚ÄúHumankind is deeply ill, [‚Ä¶] The species won‚Äôt last long.‚Äù This is the consensus among Powers‚Äôs characters, and it‚Äôs a darkly optimistic one. Optimistic for the planet, pessimistic for the fate of humanity. Once man clears out, nature will return.

The same assessment could be made of Bewilderment. Whilst it is to be lauded for its willingness to look directly at the most difficult and colossal of problems, the novel is too analytical, and too trenchantly rational in its perspective, to inspire. It lacks poetry, most notably through its narrative voice, but also more widely in the construction of its narrative.

In one throwaway moment a fellow ‚Äòplanet-hunter‚Äô remarks to Theo that he is lucky to have a son like Robin: ‚ÄúI can‚Äôt understand why my boys love Star Wars more than they love the stars.‚Äù (p219) One possible answer is that Star Wars ‚Äîlike a lot of fantasy, and like much of the sci-fi Theo professes to enjoy ‚Äî is a story of hope. Such stories have captivated the human imagination, and served as sources of inspiration, for centuries. As well composed as it is, I can‚Äôt imagine Bewilderment inspiring much besides apathy or despair.

  1. Or, more specifically, Penny Marshall‚Äôs 1990 film adaptation thereof. ↩︎

In a 2018 review for *The Atlantic*, Nathaniel Rich noted the dour outlook of Powers‚Äô previous novel, *The Overstory*: > ‚ÄúHumankind is deeply ill, [‚Ä¶] The species won‚Äôt last long.‚Äù This is the consensus among Powers‚Äôs characters, and it‚Äôs a darkly optimistic one. Optimistic for the planet, pessimistic for the fate of humanity. Once man clears out, nature will return. The same assessment could be made of *Bewilderment*. Whilst it is to be lauded for its willingness to look directly at the most difficult and colossal of problems, the novel is too analytical, and too trenchantly rational in its perspective, to inspire. It lacks poetry, most notably through its narrative voice, but also more widely in the construction of its narrative. In one throwaway moment a fellow ‚Äòplanet-hunter‚Äô remarks to Theo that he is lucky to have a son like Robin: ‚ÄúI can‚Äôt understand why my boys love *Star Wars* more than they love the stars.‚Äù (p219) One possible answer is that *Star Wars* ‚Äîlike a lot of fantasy, and like much of the sci-fi Theo professes to enjoy ‚Äî is a story of hope. Such stories have captivated the human imagination, and served as sources of inspiration, for centuries. As well composed as it is, I can‚Äôt imagine *Bewilderment* inspiring much besides apathy or despair. [^1]: Or, more specifically, Penny Marshall‚Äôs 1990 film adaptation thereof.

items.title: Nadifa Mohamed ‚Äî¬†The Fortune Men (2021)
items.content_html:
Part of a series on novels nominated for the 2021 Booker Prize
NB. This post discusses the entire novel; proceed at risk of spoilers.

It is a more difficult thing in many respects, for the writer to base events and characters in a novel upon real people and real occurrences. When inventing from whole cloth, there is no burden upon the author to maintain accuracy, or to do justice to those who once lived. Indeed, the people and events depicted in Nadifa Mohamed‚Äôs The Fortune Men are yet within living memory, still further freighting her novel with responsibilities not incumbent upon those novels wholly invented.

Fortunately (no pun intended), Mohamed is a gifted writer and a subtle stylist. She is engaged ‚Äî in The Fortune Men ‚Äî with telling the story of Mahmood Mattan: a Somali man who lived in Cardiff, where he was wrongfully accused of, and eventually hanged for, the murder of a local shopkeeper in 1952. In a piece for Waterstones, Mohamed says that with her novel she ‚Äòtried to touch hands with who Mahmood might really have been‚Äô. She does so by employing an admirable gift for empathy, bringing forth a wholly realised sense of many of the novel‚Äôs characters with nuanced phrasing. Mahmood, as vital and solid a presence as he is in the text, exists in Cardiff as ‚Äòa human silhouette in motion‚Äô, marginalised because of his nationality, race, and class. In a novel very much concerned with one‚Äôs sense of place and belonging, Mahmood‚Äôs romantic relationship ‚Äòhas fixed him in his longitude and latitude‚Äô. And Mohamed is just as gifted at depicting place through powerfully evocative use of simile and metaphor. She writes of the river that ‚Äòbrooded beneath the bridges, black and muscular‚Äô, and door locks that go ‚Äòclick, clack [‚Ä¶] like small bones breaking‚Äô.

Indeed, the weakest aspect of The Fortune Men is the extended section of directly reported speech that makes up Mahmood‚Äôs trial. This stylistic choice certainly does something to convey feelings of helplessness and unfairness that characterise the proceedings. However, I was left feeling that I was being deprived of Mahmood‚Äôs significant talents for description and interiority, on display throughout the majority of the novel.

Taken as a whole, The Fortune Men is a beautifully written fictionalisation of a tragedy, thick with unresolved questions about national identities, and ideas of belonging. Beyond even that, it is a deceptively ambitious novel, which expands to include the Jewish ancestry of the murder victim‚Äôs family, beginning to interrogate the diversity and commonalities of the immigrant experience. By bringing forth a vivid depiction of an all-too-recent miscarriage of justice, Mohamed ‚Äî the first British-Somali to find a place on the Booker Prize shortlist ‚Äî also attempts to grapple with the myriad ways in which identity can still shape circumstance in modern Britain. Interviewed in The Guardian recently, she framed it in terms of her own desire for understanding:

Modern-day Britain is intense. Something strange is happening [and] whatever postcolonial psychosis it is is so mad and so extreme. Being black, being Muslim, being someone who up until quite recently thought that they understood this country, I‚Äôm desperate to understand what‚Äôs going on.

items.title: Francis Spufford ‚Äî Light Perpetual (2021)
items.content_html:
Part of a series on novels nominated for the 2021 Booker Prize
NB. This post discusses the entire novel; proceed at risk of spoilers.

The opening section of Francis Spufford‚Äôs excellent novel Light Perpetual brings to mind the experimental fiction of Nicholson Baker, and specifically Mezzanine (1988), a book that unfolds entirely within the duration of an escalator ride. Here, Spufford distills a moment down into its constituent parts, slicing them ever thinner as though in an effort to prevent the V2 rocket that is destined to destroy the New Cross Road branch of Woolworths, from ever landing. Ultimately, however, the tragic fact of history will not be denied.

This instant ‚Äì this interval of time, measurably tiny, immeasurably vast ‚Äì arrives unwitnessed, passes unwitnessed, ends unwitnessed. (p5)

This impressive piece of writing provides a somewhat misleading opening to what thereafter unfolds as a novel in a fairly standard realist mode. It is, however, a necessary one, giving a frame to Spufford‚Äôs project of bringing forth from real rubble a set of invented lives, and through them providing expertly-rendered tableaus of 20th century London1.

In an interview for the Hay Festival, Spufford references Michael Apted‚Äôs Up series of documentaries as one point of reference for his model. In those films, as in Light Perpetual, the audience is granted a series of windows into the lives of several individuals, at intervals ‚Äì intervening years illuminated only by the glow of the glimpsed present. This technique of¬†temporally constraining the narrative can‚Äôt help but call to mind totemic works such as Woolf‚Äôs The Waves (1931), and Joyce‚Äôs Ulysses (1922). Free from such unfair comparisons however, Spufford‚Äôs novel deserves praise for its many strengths.

I found some of the most impressive sections to be those chronicling Ben‚Äôs struggles with acute, pervasive anxiety. It‚Äôs an unsettling portrait of compulsion and fear, and a bravura piece of writing. Indeed, Spufford shows no signs of faltering with any of the novel‚Äôs narratives: Alec‚Äôs comparatively less fraught journey from print worker to head teacher is rich throughout with considered observations and human feeling2. At the sentence level too, Spufford is consistently strong, and sometimes spectacular. Consider the concision and richness of this introduction for a minor character:

Trevor is six foot three and won a heavyweight title while he was in the merchant navy. He is also a deacon in the Joyful Assemblies of the Holy Spirit: but he doesn‚Äôt feel he is under an obligation to spell out his commitment to the path of heavenly peace in situations where the greater good would be served by keeping shtum. (p102)

Or this meditation, one of many that touch upon the novel‚Äôs central theme of what might have been for any one of us:

Then just as suddenly, just as clear, she thinks: so what. Nobody chooses who they love. Possessing something, being somebody, loving anyone, it rules the rest out, and so it‚Äôs quieter than being young, and looking forward, and expecting it all, that‚Äôs all. The world calms down when your choice is made. (p297)

My only real criticism of the writing was the occasional use of a technique that is one of my literary bugbears: the describing of (particularly non-white) skin colour by way of comparison to foods. It is always irksome, but sits particularly awkwardly here, in a novel that features a character suffering with a pronounced phobia of cannibalism.

On the whole, Light Perpetual is tender without being sentimental. It is interested in both the overarching shape of a life and the seemingly banal minutiae that comprise it. Spufford refrains from providing easy solutions to the real, complex issues with which his characters are faced3. He does not rescue them from their collective premature demise in order to grant them easy, uncomplicated lives. His aim is to explore the myriad paths that may have lay ahead, and which were so brutally truncated. In doing so he expertly weaves some parallel threads through the lives of several of his characters, without ever making it feel showy or heavy-handed. There is, for example, the repeated presence of music: the gospel that Ben is moved by in church; Jo‚Äôs career as both performer and teacher; Vern‚Äôs refuge in opera. As the characters‚Äô lives lengthen, the reader begins to tease out these universalities in a satisfying way that also enforces the novel‚Äôs purpose.

The novel ends with Francis Spufford achieving a delicate balance between evoking the colossal, unknowable, randomness of life to which every person is subject, and simultaneously finding a way to express unequivocally that each one of those lives is unique and important. It‚Äôs a very fine piece of writing at every level, and one to which I will return.4

  1. I should mention that, particularly before it expanded its horizons somewhat (sending Jo to LA, and Vern to Glyndebourne), another of the works that Light Perpetual brought to mind for me, was an experimental, illustrated book by Iain Sinclair & Dave McKean, titled Slow Chocolate Autopsy: Incidents from the Notorious Career of Norton, Prisoner of London (1997). I don‚Äôt know if that book is still in print, but it made an impression on my as a teenager. ↩︎

  2. I simply have to mention that there is a wonderful short documentary available to watch online for free covering the New York Times‚Äôs switch from hot-metal type to computerised setting: Farewell ‚Äì ETAOIN SHRDLU ‚Äì 1978 (1980). ↩︎

  3. One possible exception is the deus ex embolism that frees one character from a nasty vice. ↩︎

  4. For what it‚Äôs worth, I also think it‚Äôs a near-certainty for the Booker Prize shortlist, and a strong contender for the prize. ↩︎

items.title: Pembrokeshire
items.content_html:
Last week we spent a few days on the Welsh coast, at a place named Moylegrove ‚Äî a little south of Cardigan. We were staying in a birch shepherd‚Äôs hut, part way down one of the narrowest, twistiest roads I‚Äôve ever encountered, in an area where GPS, data services, and phone signal of any kind feared to tread.

We managed to fit quite a bit into the days, visiting Cardigan, Tenby, Fishguard, an Iron Age settlement, and a five-millennia old burial mound of standing stones. We also spent time walking the Stackpole Loop (Stackpole Quay ‚Üí Barafundle Bay ‚Üí Stackpole Head ‚Üí Broad Haven ‚Üí Bosherton Lily Pools), the area near Strumble Head lighthouse, and more of the coast at Ceibwr Bay.

The lack of any form of signal in our hut shaped our evenings. We played card games, listened to BBC 6Music Radio, and read paperbacks with mugs of hot chocolate at hand.

items.title: Patricia Lockwood ‚Äî No One Is Talking About This (2021)
items.content_html:
Part of a series on novels nominated for the 2021 Booker Prize

Patricia Lockwood‚Äôs extraordinary debut novel No One Is Talking About This is a book about what it‚Äôs like to live a substantial portion of one‚Äôs life online, and about the ways in which the internet has changed the manner of our being in the world. It‚Äôs also a book about what it‚Äôs like to experience something revelatory and wonderful ‚Äî and also tragic and painful ‚Äî at the scale of one‚Äôs family life, and how such an experience can change one‚Äôs understanding of the world.

Lockwood is an exceptional writer. Her work in poetry has sharpened her ability to render in language both a moment and its emotional valence: an idea as well as a sense of the absurdity or profundity of it. This, coupled with an unerring eye for the perfect detail and a talent for conjuring crystalline metaphors, leaves the reader with the impression that she is uncannily able to tease out the very heart of an emotional knot ‚Äì to lay its hidden truths bare as though they were obvious. And, whilst there is certainly narrative and incident, No One Is Talking About This is primarily a novel of tone and feeling. It is never less than captivating to watch Lockwood find and maintain that rarest pitch: a perfect harmony of humour, melancholy, and raw emotional vulnerability1. The pathos of No One Is Talking About This is exquisitely rendered ‚Äì¬†it is as saddening as it is laugh-out-loud funny, and often in the very same paragraph.

A lot of writing about life online falls short in one important respect or another. It is either ignorant of the realities of online discourse ‚Äî content instead to rely on broad or outdated clich√© ‚Äî or it adopts an arch tone that seeks to elevate the protagonist (and hence the author and reader) above the participants. Lockwood‚Äôs prose, whilst certainly still knowing, is understanding and interested. She is enthusiastic about the myriad joys of participation in social networks, often employing ‚Äòyou‚Äô & ‚Äòwe‚Äô as indefinite pronouns when writing of actions her protagonist takes online. It‚Äôs a subtle, effective evocation of the eerie sense of simultaneous communality and anonymity that life online can engender. Later in the novel ‚Äî after a shift has occurred in the protagonist‚Äôs perspective ‚Äî the technique seems to take on an almost anthropological note, as though seeking to explain the otherwise mysterious actions of a culture aeons distant. In an interview with Guernica magazine, Lockwood frames her work in terms of the realist social novel:

It doesn‚Äôt seem that different to be translating your encounter with the Ted Cruz porn tweet than it does to be translating your encounter with a croissant breakfast in Paris after your balls have been shot off in the war. You are talking about eating something, drinking something, opening the newspaper, watching people pass. You are choosing either a fine or a coarse grain of description.

It‚Äôs interesting to look at No One Is Talking About This, with its melding of forms, as a retooling of the social novel for the present moment. There is a sense that some elements of the novel exist within a very specific and narrow window. (For how long will the average reader grok references to Harambe, for example?) But, this in itself is reflective of the ephemeral nature of life online. In an interview with Slate, Lockwood refers to the ‚Äòboundedness‚Äô of the novel as a form, as an important contrast to the endlessness of the internet. So, this is a novel that knows about Trump, but not about COVID-19. In years to come it may take on new life as a piece of historical reportage about what it was like to use the social internet, very specifically, in the period 2016-2019.

At the heart of the novel‚Äôs (kinda, sorta) diptych construction is the question of whether the forms of the social web allow for serious expression. In an interview with The London Review of Books, Lockwood considers the ways in which her novel examines the limitations of ‚Äòa pre-received form‚Äô of language that has come to characterise many of the internet‚Äôs social spaces. ‚ÄòAs the forms become rigid, masks do appear‚Äô she says of the manner in which the accepted forms of expression on social networks (in particular) limit how and what participants can express. No One Is Talking About This captures the sound and feeling of two great ice sheets butting up against one another: the sardonic, quixotic, ephemeral churn of the modern connected world; and the enormity and complexity of life‚Äôs events more widely. The attempt to say something important or deeply felt about one‚Äôs own life, running up against the predominant tones and forms of online spaces. As she phrases it in the aforementioned Guernica piece:

We do spend so much of our time online, putting things out there, trying to be funny or sound smart. It can be nice to put something up and say, ‚ÄúI have a big serious life thing on the other side of the screen, too.‚Äù My mom passed away last year, and I posted photos of her every so often as a reminder: She lived, this happened.

In the LRB interview, Lockwood says that whilst writing she thought often of a line in George Elliot‚Äôs Middlemarch:

If we had a keen vision and feeling of all ordinary human life, it would be like hearing the grass grow and the squirrel‚Äôs heart beat, and we should die of that roar which lies on the other side of silence.

Thus, what she calls ‚Äòthe diffuse pain of the portal‚Äô is that no one knows where their attention should be in any one moment. It is a place comprising (in the words of Bo Burnham) ‚Äòa little bit of everything, all of the time‚Äô. No One Is Talking About This contrasts this against the focussing power of personal tragedy. The novel introduces us to a narrator who swims adroitly in the fast-flowing river of online life, before refocussing to encompass life offline: wider, more emotionally diverse, more implacably difficult.

No One Is Talking About This is a truly extraordinary accomplishment. It is a vital, timely novel that affords us the opportunity to ask important questions about the role of the internet in our lives.

In the Slate interview mentioned above, Lockwood (b. 1982) characterises herself as being ‚Äòfrom the perfect internet generation, and you can put that in a pull quote because this is very important‚Äô. It may well be the case that I responded to this novel so strongly in part because I‚Äôm from that same micro-generation: a cohort of people who had a pre-internet childhood, for whom the advent of social networks came in their late adolescence or early adulthood. No One Is Talking About This encapsulates both what I love about the internet, and also many of the ways in which it frustrates, disappoints, and constrains us. The inability of the ubiquitous digital sphere ‚Äî with its aversion to depth, seriousness, nuance, complexity, and raw human feeling ‚Äî to cope with vital parts of our lives, deserves attention. That Lockwood has addressed it with a novel both hilarious and deeply moving is nothing short of masterful.

  1. Other works that have accomplished something similar include Miranda July‚Äôs debut novel The First Bad Man (2015), and Bo Burnham‚Äôs comedy special Inside (2021). I find it noteworthy that July & Burnham are both artists who work in multiple forms (as is Lockwood: poetry, memoir, novel), and whose work is interested in part in form itself. ↩︎

And, whilst there is certainly narrative and incident, *No One Is Talking About This* is primarily a novel of tone and feeling. It is never less than captivating to watch Lockwood find and maintain that rarest pitch: a perfect harmony of humour, melancholy, and raw emotional vulnerability[^1]. The pathos of *No One Is Talking About This* is exquisitely rendered ‚Äì¬†it is as saddening as it is laugh-out-loud funny, and often in the very same paragraph.
‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢
A lot of writing about life online falls short in one important respect or another. It is either ignorant of the realities of online discourse ‚Äî content instead to rely on broad or outdated clich√© ‚Äî or it adopts an arch tone that seeks to elevate the protagonist (and hence the author and reader) above the participants. Lockwood‚Äôs prose, whilst certainly still *knowing*, is understanding and interested. She is enthusiastic about the myriad joys of participation in social networks, often employing ‚Äòyou‚Äô & ‚Äòwe‚Äô as indefinite pronouns when writing of actions her protagonist takes online. It‚Äôs a subtle, effective evocation of the eerie sense of simultaneous communality and anonymity that life online can engender. Later in the novel ‚Äî after a shift has occurred in the protagonist‚Äôs perspective ‚Äî the technique seems to take on an almost anthropological note, as though seeking to explain the otherwise mysterious actions of a culture aeons distant. In an [interview with *Guernica* magazine](https://www.guernicamag.com/miscellaneous-files-patricia-lockwood/), Lockwood frames her work in terms of the realist social novel: > It doesn‚Äôt seem that different to be translating your encounter with the Ted Cruz porn tweet than it does to be translating your encounter with a croissant breakfast in Paris after your balls have been shot off in the war. You are talking about eating something, drinking something, opening the newspaper, watching people pass. You are choosing either a fine or a coarse grain of description. It‚Äôs interesting to look at *No One Is Talking About This*, with its melding of forms, as a retooling of the social novel for the present moment. There is a sense that some elements of the novel exist within a *very* specific and narrow window. (For how long will the average reader grok references to Harambe, for example?) But, this in itself is reflective of the ephemeral nature of life online. In an [interview with *Slate*](https://slate.com/culture/2021/02/patricia-lockwood-interview-debut-novel-no-one-is-talking-about-this.html), Lockwood refers to the ‚Äòboundedness‚Äô of the novel as a form, as an important contrast to the endlessness of the internet. So, this is a novel that knows about Trump, but not about COVID-19. In years to come it may take on new life as a piece of historical reportage about what it was like to use the social internet, very specifically, in the period 2016-2019. At the heart of the novel‚Äôs (kinda, sorta) diptych construction is the question of whether the forms of the social web allow for serious expression. In an [interview with *The London Review of Books*](https://youtu.be/Nnv5eyE7QbA), Lockwood considers the ways in which her novel examines the limitations of ‚Äòa pre-received form‚Äô of language that has come to characterise many of the internet‚Äôs social spaces. ‚ÄòAs the forms become rigid, masks do appear‚Äô she says of the manner in which the accepted forms of expression on social networks (in particular) limit how and what participants can express. *No One Is Talking About This* captures the sound and feeling of two great ice sheets butting up against one another: the sardonic, quixotic, ephemeral churn of the modern connected world; and the enormity and complexity of life‚Äôs events more widely. The attempt to say something *important* or deeply felt about one‚Äôs own life, running up against the predominant tones and forms of online spaces. As she phrases it in the aforementioned *Guernica* piece: > We do spend so much of our time online, putting things out there, trying to be funny or sound smart. It can be nice to put something up and say, ‚ÄúI have a big serious life thing on the other side of the screen, too.‚Äù My mom passed away last year, and I posted photos of her every so often as a reminder: She lived, this happened. In the *LRB* interview, Lockwood says that whilst writing she thought often of a line in George Elliot‚Äôs *Middlemarch*: > If we had a keen vision and feeling of all ordinary human life, it would be like hearing the grass grow and the squirrel‚Äôs heart beat, and we should die of that roar which lies on the other side of silence. Thus, what she calls ‚Äòthe diffuse pain of the portal‚Äô is that no one knows where their attention should be in any one moment. It is a place comprising ([in the words of Bo Burnham](https://genius.com/Bo-burnham-welcome-to-the-internet-lyrics)) ‚Äòa little bit of everything, all of the time‚Äô. *No One Is Talking About This* contrasts this against the focussing power of personal tragedy. The novel introduces us to a narrator who swims adroitly in the fast-flowing river of online life, before refocussing to encompass life offline: wider, more emotionally diverse, more implacably difficult.
‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢
*No One Is Talking About This* is a truly extraordinary accomplishment. It is a vital, timely novel that affords us the opportunity to ask important questions about the role of the internet in our lives. In the Slate interview mentioned above, Lockwood (b. 1982) characterises herself as being ‚Äòfrom the perfect internet generation, and you can put that in a pull quote because this is very important‚Äô. It may well be the case that I responded to this novel so strongly in part because I‚Äôm from that same micro-generation: a cohort of people who had a pre-internet childhood, for whom the advent of social networks came in their late adolescence or early adulthood. *No One Is Talking About This* encapsulates both what I love about the internet, and also many of the ways in which it frustrates, disappoints, and constrains us. The inability of the ubiquitous digital sphere ‚Äî with its aversion to depth, seriousness, nuance, complexity, and raw human feeling ‚Äî to cope with vital parts of our lives, deserves attention. That Lockwood has addressed it with a novel both hilarious and deeply moving is nothing short of masterful. I find it noteworthy that July & Burnham are both artists who work in multiple forms (as is Lockwood: poetry, memoir, novel), and whose work is interested in part in form itself.

items.title: Kazuo Ishiguro ‚Äî Klara and the Sun (2021)
items.content_html:
Part of a series on novels nominated for the 2021 Booker Prize
NB. This post discusses the entire novel; proceed at risk of spoilers.

Sir Kazuo Ishiguro is the only previous winner on this year‚Äôs Booker Prize longlist1, and I come to his novel ‚Äî Klara and the Sun ‚Äî in the week that it was cut from the running, having not made the shortlist. Nevertheless, it seems likely that this will be one of the most widely read of the current Booker crop, and it is a strong novel. In the final analysis, however, it didn‚Äôt shock me to find it missing from the shortlist, as I think it falls short of Ishiguro‚Äôs finest work in a couple of key ways.

In a 2015 interview with The Guardian, Kazuo Ishiguro is quoted as saying ‚ÄúI tend to write the same book over and over, or at least, I take the same subject I took last time out and refine it, or do a slightly different take on it.‚Äù The example that he offers for this is (his Booker Prize winning novel) The Remains of the Day (1989), which he refers to as a ‚Äúremake‚Äù of Artist of the Floating World (1986). Ishiguro frames both novels, despite their distinct settings, as works about what it means to waste one‚Äôs life: be it professional, personal, or romantic.

Much of the commentary around Klara and the Sun has figured the novel as a kind of ‚Äòremake‚Äô of 2005‚Äôs Never Let Me Go (2005). Both books fall within the broad category of literary science fiction, and both have at their heart shared questions around humanity. In a 2008 interview for The Paris Review, Ishiguro said this of why he chose to use clones as the protagonists in Never Let Me Go:

One of the attractions about using clones is that it makes people ask immediately, What does it mean to be a human being? It‚Äôs a secular route to the Dostoyevskian question, What is a soul?¬†

Undoubtedly, he is asking similar questions with this new novel, and approaching the subject from a slightly different angle. In Klara and the Sun the narration is from the perspective of the titular character, who is an artificial consciousness in a mechanical body2. Klara‚Äôs voice, as narrator, is pleasant and even, though the reader becomes increasingly aware of the ways in which she sees the world differently from those around her. I was reminded, in places, of Mark Haddon‚Äôs The Curious Incident of the Dog in the Night-Time (2003), which is narrated by a neurodiverse boy, whose perception of the world shapes the text to a large extent.

With novels in this mode it becomes the reader‚Äôs task to parse some of what is happening through the filter of how the narrator is experiencing it. In Klara‚Äôs case, we learn some of the peculiarities of how her vision works; we find that she is fond of specifics (particularly around things like measured dimensions and age); and we slowly grow accustomed to the fact that there are significant gaps in her understanding of the world. This form of narration is something of a double-edged sword in Klara and the Sun. It was certainly interesting to experience the world through a different lens, and to see how Klara perceives the places, people, and circumstances with which she comes into contact. However, increasingly I felt the absence of a dependable baseline of experience against which to make comparison. Unlike Haddon‚Äôs novel, for example, which is set in a recognisable turn-of-the-millennium Wiltshire, the reader necessarily cannot come to Ishiguro‚Äôs novel with any prior knowledge. This is a world of Artificial Friends and children who are ‚Äòlifted‚Äô; the reader‚Äôs wish to understand the intricacies of these things is often frustrated by either the narrator‚Äôs ignorance of them, her misunderstanding of them, or her lack of interest in them.

When an author chooses to present a unique world in first-person perspective, there will always be the question of how much explanatory work the narrator is expected to perform. It is a characteristic of many pure fantasy novels, for instance, that a first-person narrator is burdened not only with telling their own story, but also with explaining the nuances of a peculiar world to the reader. The opposite, as employed by Ishiguro here, is to have a narrator unaware (or uninterested) in their role as tour guide, who leaves the reader largely in the dark as to how the world of the novel functions. It becomes part of the work of reading the novel, in these cases, to piece together the concrete particulars of the book‚Äôs world. It will likely be a matter of individual readers‚Äô tastes as to how well they feel this is handled in Klara and the Sun. To my mind Ishiguro is operating a couple of steps beyond a level of obscurity that could have provided a richer experience. In the aforementioned Paris Review piece, Ishiguro says this of his writing style:

Most writers have certain things that they decide quite consciously, and other things they decide less consciously. In my case, the choice of narrator and setting are deliberate. You do have to choose a setting with great care, because with a setting come all kinds of emotional and historical reverberations.

By passing a world necessarily foreign to the reader through the somewhat distorted lens of Klara‚Äôs perception, I felt as though Ishiguro had deprived us of the means by which to truly know the world of his novel.

I also felt an uneasy tension in the construction and tone of the narrative. It is as though Ishiguro is not wholly decided as to whether or not the novel is to be read as allegory3.

One particular plot beat, for example, has an almost fairytale-like neatness. A character is conspicuously present who happens to possess the specialist knowledge required to effectively sabotage a particular machine. To compound this, the manner of sabotage happens to require a ‚Äòspecial liquid‚Äô which would be difficult to obtain were it not for the fact that it is also contained within the workings of Klara‚Äôs mechanical body. It is as though Ishiguro is too invested in furthering particular threads of plot, to worry about whether the action feels at all likely within the frame of his story.

Likewise, there is an irksome disparity between the function that some of the novel‚Äôs human characters ultimately wish for Klara to perform, and the reader‚Äôs clear understanding that she will not be capable of it. This is an instance in which the reader possesses greater clarity about Klara‚Äôs inner life than any of the humans who surround her can. To them, her simulacrum of a human being is often near-perfect; they do not know that her grasp of spatial awareness is so poor that she believes the Sun goes to rest at night in a particular building behind which it sets. When the novel raises questions about the distance between a human girl and an approximation of a human girl, it might frustrate the reader ‚Äì who alone knows that Klara believes all the pollution in the world to be caused by one machine ‚Äì that some characters in the novel believe it to be a negligible, bridgeable gap4.

The Nobel Prize in Literature is awarded for a body of work, with particular reason given for why the recipient was chosen. In Ishiguro‚Äôs case, when he was awarded the 2017 Prize, the Academy said that he has ‚Äòin novels of great emotional force‚Ä¶ uncovered the abyss beneath our illusory sense of connection with the world‚Äô. It is certainly possible to see this latest novel ‚Äî his first since having been awarded the Nobel Prize ‚Äî as a continuation of that project. And it is certainly a fascinating, immensely readable entry in that discourse.

Much of the above may read as though I did not enjoy Klara and the Sun, and that is not at all the case. Ishiguro is a masterful writer, with a deceptively simple prose style, and he is able to sustain the reader‚Äôs interest paragraph-to-paragraph and chapter-to-chapter with admirable ease. My complaints largely amount to subjective arguments about stylistic choices, and it is quite possible they may prove to be peculiarities of my own reading. It may well be the case that an approach to the novel that took it primarily as allegorical would find it all the more satisfying.

Towards the end of the book, after an indistinct passage of years has passed, there is a scene in which a roboticist explains to Klara (and thus the reader) that developments in artificial consciousness have outstripped human understanding. In turn, this has led to fear amongst people about the growing capabilities of non-biological minds.

They‚Äôre afraid because they can‚Äôt follow what‚Äôs going on inside any more. They can see what you do. They accept that your decisions, your recommendations, are sound and dependable, almost always correct. But they don‚Äôt like not knowing how you arrive at them.

Ironically, I found Klara and the Sun to be a very enjoyable and tenderly composed novel, which was somewhat at odds with its depiction of the functioning of its narrator‚Äôs artificial consciousness.

  1. Alongside Rachel Cusk and Richard Powers, he is one of three previous nominees. ↩︎

  2. A great deal of caution is required when discussing books in this genre space, to avoid using terms that may have specific connotations within the world of the novel. We might think of Klara, broadly, as an Artificial Intelligence, or say that she is an android, but these are not terms that the novel employs, and their absence is evidently a choice on the author‚Äôs part. ↩︎

  3. Likewise, there are certainly threads of the text that could be read as religious commentary; the intent, however, is not made explicit. ↩︎

  4. Consider, by way of comparison, Steven Spielberg‚Äôs 2001 film A.I. Artificial Intelligence, which raises this same question, but profits from the viewer‚Äôs comparatively less-direct access to the workings of an artificial consciousness. ↩︎

items.title: Karen Jennings ‚Äî¬†An Island (2021)
items.content_html:
Part of a series on novels nominated for the 2021 Booker Prize
NB. This post discusses the entire novel; proceed at risk of spoilers.

This is the sixth novel I‚Äôve read as part of the 2021 Booker Prize longlist marathon, and the first that has not been a pleasant reading experience. That isn‚Äôt intended in an entirely pejorative sense, since Karen Jennings is certainly aiming ‚Äì with some elements of An Island ‚Äì to make the reader uncomfortable.

The narrative moves back and forth between an undated present and past in the life of its protagonist: Samuel. In doing so, the novel gives a wider picture of the misery and loss he has endured before ending up alone on a desolate island where he serves as lighthouse keeper. When the introduction of an unnamed man breaks decades of Samuel‚Äôs solitude, the reader comes to realise that his presence represents not just a dramatic change in Samuel‚Äôs life, but an opportunity to atone for some mistakes of his past.

John Donne‚Äôs ‚ÄòMeditation XVII‚Äô, to which the title of Karen Jennings‚Äôs novel can‚Äôt help but allude, is an expression of common humanity, in which Donne expresses the human condition in terms of shared suffering:

No man is an island entire of itself; every man is a piece of the continent, a part of the main; if a clod be washed away by the sea, Europe is the less, as well as if a promontory were, as well as any manner of thy friends or of thine own were; any man’s death diminishes me, because I am involved in mankind. And therefore never send to know for whom the bell tolls; it tolls for thee.

It is certainly open to the charge of being morbid, but it is ultimately a hopeful work that revels in the universality of the human experience, including that of mortal death:

all mankind is of one author, and is one volume; when one man dies, one chapter is not torn out of the book, but translated into a better language

By contrast, I found An Island to be an unrelentingly pessimistic work, such that it leaves the reader feeling that it has nothing much to say. The most significant difference, I found, was a complete absence of faith in Jennings‚Äôs novel.

The locus of faith in Donne‚Äôs work is in the Christian God ‚Äî¬†Donne was, after all, an Anglican priest at the time of composing Devotions upon Emergent Occasions (1623) ‚Äî but An Island also calls to mind the works of staunch atheist Samuel Beckett. In plays such as Waiting for Godot (1952) and Endgame (1957), Beckett has pairs of characters marooned in unforgiving environs, with little hope for the future. In these works ‚Äî though the characters may be loathe to admit it ‚Äî faith is found in the human spirit‚Äôs endurance, and the stubborn will to survive. Despite stark settings and pitch dark subjects, these are plays of humour that find warmth in the natures of their characters, and in their interactions. An Island, by contrast, seemed to me entirely cynical. It lacks any sense whatsoever of a universal order, but it also refuses to replace it with any sense of faith in its characters‚Äô humanity, or in humanity generally.

The scope of the narrative, for instance, encompasses several eras of governance for its unnamed country. A revolution for independence replaces a colonial power with a President; the President is later overthrown in favour of a Dictator, and so on. Throughout, there are physical changes to some parts of the unnamed city, but the lives of the people barely change, and the slums do not improve, they only grow in size. Likewise, the novel has no faith in the power of people, or political activism, to engender meaningful change. Any sense of hope that a character experiences is quickly undercut by another, promising that it is futile:

The woman smiled, but the man said, ‚ÄúIt was like this for us too, uncle. I‚Äôm sorry to tell you that. We were exactly like you.‚Äù
Samuel‚Äôs father laughed. ‚ÄúNo, my friend, that isn‚Äôt possible. This is a free and democratic country. We‚Äôre independent, we have it all now. There will be no problems here. Your country did it the wrong way, you made mistakes.‚Äù
‚ÄúWait, uncle. You will see.‚Äù (p74)

And, when Samuel is moved to directly participate in frustrating for change, he too is quickly disillusioned:

The march could not be stopped. Not this tide of men and women who would no longer be told how to live. They had given up fear. They knew only strength.
Only afterwards, in the first interrogation room, did he learn that the march had been poorly attended, with little more than two thousand people participating. The event had barely disrupted the peace, and though hundreds had died and many more were arrested, it had made no impact at all. (p94)

Just as the works of groups are depicted as ineffectual, so the novel also has no faith in the ability of individuals to meaningfully change. Towards the end of the book, Jennings has reduced her elderly protagonist to little more than paranoia and base impulse:

He thought only of that word he had spoken down in the stone hut: violence ‚Äì though now he uttered another world altogether, ‚ÄúMine.‚Äù He stood up from where he had been kneeling. And again, ‚ÄúMine‚Äù as he grabbed the knife out of the man‚Äôs hand. ‚ÄúMine, mine, mine!‚Äù (p98)

The act of violence on which the novel ends is but the latest in a depressing, predictable sequence. It serves as but one more example in the novel of violence rendered in response to violence, and accomplishing nothing.

One might expect that in a novel so pessimistic about humanity, notes of optimism might be found in the depiction of nature. Instead, the natural world is often shown in An Island not as a force for rejuvenation, but as an adversary to be guarded against. Often, unsurprisingly in the world of the novel, this requires some form of violence:

he manipulated the weed with lit matches, watching it twist and shrivel, not stopping until he was certain enough damage had been done that it would never grow again. (p15)

At best, nature is sometimes shown to hold the power of erasure; for the most part, like the man-made change of the novel, much of what the natural world offers is bad and getting worse. A late scene depicts what at first seems to be a miraculous natural event: the annual arrival of giant crabs to the island. Quickly, however, the beauty of the event is undermined. The crabs (just like the island‚Äôs hens) attack one another, before the humans also attack the crabs. Next the reader is told of how precipitously the crab populations have declined, and how the small crabs that remain taste comparatively awful. If the sequence fails to depress, it is only because by this point in the novel the reader has likely been numbed into expecting nothing else.

Much of the above may have been more palatable to me, had I felt that the novel had something to say about a specific time, place, or culture. Instead, I felt that Jennings‚Äôs choice to make her novel purely an allegory robbed it of any chance of making meaningful political statements. Take, for example, this exchange, which is typical of the book‚Äôs political discourse:

‚ÄúBut you don‚Äôt agree with the idea of fighting against tyranny? You support the Dictator?‚Äù asked Big Ro.
‚ÄúNo, I‚Äôm not saying that. I know about opposing power. My father was amongst those who fought for independence.‚Äù (pp78-79)

Whom among us would support ‚Äòthe Dictator‚Äô? What does it mean to ‚Äòoppose power‚Äô, or ‚Äòfight for independence‚Äô? The novel is so determined to remain entirely allegorical that it absolutely refuses to be specific about any of these matters. Samuel‚Äôs political awakening is also rendered in similarly cursory terms:

They went to regular meetings, passed worn paperbacks between them in which they read theories of how to create a better world and life. They recited quotes from the texts, argued over words and phrases. At the meetings they rose, made speeches. (p91)

In an interview for LitNet, Jennings explicitly frames her responsibility as a novelist so as to exclude the need to answer any of the questions she poses:

My job as a writer is to hold a mirror up to these realities, but it is not within my abilities to suggest solutions.

The problem is that, so foggy and blurred is the mirror, that nothing can be seen of the ‚Äòrealities‚Äô but the vaguest of outlines. Does the reader agree, in principle, that it is right to ‚Äòoppose tyranny‚Äô? Regardless of the answer, the novel suggests, nothing will really change.

In another interview, this one with the Johannesburg Review of Books, Jennings discusses the difficulties she faced in writing An Island:

There was so much that was difficult about it. Firstly, trying to write a sensitive and nuanced book about a very complex set of topics‚Äîto do it without being heavy handed or reductive. Secondly, to write a readable, compelling story in which basically nothing happens!

To the first point, I found An Island to be too steeped in the vagaries of allegory to have anything insightful to say about either the political realities of post-colonialism, or the manner in which living in such circumstances might shape a person. And, as to the second point, I‚Äôm not convinced Jennings has succeeded there either. Paragraph-to-paragraph I enjoyed her writing well enough, but the relative slightness of the story, paired with its unrelenting cynicism, made the book feel increasingly like a chore as it progressed.

Unfortunately, the context in which I read An Island ‚Äî as part of a Booker Prize longlist marathon ‚Äî also makes for comparisons from which it does not profit. There is Anuk Arudpragasam‚Äôs A Passage North, which is more thoughtful and more grounded in its depiction of a country shaped by a history of conflict. items.title: Sunjeev Sahota ‚Äî China Room (2021)
items.content_html:
Part of a series on novels nominated for the 2021 Booker Prize
NB. This post discusses the entire novel; proceed at risk of spoilers.

The miserable have no other medicine
But only hope.

‚Äî Measure For Measure, Act III Scene i

Sunjeev Sahota is a British writer of Indian heritage, who was previously shortlisted for the Booker Prize in 2015, with his second novel: The Year of Runaways. That novel dealt with the lives of Indian immigrant workers in England, and followed Sahota‚Äôs first novel ‚Äî Ours Are the Streets (2011) ‚Äî which told the story of a British Pakistani‚Äôs radicalisation towards a terrorist act. China Room continues this examination of the topics of race, and entrapment within societal structures, but Sahota‚Äôs approach here is somewhat different.

The basic structure of China Room is an interweaving of two narratives separated by ~70 years, and three familial generations. Mehar Kaur lives on a farm in 1920s India, where she has been married to one of three brothers ‚Äì though she does not know which. At the close of the 20th century, her great-grandson arrives at the farm from his home in England, hoping to escape an addiction to heroin.

For the most part Mehar‚Äôs narrative ‚Äî which is based in part upon a story from Sahota‚Äôs own family history ‚Äî eschews the trappings of ‚Äòperiod‚Äô writing, and feels every bit as alive to the reader as the more modern strand. There is, however, one important exception: the centrality to the plot of something very like a ‚Äòbed trick‚Äô, a literary device that pre-dates the bible, whereby the plot is moved forward by improbable cases of mistaken identity during intercourse. Not only does it feel more like literary device than convincing plotting, but my primary association with it is from Shakespeare‚Äôs dark comedies: Measure For Measure, and All‚Äôs Well That Ends Well. This, unavoidably, coloured the tone of Sahota‚Äôs novel for me, such that I found myself treating it less like a piece of realism and more like a morality play. The characters are mostly well drawn, and Sahota has a talent for evoking the physical composition of scenes. At its heart though, Mehar‚Äôs narrative has an uneasy balance between its commitment to a romance plot, and the depth with which it can interrogate the complex injustices of her circumstance.

The other narrative suffers from a similar imbalance. The narrator‚Äôs addiction is inciting incident enough to get him to India, but I felt that the treatment of it afterwards was too cursory. Sahota‚Äôs way with detail and allusion is enough to convey some aspects of his narrator‚Äôs plight, but he‚Äôs unwilling to give over much narrative space to exploring the depths of addiction‚Äôs misery. For a writer of Sahota‚Äôs talents, this is clearly a choice about the type of novel he wants to write. I couldn‚Äôt help but feel some disappointment, however, at the focus being placed on a relatively predictable romance plot instead of something more substantive.

Ultimately I found China Room to be very readable; Sahota‚Äôs style is characterised by an easy flow, with a particular talent for enlivening scenes through the description of details such as facial expression and clothing. I found both of the narratives, separately, were enjoyable despite the reservations outlined above1. I remained less convinced, however, that the novel does much to draw out an interesting parallel between the two. There is the familial relationship, and the shared geographic location of the two plots. But, beyond that, there is only the broadest of generalities. In an interview with The Guardian around the novel‚Äôs release, Sahota attempts at first to make the case for a deeper connection between the book‚Äôs two narratives:

‚ÄúThe two strands of the novel talk to each other,‚Äù he says. ‚ÄúThere‚Äôs this mutual haunting that‚Äôs going along ‚Äì the echoes and the mirrorings and the whispers across time.‚Äù

However, I found the manner in which he goes on to characterise this relationship to be telling:

‚ÄúBoth characters are seeking a kind of liberation, and they‚Äôre both suffering.‚Äù

This, of course, could be said of virtually any protagonist in any novel. It is the very basis of storytelling that a character wants something, and suffers in trying to obtain it. In China Room, the mere fact that the two characters are blood relatives did not feel like enough to establish meaningful parallels between their individual struggles.

I came away from China Room having enjoyed the novel, though lamenting its slightness. Of course, it would have been a very different book if the stories of four generations had been included, and it is understandably not the novel that Sahota has set out to write. Nevertheless, choices such as the inclusion of the nascent Indian revolutionary movement as a plot element in Mehar‚Äôs story, left me wanting to know more of what happened to the family between the times of the two included narratives. I couldn‚Äôt escape the feeling that a vital part of the wider story had been elided, and that each half of the novel as it stands suffers from the absence. This, in turn, contributed to an overall sense that Sahota had elected to include parts of two narratives, as opposed to a satisfyingly deep exploration of either one. China Room could very well be the opening volume in a captivating family saga; I would return to its settings and characters, and to Sahota‚Äôs sure-handed depiction of them, with pleasure. As it stands however, I found China Room enjoyable, but somewhat wanting for depth.

  1. Indeed, my main complaint is that I wanted more detail, and more depth from each. ↩︎

items.title: Mary Lawson ‚Äî A Town Called Solace (2021)
items.content_html:
Part of a series on novels nominated for the 2021 Booker Prize
NB. This post discusses the entire novel; proceed at risk of spoilers.

Without having planned it this way, I seem to have begun reading the 2021 Booker Prize longlist by alternating philosophical novels with those more story-centric. A Town Called Solace falls firmly into the latter category, and as such I‚Äôm going to make an effort to leave story specifics to the end of these notes, so as not to spoil things for interested future readers.

One of the great strengths of A Town Called Solace is the interplay between its three narrators. The manner in which Mary Lawson portions out plot beats to the reader is well judged. Often one character‚Äôs narrative will tease a further revelation to which another of the narrator‚Äôs holds the missing piece. Even if the narrators themselves aren‚Äôt able to put all of the puzzle together, the reader feels increasingly rewarded by the plot‚Äôs breadcrumb trail. I enjoyed the interplay between the three narrators‚Äô blind spots, and how it placed the reader at the centre of a Venn diagram: the only one who got to see a full picture. Occasionally Lawson cannot help but use this device with good-natured cruelty, closing Chapter 7 with a dramatic event, and immediately switching (in Chapter 8) to the vantage point of the one character who isn‚Äôt involved. This, however, only served to keep me turning pages, and I found it to be an excellent method of constructing a thriller.

Alas, technique ‚Äî and Lawson‚Äôs perfectly serviceable, unexceptional writing style ‚Äî didn‚Äôt prove to be enough to sustain the novel for me. Having completed it, my overall impression was that the author was more interested in place than plot. Her love for the particular region of Canada in which the novel is set, is evident even before she opens the ‚ÄòAcknowledgements‚Äô section thus:

The town of Solace exists only in my imagination, but the setting is very real: the vast and beautiful area of lakes and rocks and forests known as the Canadian Shield, in Northern Ontario. Locating the story there was an act of self-indulgence on my part; it is the landscape I think of when I think of home, and writing about it allows me to revisit it in my mind. (p289)

It is a shame then, that Lawson doesn‚Äôt do enough to make the reader fall in love with her setting or her characters. When I think of Fannie Flagg‚Äôs southern US, or the Maine of many Stephen King novels, I have a far more vivid mental picture of the locales, and a better sense for the texture of the culture: the way the language is spoken, customs, and mannerisms. Those authors are both excellent at conjuring personality (of both persons and places) from detail, in a way that Lawson has not mastered. Even the narrators, with whom we necessarily spend the most time, remain less than fully realised up to the close of the novel.

Before writing in more specific detail about the plot, I‚Äôll close the non-spoiler portion of these notes by saying that A Town Called Solace is the weakest of the four longlisted novels I‚Äôve read thus far. It‚Äôs certainly not unenjoyable, but I came away feeling as though it had not fulfilled the potential of its setup, instead settling for sentimentality.

OK, if you‚Äôre still reading this I‚Äôm going to assume you‚Äôve either read the novel yourself or have no intention of doing so. If the former, I wonder whether you share my frustration with its denouement. Perhaps it is my failing as a reader, but to my mind a novel that sets as its inciting incident the disappearance of a young girl, should have in store some revelation about that mystery. In A Town Called Solace, Rose‚Äôs disappearance is treated as central to the plot, until it‚Äôs resolved in a cursory couple of paragraphs and thereafter has no bearing on the rest of the novel. I found this case of Chekhov‚Äôs missing girl to be deeply unsatisfying in a story sense. I had anticipated that upon Rose‚Äôs return she would provide a key missing piece to the mechanics of the plot, but instead it turns out that the author has merely kept her off the page as a way to animate strains of the narrative involving Clara and Liam. Rose, introduced as strong and wilful (at least through her sister‚Äôs eyes), is given no agency or voice, and the details of what happened to her are treated as entirely unimportant once her return has provided some form of resolution for Clara.

Similarly, I did not like the manner in which Liam‚Äôs story closes. It is possible, in showing his (and Jo‚Äôs) vacillations, that Lawson is attempting to construct a version of the running-to-the-airport scene that might end a romantic comedy. However, it‚Äôs a ‚Äòromance‚Äô introduced so late in the novel that there is no possible way a reader can feel any investment in it. Lawson lays out Jo‚Äôs backstory (including a needlessly cruel relationship history) in a short paragraph less than 20 pages before the close of the novel, as though just then realising that the character remains little more than a sketch. Likewise the third act arrival, and swift departure, of Fiona felt like a hollow attempt at showing the emotional progress Liam had made during his time in the wholesome, healing environs of Solace.

That Lawson chooses to end the novel with the first meeting between Liam and Moses (the cat with whom he has been sharing a house for months, but has never seen), speaks directly to the book‚Äôs sentimentality. I‚Äôm certainly not averse to that tone in principle, but in order for it to work the reader must feel invested in the world of the novel: its setting, and most importantly its characters. Without having planned it this way, I seem to have begun reading the 2021 Booker Prize longlist by alternating philosophical novels with those more story-centric. *A Town Called Solace* falls firmly into the latter category, and as such I‚Äôm going to make an effort to leave story specifics to the end of these notes, so as not to spoil things for interested future readers.
‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢
One of the great strengths of *A Town Called Solace* is the interplay between its three narrators. The manner in which Mary Lawson portions out plot beats to the reader is well judged. Often one character‚Äôs narrative will tease a further revelation to which another of the narrator‚Äôs holds the missing piece. Even if the narrators themselves aren‚Äôt able to put all of the puzzle together, the reader feels increasingly rewarded by the plot‚Äôs breadcrumb trail. I enjoyed the interplay between the three narrators‚Äô blind spots, and how it placed the reader at the centre of a Venn diagram: the only one who got to see a full picture. Occasionally Lawson cannot help but use this device with good-natured cruelty, closing Chapter 7 with a dramatic event, and immediately switching (in Chapter 8) to the vantage point of the one character who isn‚Äôt involved. This, however, only served to keep me turning pages, and I found it to be an excellent method of constructing a thriller. Alas, technique ‚Äî and Lawson‚Äôs perfectly serviceable, unexceptional writing style ‚Äî didn‚Äôt prove to be enough to sustain the novel for me. Having completed it, my overall impression was that the author was more interested in place than plot. Her love for the particular region of Canada in which the novel is set, is evident even before she opens the ‚ÄòAcknowledgements‚Äô section thus: > The town of Solace exists only in my imagination, but the setting is very real: the vast and beautiful area of lakes and rocks and forests known as the Canadian Shield, in Northern Ontario. Locating the story there was an act of self-indulgence on my part; it is the landscape I think of when I think of home, and writing about it allows me to revisit it in my mind. (p289) It is a shame then, that Lawson doesn‚Äôt do enough to make the reader fall in love with her setting or her characters. When I think of Fannie Flagg‚Äôs southern US, or the Maine of many Stephen King novels, I have a far more vivid mental picture of the locales, and a better sense for the texture of the culture: the way the language is spoken, customs, and mannerisms. Those authors are both excellent at conjuring personality (of both persons and places) from detail, in a way that Lawson has not mastered. Even the narrators, with whom we necessarily spend the most time, remain less than fully realised up to the close of the novel. Before writing in more specific detail about the plot, I‚Äôll close the non-spoiler portion of these notes by saying that *A Town Called Solace* is the weakest of the four longlisted novels I‚Äôve read thus far. It‚Äôs certainly not unenjoyable, but I came away feeling as though it had not fulfilled the potential of its setup, instead settling for sentimentality.
‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢
OK, if you‚Äôre still reading this I‚Äôm going to assume you‚Äôve either read the novel yourself or have no intention of doing so. If the former, I wonder whether you share my frustration with its denouement. Perhaps it is my failing as a reader, but to my mind a novel that sets as its inciting incident the disappearance of a young girl, should have in store some revelation about that mystery. In *A Town Called Solace*, Rose‚Äôs disappearance is treated as central to the plot, until it‚Äôs resolved in a cursory couple of paragraphs and thereafter has no bearing on the rest of the novel. I found this case of Chekhov‚Äôs missing girl to be deeply unsatisfying in a story sense. I had anticipated that upon Rose‚Äôs return she would provide a key missing piece to the mechanics of the plot, but instead it turns out that the author has merely kept her off the page as a way to animate strains of the narrative involving Clara and Liam. Lawson lays out Jo‚Äôs backstory (including a needlessly cruel relationship history) in a short paragraph less than 20 pages before the close of the novel, as though just then realising that the character remains little more than a sketch. I‚Äôm certainly not averse to that tone in principle, but in order for it to work the reader must feel invested in the world of the novel: its setting, and most importantly its characters. I didn‚Äôt feel as though *A Town Called Solace* did nearly enough to make that possible. What‚Äôs more, given how little it makes of the mystery at its centre, the book has little else to fall back on.

items.title: Anuk Arudpragasam ‚Äî A Passage North (2021)
items.content_html:
Part of a series on novels nominated for the 2021 Booker Prize
NB. This post discusses the entire novel; proceed at risk of spoilers.

One of the joys of choosing to read the entirety of the 2021 Booker Prize longlist, is being able to start novels knowing very little about them. I began Anuk Arudpragasam‚Äôs A Passage North without so much as having read the back cover, and I was delighted to find a novel full of heart and human feeling, unafraid to address the largest of topics with an assured, light touch.

I was most impressed by the structure of Arudpragasam‚Äôs novel, which has at its centre a relatively simple narrative: someone associated with the protagonist‚Äôs family dies, and he travels to attend their funeral. From here, however, the author uses the spine of the story to make a series of discursive forays into larger questions in Krishan‚Äôs life, and on his mind. The manner in which the text moves smoothly into and out of these extended meditations is handled with the utmost care. The reader finds themselves caught up in Krishan‚Äôs thoughts on a particular poem, or his hopes and fears surrounding his relationship with a partner,¬†and is then returned to the slow-moving flow of the main narrative with something more about Krishan‚Äôs character having been illuminated. These discursions¬†‚Äî¬†which hold a prominence in the text above that of the contemporary action, such that in truth they are the substance of the novel ‚Äî are sometimes intensely personal, and sometimes more widely scoped. As such, it will help the reader to have at least a broad understanding of the contours of the Sri Lankan civil war, but tellingly the more universally accessible themes are the more specific, interpersonal ones. I found particularly affecting the saga, relayed early in the novel, of Krishan‚Äôs grandmother‚Äôs declining health, and thus declining independence. Arudpragasam makes of it a delicate, compassionate examination of pride and human frailty.1

For the majority of the text, an overall arc to the novel remained hidden to me. However, towards the book‚Äôs conclusion I found Arudpragasam introducing a suggestion of personal growth for Krishan. In earlier periods described in the text he sometimes exhibits a tendency to conceive of his own experience as being, in some respects, qualitatively different to those of other people

It was as though for most of his life he‚Äôd been driven by a longing that was somehow stronger or more insistent than that of most people he knew, by a desire that had to meet more resistance than average before it could be vanquished

Towards the culmination of the narrative, however, his experiences at Rani‚Äôs funeral seem to have widened and softened Krishan‚Äôs thinking. He begins to comprehend something of the universality of the human experience, not just intellectually but on a deeper, more personal level. Arudpragasam has carefully introduced these ideas throughout the novel ‚Äî as part, for example, of Krishan‚Äôs retelling of the story of the Buddha ‚Äî but only towards the text‚Äôs conclusion does his protagonist begin to exhibit a deeper-seated, personal understanding of them.

This nascent insight, of course, cannot extinguish the baseline suffering of the human condition ‚Äî what, in Tamil, would be called ‡Æ§‡ØÅ‡Æï‡Øç‡Æï‡ÆÆ‡Øç (thukkam), and which western Buddhists are more likely to know by its Pali name: dukkha. Towards the very end of the text we find Krishan attempting to establish for himself a frame for this dilemma that places ‚Äòdesire‚Äô in contrast to ‚Äòyearning‚Äô:

To desire, in a sense, was to know or think one knew what one wanted, to know or think one knew the paths by which it might be reached, even if those paths turned out to be too difficult to follow, even if the things they led to, the things one desired, turned out not to provide the liberation one thought. To yearn on the other hand was to be lost, to lack bearings in the world because one did not know what one was seeking or where it could be found, so that unable to distract oneself, by frenetic activity or single-minded pursuit, from the painful sense of lack, one‚Äôs only consolation was to look out across vast distances, as if surely somewhere in the expansiveness of the horizon, across space and sea and sky, some possibility was contained that could make life self-sufficient and devoid of need, some possibility that could bring an end to time. That such a possibility didn‚Äôt exist he was now old enough to know‚Ä¶

This is useful in so far as it helps him toward an understanding of both the uniqueness and the universality of human suffering. It does not, however, offer him any reprieve. We do not witness Krishan return at this point to the tension between attachment and detachment that Arudpragasam has introduced elsewhere in the novel. Regardless, we feel that he has begun to develop a greater sense of compassion, and that in itself is a profound step.

Within a story rooted in the wider Tamil struggle against persecution, Arudpragasam offers the reader a picture of several lives burdened with unique struggles. By expertly revealing the universality of suffering within the human experience, he is able to offer a different vantage point from which to view struggle at any scale. That he is able to do all of this within the form of an immensely readable, warm, and very human novel, is a testament to his great talent as a novelist.

  1. It warrants mentioning that I think I found the character of Krishan‚Äôs grandmother all the more endearing because of the appearances that the author‚Äôs own grandmother makes in photos on his Instagram, such as this one, captioned ‚Äòfirst time out in two years‚Äô ↩︎

items.title: Lu√≠s Ant√≥nio ‚Äî Twelve Minutes (2021)
items.content_html:
During the week I played through Twelve Minutes, a video game from Lu√≠s Ant√≥nio & Annapurna Interactive, and I need to vent a little! I’ve been looking forward to this title for a while, a) because I like games that centre story; b) because I take Annapurna’s imprimatur as indicative of a level of quality; and c) because its time-loop mechanic sounded unique.

I’m more or less fighting the urge to write something longer here, because generally I don’t like to write negative pieces ‚Äì if I don’t enjoy something I tend to just not write about it, and move on. Twelve Minutes, however, proved to be such a disappointment on several different levels that I have to at least say something brief.

In short, this is a game with six single-screen environments1, approximately two-dozen objects with which one can interact2, and four characters, only two of whom are anything more than a plot device.

The headline actors are wasted on a script that is cumbersome and poorly thought out. The storytelling, which requires a certain density because it needs to develop in twelve minute increments, is doled out in a heavy-handed manner that elicited from me an eye-roll or groan with most of its beats. The less said about the final twist, upon which the entire thing depends, the better. Suffice to say that it makes so little sense as to undermine any affection for the characters that the player may have developed despite the rest of the game’s glaring flaws. I found myself, hours after finishing the game, shaking my head at how poorly conceived the whole thing is, and how badly it’s executed.

Worst of all, the act of playing Twelve Minutes quickly becomes repetitive and unenjoyable. Even if the player is able to parse the game’s often non-sensical logic so as to understand what they need to do next, they are required to play out the rote preceding steps for a sixth time to reach an inflection point. This includes the game compelling the player to repeatedly drug their pregnant wife into a state of unconsciousness ‚Äì just one of several instances of abhorrent violence upon a pregnant woman, about which the game does nothing to warn the player.

OK, I’m going to stop myself there. Twelve Minutes was first previewed in 2015, and I found it difficult to believe that the finished product some six years later was so slight, and so thoroughly disappointing in terms of both storytelling and game mechanics. At the time of writing, the game is available on Game Pass3; however, even if you’re a subscriber to that service, I can only recommend that you play it if you wish to be perplexed, disappointed, and then infuriated.

  1. And, if we’re being honest, it’s really just three small rooms and a cupboard.¬†¬† ↩︎

  2. Again, fewer than ten of them are either of any importance to the game’s plot or required for the furtherance of its action. ↩︎

  3. And, honestly, thank goodness for that! If I had paid ¬£20.99 for it I would be livid.¬†¬† ↩︎
