items.title: Maggie Shipstead ‚Äî Great Circle (2021)
items.content_html:
Part of a series on novels nominated for the 2021 Booker Prize

In some ways the second book in my marathon read of the 2021 Booker Prize could not be more different from the first. Whereas Rachel Cusk‚Äôs Second Place is a slim, dense novel of ideas, which confines its action to a single spread of marshland, Maggie Shipstead‚Äôs Great Circle is an epic in multiple senses of that word. Its story is rich, and is peopled with a diverse cast of characters, whose lives Shipstead weaves together into an expansive tapestry, spread over decades and continents.

I feel as though my notes here should be presented in two sections: this first, which need only be short, is directed at anyone who‚Äôs wondering whether they should read this novel. I can only say that I found Great Circle to be an unalloyed pleasure. The experience of reading it was reminiscent of first encounters with similarly ambitious novels, such as Michael Chabon‚Äôs The Amazing Adventures of Kavalier & Clay (2000), and Donna Tartt‚Äôs The Goldfinch (2013). Having deliberately begun the novel with no prior knowledge, I was at first surprised and delighted, and then found myself walking the emotional tightrope of being so impressed and swept along by a novel that I was desperate for it to not falter! And it does not; having spent the best part of the last two days reading Great Circle I can honestly say I‚Äôm already looking forward to revisiting it in years to come.

This is a book that is unrelentingly generous in its gifts, offering the reader countless brilliantly-orchestrated set pieces and unforgettable moments in its characters‚Äô lives. It‚Äôs as though, having begun the novel with a sinking ocean liner, then moving to mountaintop horse-riding, and biplane flying barnstormers, Shipstead thinks why not, and proceeds to include Prohibition era gangsters, bordellos, assassination, wartime romance, and finally ‚Äì of course ‚Äì¬†a flight around the world. At each turn I found myself marvelling at both the novel‚Äôs scope and its ambition. In lesser hands it is a recipe for either a jumbled mess or at best some camp, pulpy fun. Shipstead, however, reaches for far more, and has the talent necessary to attain it.

As an interval, here‚Äôs a small bonus since the novel inspired me to fire up Microsoft Flight Simulator. They didn‚Äôt have a Steerman in the game, but this is a shot of a biplane I took out over Missoula, MT just to get a better sense of what that experience might look like.


OK, if you‚Äôre still reading, be warned that the following gives some specifics for this wonderful novel that you should absolutely read.

To my mind, one of the book‚Äôs great successes is the extent to which it manages to remain interested simultaneously in both the macro and micro: the grand sweep of the narrative ‚Äî encompassing several generations of multiple families ‚Äî is bejewelled with many moments of crystalline beauty. Shipstead unfailingly knows when best to pause the story‚Äôs self-perpetuated momentum, and indulge in the scenes that she has brought about. Take, as just one example, this passage from the beginning of the novel that feels as though the author is pulling the camera out, better to frame the action:

Below [the ship‚Äôs] lights and honeycombed cabins, below the men toiling in red heat and black dust, below her barnacled keel, a school of cod passed, a dense pack of flexing bodies in the darkness, eyes bulging wide though there was nothing to see. Below the fish: cold and pressure, empty black miles, a few strange, luminescent creatures drifting after flecks of food. Then the sandy bottom, blank except for faint trails left by hardy shrimp, blind worms, creatures who would never know such a thing as light existed. (p20)

On countless occasions, Shipstead proves herself to be enormously skilled at conjuring striking images that leaps off the page for the reader:

Once a riderless horse had run into the hangar at their aerodrome from God knows where, dreadfully burned, perhaps mistaking the structure for a barn. They‚Äôd shot the poor thing to put it out of its misery. ‚ÄúOne time,‚Äù Felix said, ‚ÄúI was shooting at a German and his engine caught fire, so he climbed out onto the wing and jumped. He was wearing a huge brown fur coat and looked like a bear falling through the sky. (p89)

And, whilst I frequently found myself re-reading such moments to enjoy the frame that Shipstead had frozen, the true pleasure of the novel comes from immersing oneself in the grand, romantic architecture of its narrative. Great Circle has at its core some big questions: such as that of the individual‚Äôs power to pursue their ambitions, and the extent to which ambition itself is a dangerous compass by which to navigate. I found these threads intertwined with the similarly large and thorny question of destiny in the novel, in a manner that grew pleasantly more nuanced and complicated throughout.

Early in the book allusions are made suggesting a natural order by which things progress: Marian‚Äôs uncle Wallace explaining to her that ‚ÄòWater was always on its way somewhere bigger‚Äô (p45). And, indeed, it feels like love-at-first-sight to Marian when she initially encounters flight first hand. But, as the novel progresses, there is a more troubling instance of love-at-first-sight figured in Barclay‚Äôs controlling obsession with Marian.

These loves each prove to be fraught in different ways. As Barclay comes to find that ‚Äòwhat he wants is not actually in her but beyond her‚Äô (p204), so Marian ‚Äòlongs to fly on even though the horizon will only ever recede‚Äô (p195). The central tenet of their relationship proves to be that Marian often gets what she wants, but wonders constantly at the price; she ‚Äòsenses she is inside a trap, the dimensions and mechanism of which remain concealed‚Äô (p187).

The relationship remains compelling precisely because Shipstead resists the temptation to make Barclay out as a cartoon villain, and is content to complicate the dynamics, and leave the complications unresolved. When the trade of sex in return for flying ‚Äòover the line‚Äô happens, it is not clear to the reader whose idea it ultimately is, Marian‚Äôs or Barclay‚Äôs.

When, later in the text, Hadley critiques Carol Redwood‚Äôs book for trying to make Marian into too much of a romantic character, it helped emphasise for me the extent to which, throughout Great Circle, Shipstead walks this line assuredly. She is always more interested in making Marian a fuller, more nuanced presence no matter how grand and romantic the arc of her life might appear from the macro perspective.

If I had one quibble with the novel, it is that as the narratives progresses it develops a slight problem with stakes. Switching between Marian‚Äôs life-and-death exploits during the Second World War, to Hadley‚Äôs love triangle, sometimes made the latter seem ridiculous. I found myself increasingly frustrated with Hadley‚Äôs sometimes myopic narration in these passages, precisely because her problems were comparatively slight.

There is every chance, however, that this has something to do with me as a reader. There is one stretch, about two thirds of the way through the novel, where multiple chapters in a row deal first with Hadley‚Äôs complicated relationship with Alexei, then Marian‚Äôs complicated relationship with Caleb, and then Jamie‚Äôs complicated relationship with Sarah. Shipstead may have constructed things this way so as to invite the reader to draw comparisons, but the beats of these relationships were never as interesting to me as the larger themes of the novel. As such, the portions of the book that centred relationship intrigue for extended periods felt to me like distractions from the real narrative, to which I longed to return.

It was around this same point in the novel that I began to hope that there would prove to be more to Hadley‚Äôs story than simply a clever device, teasing the reader as to what happened to Marian. Ultimately I was pleased that Shipstead refrained from making explicit comparisons between the two women. She simply provides the raw material, and allows the reader to draw from it what they wish. I, for example, enjoyed the parallel between Marian‚Äôs experience in the endless white of the Antarctic, and Hadley‚Äôs in the darkness of the glow worm cave: both women unsure whether they are still alive, or if they‚Äôve unknowingly passed through the veil into death. In the final analysis Hadley‚Äôs story proves to be far more than a mere plot device, but the novel is very much Marian‚Äôs. ![](/uploads/2023/2dc55ce354.png) Part of a series on [novels nominated for the 2021 Booker Prize](/booker21) In some ways the second book in my marathon read of the 2021 Booker Prize could not be more different from the first. Whereas Rachel Cusk‚Äôs [*Second Place*](/secondplace) is a slim, dense novel of ideas, which confines its action to a single spread of marshland, Maggie Shipstead‚Äôs *Great Circle* is an epic in multiple senses of that word. Its story is rich, and is peopled with a diverse cast of characters, whose lives Shipstead weaves together into an expansive tapestry, spread over decades and continents.
‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢
I feel as though my notes here should be presented in two sections: this first, which need only be short, is directed at anyone who‚Äôs wondering whether they should read this novel. I can only say that I found *Great Circle* to be an unalloyed pleasure. The experience of reading it was reminiscent of first encounters with similarly ambitious novels, such as Michael Chabon‚Äôs *The Amazing Adventures of Kavalier & Clay* (2000), and Donna Tartt‚Äôs *The Goldfinch* (2013). Having deliberately begun the novel with no prior knowledge, I was at first surprised and delighted, and then found myself walking the emotional tightrope of being so impressed and swept along by a novel that I was desperate for it to not falter! And it does not; having spent the best part of the last two days reading *Great Circle* I can honestly say I‚Äôm already looking forward to revisiting it in years to come. This is a book that is unrelentingly generous in its gifts, offering the reader countless brilliantly-orchestrated set pieces and unforgettable moments in its characters‚Äô lives. It‚Äôs as though, having begun the novel with a sinking ocean liner, then moving to mountaintop horse-riding, and biplane flying barnstormers, Shipstead thinks *why not*, and proceeds to include Prohibition era gangsters, bordellos, assassination, wartime romance, and finally ‚Äì of course ‚Äì¬†a flight around the world. At each turn I found myself marvelling at both the novel‚Äôs scope and its ambition. In lesser hands it is a recipe for either a jumbled mess or at best some camp, pulpy fun. Shipstead, however, reaches for far more, and has the talent necessary to attain it.
‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢
As an interval, here‚Äôs a small bonus since the novel inspired me to fire up *Microsoft Flight Simulator*. They didn‚Äôt have a Steerman in the game, but this is a shot of a biplane I took out over Missoula, MT just to get a better sense of what that experience might look like. ![](/uploads/2023/083e11a86a.png)
‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢
OK, if you‚Äôre still reading, be warned that the following gives *some* specifics for this wonderful novel that you should absolutely read. To my mind, one of the book‚Äôs great successes is the extent to which it manages to remain interested simultaneously in both the macro and micro: the grand sweep of the narrative ‚Äî encompassing several generations of multiple families ‚Äî is bejewelled with many moments of crystalline beauty. Shipstead unfailingly knows when best to pause the story‚Äôs self-perpetuated momentum, and indulge in the scenes that she has brought about. Take, as just one example, this passage from the beginning of the novel that feels as though the author is pulling the camera out, better to frame the action: > Below [the ship‚Äôs] lights and honeycombed cabins, below the men toiling in red heat and black dust, below her barnacled keel, a school of cod passed, a dense pack of flexing bodies in the darkness, eyes bulging wide though there was nothing to see. Below the fish: cold and pressure, empty black miles, a few strange, luminescent creatures drifting after flecks of food. Then the sandy bottom, blank except for faint trails left by hardy shrimp, blind worms, creatures who would never know such a thing as light existed. (p20) On countless occasions, Shipstead proves herself to be enormously skilled at conjuring striking images that leaps off the page for the reader: > Once a riderless horse had run into the hangar at their aerodrome from God knows where, dreadfully burned, perhaps mistaking the structure for a barn. They‚Äôd shot the poor thing to put it out of its misery. ‚ÄúOne time,‚Äù Felix said, ‚ÄúI was shooting at a German and his engine caught fire, so he climbed out onto the wing and jumped. He was wearing a huge brown fur coat and looked like a bear falling through the sky. (p89) And, whilst I frequently found myself re-reading such moments to enjoy the frame that Shipstead had frozen, the true pleasure of the novel comes from immersing oneself in the grand, romantic architecture of its narrative. *Great Circle* has at its core some big questions: such as that of the individual‚Äôs power to pursue their ambitions, and the extent to which ambition itself is a dangerous compass by which to navigate. I found these threads intertwined with the similarly large and thorny question of destiny in the novel, in a manner that grew pleasantly more nuanced and complicated throughout. Early in the book allusions are made suggesting a natural order by which things progress: Marian‚Äôs uncle Wallace explaining to her that ‚ÄòWater was always on its way somewhere bigger‚Äô (p45). And, indeed, it feels like love-at-first-sight to Marian when she initially encounters flight first hand. But, as the novel progresses, there is a more troubling instance of love-at-first-sight figured in Barclay‚Äôs controlling obsession with Marian. These loves each prove to be fraught in different ways. As Barclay comes to find that ‚Äòwhat he wants is not actually in her but beyond her‚Äô (p204), so Marian ‚Äòlongs to fly on even though the horizon will only ever recede‚Äô (p195). The central tenet of their relationship proves to be that Marian often gets what she wants, but wonders constantly at the price; she ‚Äòsenses she is inside a trap, the dimensions and mechanism of which remain concealed‚Äô (p187). The relationship remains compelling precisely because Shipstead resists the temptation to make Barclay out as a cartoon villain, and is content to complicate the dynamics, and leave the complications unresolved. When the trade of sex in return for flying ‚Äòover the line‚Äô happens, it is not clear to the reader whose idea it ultimately is, Marian‚Äôs or Barclay‚Äôs. When, later in the text, Hadley critiques Carol Redwood‚Äôs book for trying to make Marian into too much of a romantic character, it helped emphasise for me the extent to which, throughout *Great Circle*, Shipstead walks this line assuredly. She is always more interested in making Marian a fuller, more nuanced presence no matter how grand and romantic the arc of her life might appear from the macro perspective.
‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢
If I had one quibble with the novel, it is that as the narratives progresses it develops a slight problem with stakes. Switching between Marian‚Äôs life-and-death exploits during the Second World War, to Hadley‚Äôs love triangle, sometimes made the latter seem ridiculous. I found myself increasingly frustrated with Hadley‚Äôs sometimes myopic narration in these passages, precisely because her problems were comparatively slight. There is every chance, however, that this has something to do with me as a reader. There is one stretch, about two thirds of the way through the novel, where multiple chapters in a row deal first with Hadley‚Äôs complicated relationship with Alexei, then Marian‚Äôs complicated relationship with Caleb, and then Jamie‚Äôs complicated relationship with Sarah. Shipstead may have constructed things this way so as to invite the reader to draw comparisons, but the beats of these relationships were never as interesting to me as the larger themes of the novel. As such, the portions of the book that centred relationship intrigue for extended periods felt to me like distractions from the real narrative, to which I longed to return. It was around this same point in the novel that I began to hope that there would prove to be more to Hadley‚Äôs story than simply a clever device, teasing the reader as to what happened to Marian. Ultimately I was pleased that Shipstead refrained from making explicit comparisons between the two women. She simply provides the raw material, and allows the reader to draw from it what they wish. I, for example, enjoyed the parallel between Marian‚Äôs experience in the endless white of the Antarctic, and Hadley‚Äôs in the darkness of the glow worm cave: both women unsure whether they are still alive, or if they‚Äôve unknowingly passed through the veil into death. In the final analysis Hadley‚Äôs story proves to be far more than a mere plot device, but the novel is very much Marian‚Äôs. I can imagine that knowing this, and thus being free from second-guessing the author‚Äôs intentions as to structure, will only strengthen this already extraordinary book for me on a second reading.

items.title: Rachel Cusk ‚Äî Second Place (2021)
items.content_html:
Part of a series on novels nominated for the 2021 Booker Prize
NB. This post discusses the entire novel; proceed at risk of spoilers.

The first stop on my 2021 Booker Prize longlist odyssey is the latest novel from an author with whom I‚Äôm already familiar. Second Place is the first work of fiction Rachel Cusk has published since the completion of her Outline trilogy three years ago1; I read those three books ‚Äî Outline (2014); Transit (2017); & Kudos (2018) ‚Äî earlier this year, and the experience left me eager to explore more of her work. It‚Äôs fortunate for me then, that Second Place has garnered Cusk her second Booker nomination.

Much has been made of the statement in the ‚ÄòAcknowledgements‚Äô section of Second Place, that the novel ‚Äòowes a debt to Lorenzo in Taos, Mabel Dodge Luhan‚Äôs 1932 memoir of the time D. H. Lawrence came to stay with her in Taos‚Äô. Doubtless, this touchstone offers one lens through which we can view Cusk‚Äôs novel, but it is perhaps most instructive merely in terms of the book‚Äôs form. Second Place (similar to Dodge Luhan‚Äôs memoir) is a kind of epistolary work, presented as an extended outpouring by the narrator (M) to one Jeffers, about whom we learn little. In truth, however, I read Second Place as following not in Dodge Luhan‚Äôs footsteps, but more closely in those of DH Lawrence.

In her introduction to the 2011 Vintage edition of Lawrence‚Äôs The Rainbow, Cusk quotes from a letter Lawrence wrote in 1913, in which he argues that the most vital pursuit of his age should be ‚Äòthe establishment of a new relation, or the re-adjustment of the old one, between men and women‚Äô. This, Cusk argues, is precisely the project in which Lawrence is engaged across both The Rainbow (1915) and its sequel, Women in Love (1920). As she phrases the question:

Without the context of hearth and home, childbearing, male protection inextricable from female servitude, what will love between a man and woman be?

A century later, the same question is at the centre of Cusk‚Äôs novel. Throughout the book we witness M struggle with understanding, or re-conceiving, her place in the world: what is her proper relationship to the people and structures in it, and to what extent are those relationships open to self-determination or imposed by external forces? As Cusk phrased it in a recent interview with Politics & Prose, M is troubled by the question of ‚Äònot being sure whether the whole of femininity was a trick that you fell for‚Äô. Thus, the reader is presented with a tapestry of M‚Äôs thoughts and feelings on subjects such as the evolution of her relationship with her daughter:

True love is the product of freedom, and I‚Äôm not sure a parent and child can ever have that kind of love, unless they decide to start over again as adults. (p75)

and the promise and limitations of the creative act:

Because this is partly a story of will, and of the consequences of exerting it, you will notice, Jeffers, that everything I determined to happen happened, but not as I wanted it! This is the difference, I suppose, between an artist and an ordinary person: the artist can create outside himself the perfect replica of his own intentions. The rest of us just create a mess, or something hopelessly wooden, no matter how brilliantly we imagined it. (p22)

It is a hallmark of Cusk‚Äôs narrators that they are at once highly perceptive (of both the world around them, and of their own interior worlds), and also have a mysterious access to the interior worlds of others. A different novelist may choose to reveal elements of characters‚Äô histories, personalities, thoughts and feelings, if not by employing omniscient third-person narration then through extended sections of dialogue. Cusk largely elides these conversations, and often allows her first-person narrators an almost mystical-seeming access to the inner lives of others. This, coupled with the manner in which Cusk constructs her narratives to shift easily and seamlessly between times, places, and topics, gives her novels a dreamlike quality. The reader commonly finds themselves transported, in the space of a few pages, between several periods, places, topics, and states of mind ‚Äì the shifts effected frictionlessly and rendered in exquisite, flowing paragraphs.

It felt to me as though Cusk provides a greater sense of evolution in Second Place than was the case in the Outline trilogy. Towards the novel‚Äôs culmination there are indications that M has made progress towards, if not resolution, at least finding a greater sense of peace in the search. Second Place is a book to which I‚Äôm likely to return; the density of its ideas and unanswered questions can sometimes feel overwhelming, but it rewards the reader‚Äôs willingness to be open to them.

  1. A collection of essays, titled Coventry, was published in 2019. ↩︎

items.title: Rizzo v Freeman
items.content_html:
Baseball is ridiculous. Sport, actually, when you think about it: ridiculous. Aren’t there better things all these super-fit men and women could be doing with their time and their gifted mastery of their own bodies? Surely. But the beautiful things human beings create are rarely useful, they are made for different reasons.

There are plenty of people on the internet this morning expressing their frustration at the Chicago Cubs' recent performance. I get it: the team has lost five straight games and hasn’t scored a single run in the last 20 innings of play; 24 games into the season they’re last in their division, and only two teams in the majors have a worse record.

But there’s still a lot of beauty in this game. Take for example the storyline that has been playing out between Cubs' first baseman, Anthony Rizzo, and his Atlanta Braves counterpart, Freddie Freeman. Drafted one year apart, both Golden Glove winners and multiple-time All Stars, their respective performances on the field have been inspiring comparison for years. What’s more, they’re both eminently likeable people who happen to be friends. So, when the former caught the latter in a rundown during a game last week, it was our good fortune that he was wearing a microphone:

Final: Braves 13, Cubs 4. pic.twitter.com/wh8N3DfSbb

— Chicago Cubs (@Cubs) April 19, 2021

That moment inspired a t-shirt, which Freeman naturally ended up wearing. And then, last night, when another game was beyond the reach of the Cubs' silent offence, manager David Ross gave his first baseman a chance to pitch to his friend. Freeman had hits in each of his four prior plate appearances in the game, including a home run in the previous inning. But his red hot bat was no match for Rizzo’s‚Ä¶ checks notes‚Ä¶ 74mph fastball. It’s worth watching the battle in full, but the joy of the moment is hard to miss.

Take a seat, FREDERICK.@ARizzo44 pic.twitter.com/ArqdIRVuM3

— Chicago Cubs (@Cubs) April 29, 2021

And yet many people seem to miss it. [1, 2, 3, 4]

For those to whom the final score is everything, it seems as though reading the box score would be as good as watching the game. If you can’t take joy from moments like these the whole enterprise of sport is completely lost on you. Despite his embarrassment at the plate, Freddie Freeman gets it:

That‚Äôs one strikeout I‚Äôm okay with. That‚Äôs what baseball is; that‚Äôs what sports is: it‚Äôs to put smiles on people‚Äôs faces. I was on the wrong side of it tonight, but I‚Äôm okay with it. I‚Äôm sure a lot of people got some good smiles and laughs, ‚Äòcause that‚Äôs what sports is about.

items.title: On c. 20 Years of Writing on the Web
items.content_html:
Recently, apropos of nothing in particular, I did some thinking about how and why I got started blogging. That led to a mild shock of realisation that it had been two decades since I first created a Blogger account. In turn, that seemed like reason enough for a little reflection.

How It Started

Along one of the shorter sides of the University of Reading’s main campus green space sits a building constructed mostly from dark brown brick, with a white entrance fa√ßade. This weirdly angular structure is the Palmer Building, and it was home to a couple of milestone moments for me during my time at the University. It was in the 400 seat Palmer Lecture Theatre that I sat watching a documentary about the Sex Pistols, whilst the rest of my Law school cohort attended a gala function. It was in the same lecture hall that I saw my first iPod in the wild, looking eagerly (perhaps even a little creepily) over another student’s shoulder as he scrolled and scrolled that mechanical wheel, changing selections on the monochrome screen. I myself, at the time, was notoriously never more than arm’s reach from my CD Walkman ‚Äì¬†one professor started calling me ‘wired for sound’ for my habit of wearing headphones around my neck during her seminars.

However, it isn’t the lecture theatre of the Palmer Building that I remember most clearly, but the room directly beneath it. On a couple of rows of tables were set out a dozen or so chunky Pentium II PCs: dull metal towers the size of a (large) briefcase, and CRT monitors as deep as they were wide. At a time when only 13% of UK homes were connected to the internet, there was something magical to me about a roomful of machines wired up to the web. And the real joy of that room was that, unlike the rest of the building, it could be accessed 24 hours a day. I was already enamoured of the internet by the time I reached University in 1999, but that was where the relationship really developed. With a magnetic keycard and an entry code I could access the web any time I wanted. And so I did. Foregoing study, socialising, and sleep, I frequently left my room in Wells Hall in the late evening and ‚Äî with Neon Ballroom or Hybrid Theory on my headphones ‚Äî made the 10 minute walk to the Palmer Building Computer Room. Often the number pad on which you were expected to enter an access code refused to cooperate, and you had to rely on there being someone else inside who had also chosen to spend their night with the internet, and who would answer your pleading knock.

It was in that room that I asked and was asked for my ‘a/s/l’ on the brand new MSN Messenger. It was there that I ignored all dictums against installing software, and instead lobbied my fellow late night denizens to join me in multiplayer LAN sessions of Doom II. When Yahoo! Groups launched during my second year, I spent uncountable late night hours in that room arguing the merits of various punk bands with Americans in the middle of their days, and Europeans even deeper into their nights.

It was to that room that I went on September 11th 2001, having received an SMS on my Nokia 3210 from an ex-girlfriend telling me to turn on the TV. My TV wasn’t hooked up, but I knew a place I could get all the information I needed, and where I’d be able to join countless other people asking one another just what the heck was going on.

And it was also in that room that I began writing my first blog. Hosted on Pyra Labs' Blogger (pre Google acquisition), mine was the simplest stream of posts on the music I was listening to, films I was watching, books I was reading, and games I was playing.

If you wanted to hear why Deftones' White Pony was an instant classic; observe in real-time as Mulholland Drive melted my mind; read an argument about what made Invisible Monsters a worthy follow-up to Fight Club; or lament the premature death of the Dreamcast, I had you covered. In the years since, I’ve had blogs and personal sites hosted on various platforms (Wordpress, Squarespace, Svbtle), and in truth the subject matter has remained largely unchanged! Occasionally I’ve run social accounts alongside these sites, but the blog was always there as a home for my more considered lengthier thoughts.

How It’s Going

In the year 2021 I find myself several years deep into a state of confusion about what the social web has become. As the internet has grown increasingly omnipresent and ubiquitous, the amount of content generated has grown exponentially, but ‚Äî at least in the most heavily trafficked spaces ‚Äî the forms of expression have become homogenised. The vast majority of published material is made to fit into one of a vanishingly small number of moulds. Likewise, platform ubiquity has led to a weird blurring of previously guarded lines: social / professional; public / private etc. The nature(s) of connections between people, groups, corporations, and institutions has undergone a series of seismic shifts facilitated by these technologies.

Nine years ago I published a post titled ‘The Social Web Got Weird'1. Re-reading it now it’s fascinating how things have further developed; not as I had expected, or predicted, that’s for sure. About three years ago I published a somewhat torturous post seeking to explain the idiosyncrasies of how I used Twitter. The short version is that I had found it necessary to contort myself into all manner of untenable postures just to feel OK about using the social web. That’s not a hole I’ve managed to entirely dig my way out of, but my thinking continues to evolve.

At present I have accounts all over the place‚Ä¶ but none of them are active. Or, I guess it might be more accurate to say that they are largely ‘read-only’. Some of these tools have more than proven their utility; for example, the experience of following a baseball season without Twitter would now feel much diminished. In many other cases I feel drawn to at least be notionally present simply because of how interested I am in the internet as a phenomenon. The web is still capable of making me feel thrilled and captivated and engaged. For me, the internet’s staggering power and potential remain undimmed since those days (and nights) in the Palmer Building Computer Room. The bottom line is that the web is still a place I want to be, and I have an inkling that the blog format still holds promise for me ~20 years after I first created one.

  1. Side note: that post (not quite a decade old) contains links out to six different sources, every single one of which now returns a 404. Usually I try and fix these things when I spot them, but I quite like the irony of it in this instance ‚Äî¬†link rot is real! ↩︎

Recently, apropos of nothing in particular, I did some thinking about how and why I got started blogging. That led to a mild shock of realisation that it had been two decades since I first created a Blogger account. In turn, that seemed like reason enough for a little reflection.

### How It Started

Along one of the shorter sides of the University of Reading's main campus green space sits a building constructed mostly from dark brown brick, with a white entrance fa√ßade. This weirdly angular structure is the [Palmer Building](https://goo.gl/maps/vJhbmebJTtfWgDEn8), and it was home to a couple of milestone moments for me during my time at the University. It was in the 400 seat Palmer Lecture Theatre that I sat watching a [documentary about the Sex Pistols](https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0236216/), whilst the rest of my Law school cohort attended a gala function. It was in the same lecture hall that I saw my first iPod in the wild, looking eagerly (perhaps even a little creepily) over another student's shoulder as he scrolled and scrolled that mechanical wheel, changing selections on the monochrome screen. I myself, at the time, was notoriously never more than arm's reach from my CD Walkman ‚Äì¬†one professor started calling me 'wired for sound' for my habit of wearing headphones around my neck during her seminars.

However, it isn't the lecture theatre of the Palmer Building that I remember most clearly, but the room directly beneath it. On a couple of rows of tables were set out a dozen or so chunky Pentium II PCs: dull metal towers the size of a (large) briefcase, and CRT monitors as deep as they were wide. At a time when only [13% of UK homes](https://www.statista.com/statistics/275999/household-internet-penetration-in-great-britain/) were connected to the internet, there was something magical to me about a roomful of machines wired up to the web. And the real joy of that room was that, unlike the rest of the building, it could be accessed 24 hours a day. I was already enamoured of the internet by the time I reached University in 1999, but that was where the relationship really developed. With a magnetic keycard and an entry code I could access the web any time I wanted. And so I did. Foregoing study, socialising, and sleep, I frequently left my room in Wells Hall in the late evening and ‚Äî with *Neon Ballroom* or *Hybrid Theory* on my headphones ‚Äî made the 10 minute walk to the Palmer Building Computer Room. Often the number pad on which you were expected to enter an access code refused to cooperate, and you had to rely on there being someone else inside who had also chosen to spend their night with the internet, and who would answer your pleading knock. 

It was in that room that I asked and was asked for my '[a/s/l](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/a/s/l)' on the brand new [MSN Messenger](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Windows_Live_Messenger). It was there that I ignored all dictums against installing software, and instead lobbied my fellow late night denizens to join me in multiplayer LAN sessions of *Doom II*. When [Yahoo! Groups](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Yahoo!_Groups) launched during my second year, I spent uncountable late night hours in that room arguing the merits of various punk bands with Americans in the middle of their days, and Europeans even deeper into their nights. 

It was to that room that I went on September 11th 2001, having received an SMS on my Nokia 3210 from an ex-girlfriend telling me to turn on the TV. My TV wasn't hooked up, but I knew a place I could get all the information I needed, and where I'd be able to join countless other people asking one another just what the heck was going on.

And it was also in that room that I began writing my first blog. Hosted  on Pyra Labs' Blogger (pre Google acquisition), mine was the simplest stream of posts on the music I was listening to, films I was watching, books I was reading, and games I was playing. 

If you wanted to hear why Deftones' *White Pony* was an instant classic; observe in real-time as *Mulholland Drive* melted my mind; read an argument about what made *Invisible Monsters* a worthy follow-up to *Fight Club*; or lament the premature death of the Dreamcast, I had you covered. In the years since, I've had blogs and personal sites hosted on various platforms (Wordpress, Squarespace, Svbtle), and in truth the subject matter has remained largely unchanged! Occasionally I've run social accounts alongside these sites, but the blog was always there as a home for my ~~more considered~~ lengthier thoughts.

### How It's Going

In the year 2021 I find myself several years deep into a state of confusion about what the social web has become. As the internet has grown increasingly omnipresent and ubiquitous, the amount of content generated has grown exponentially, but ‚Äî at least in the most heavily trafficked spaces ‚Äî the forms of expression have become homogenised. The vast majority of published material is made to fit into one of a vanishingly small number of moulds. Likewise, platform ubiquity has led to a weird blurring of previously guarded lines: social / professional; public / private etc. The nature(s) of connections between people, groups, corporations, and institutions has undergone a series of seismic shifts facilitated by these technologies. 

Nine years ago I published a post titled '[The Social Web Got Weird](/socialweird)'[^1]. Re-reading it now it's fascinating how things have further developed; not as I had expected, or predicted, that's for sure. About three years ago I published a [somewhat torturous post](/ontwitter) seeking to explain the idiosyncrasies of how I used Twitter. The short version is that I had found it necessary to contort myself into all manner of untenable postures just to feel OK about using the social web. That's not a hole I've managed to entirely dig my way out of, but my thinking continues to evolve. 

At present I have accounts all over the place‚Ä¶ but none of them are active. Or, I guess it might be more accurate to say that they are largely 'read-only'. Some of these tools have more than proven their utility; for example, the experience of following a baseball season without Twitter would now feel much diminished. In many other cases I feel drawn to at least be notionally present simply because of how interested I am in the internet as a phenomenon. The web is still capable of making me feel thrilled and captivated and engaged. For me, the internet's staggering power and potential remain undimmed since those days (and nights) in the Palmer Building Computer Room. The bottom line is that the web is still a place I want to be, and I have an inkling that the blog format still holds promise for me ~20 years after I first created one. 

[^1]: Side note: that post (not quite a decade old) contains links out to six different sources, every single one of which now returns a 404. Usually I try and fix these things when I spot them, but I quite like the irony of it in this instance ‚Äî¬†link rot is real!

[^2]: Since deleted out of industrial-strength embarrassment

items.title: The List 2020
items.content_html:
At the end of each year I make a list of the twenty albums I enjoyed the most. To be eligible, a record has to be of album length (at least ~30 mins), and contain entirely (or almost entirely) new material; live albums, cover records, and compilations are ineligible.

20. Joywave ‚Äî Possession

Three years ago Joywave announced themselves to me, and took second place on my 2017 list, with their sophomore album Content. At the time I said that I found the band ‚Äòvery exciting if they‚Äôre going to keep making music this inventive and urgent‚Äô and guess what? Possession is another assured, multi-faceted set of a dozen uncategorisable bops. Of the previous record I listed the genres touched upon as ‚Äòincluding, but not limited to: math rock, electronica, dance, soul‚Ä¶‚Äô and that‚Äôs still all in the mix here though, for some reason I can‚Äôt quite put my finger on the new album feels slightly more humane and less coldly electronic than its predecessor.

Opener ‚ÄòLike a Kennedy‚Äô is, for me, one of the defining songs of the Trump / Brexit era: a vulnerable, exhausted lament that asks only for the simplest things amidst incomprehensible turmoil. ‚ÄòF.E.A.R.‚Äô twists ‚ÄòMonster Mash‚Äô DNA into a campy downbeat stomp, whereas ‚ÄòFunny Thing About Opinions‚Äô is an upbeat treatise on the state of internet dialogue.

This is another record of surprising, inventive dance-pop-rock cuts that was everything I wanted from more Joywave. I would love to see these guys live when that‚Äôs possible once more, though‚Äîwith the same sense of humour apparent in their music‚Äîthe band‚Äôs faux-Fox News website informs me that their touring has been postponed ‚Äòdue to pressure from health experts and communists‚Äô.

19. Oliver Coates ‚Äî skins n slime

On my spider-diagram of musical influences there would be a large number of lines spreading outwards from Radiohead, and Oliver Coates is the newest addition. It seems like a fitting way to encounter a classically trained cellist making something he‚Äôs called (probably with tongue firmly in cheek) ‚Äòpastoral metal‚Äô.

It‚Äôs a tough task to affix meaningful labels to what Coates is doing on skins n slime, and that‚Äôs not a bad thing. Sure, I take his allusion to metal, but there‚Äôs also drone influences √† la Roly Porter, and minimalist composition √† la William Basinski & Steve Reich (with whom Coates has previously collaborated). The result is a singular m√©lange of a headphone record that I found mesmerising.

18. Empress Of ‚Äî I‚Äôm Your Empress Of

Despite this being her third record, Lorely Rodriguez‚Äîas Empress Of‚Äîis a new artist to me this year. She also, drum roll, made my favourite track of the year in the form of peerless, euphoric dance banger ‚ÄòLove is a Drug‚Äô. But that‚Äôs just one of the jewels on offer here. The album‚Äôs true opener (though it follows a sweet intro) ‚ÄòBit of Rain‚Äô is a house-infused treat, whereas ‚ÄòShold‚Äôve‚Äô is a more complex, layered affair.

Only three tracks break the three-minute barrier, and the album as a whole is only a little over a half hour, content to show up, put a smile on your face, and dip out leaving you wanting more. This was a trip I took dozens of times since the record‚Äôs release back in spring, and I‚Äôll be playing it for a while yet. I‚Äôll also be looking out both for remixes of what‚Äôs here, and for what Rodriguez does next.

17. Phoebe Bridgers ‚Äî Punisher

Someday, I’m gonna live
In your house up on the hill
And when your skinhead neighbor goes‚ÄÖmissing
I’ll‚ÄÖplant a garden‚ÄÖin the yard

Those are the first lines delivered on Punisher, and a fitting testament to the fact that no one told more compelling stories on record this year than Phoebe Bridgers. A stellar lyricist, she paints a series of vivid pictures for the listener, then uses them as the setting for raw emotional openness. It‚Äôs the same formula used by her partner in Better Oblivion Community Center: one Conor Oberst. But Bridgers is painting with softer brushes and ‚Äì for the most part ‚Äì a darker palette.

The title track is a heart-rending ballad of loneliness, ‚ÄòKyoto‚Äô is a more up-beat invitation to sing along (if you can match Bridgers‚Äô range), and album highlight ‚ÄòSavior Complex‚Äô is a brilliantly judged balancing act that manages to be both delicate and devastating.

For whatever reason Better Oblivion Community Center didn‚Äôt really work for me last year, but Punisher is persuasive proof that I need to go back to Bridgers‚Äô solo debut (Stranger in the Alps (2017)), and also her work with Lucy Dacus in boygenius.

Side note: Bridgers‚Äô non-album cover of Radiohead‚Äôs ‚ÄòFake Plastic Trees‚Äô (with Arlo Parks) is outstanding.

Second side note: despite its June release I was late in coming to this album for whatever reason, and I get the distinct feeling it‚Äôs not done growing on me. Ask me in 6-12 months and this may well have climbed up a fair few places.

16. Holy Fuck ‚Äî Deleter

HF took 7th place on this list in 2016 with their previous album: Congrats. I never did do the work of going back and exploring their catalogue ‚Äî which is something I still should do ‚Äî but when I saw a new LP drop at the beginning of 2020 I jumped on it. This is a record that has stuck around for me all year, and which doesn‚Äôt sound like anything else on this list.

HF are a band doing their own thing in their own way: bending all manner of instruments to make a supreme electronic racket with a pulse. However, the guests on Deleter‚Äôs opening couple of tracks make for an interesting way of triangulating the band‚Äôs place on the musical map. The understated build and break of ‚ÄòLuxe‚Äô features Alexis Taylor of Hot Chip, and the more forthright follow-up of a title track includes Angus Andrew of Liars. (I made an additional comparison to Battles last time, and that still stands.)

My favourite track on an inventive, restless record is ‚ÄòMoment‚Äô, with its build-and-build again dynamic and krautrock hard edge.

15. Surfer Blood ‚Äî Carefree Theatre

The last two Surfer Blood records (1000 Palms (2015) & Snowdonia (2017)) haven‚Äôt found a spot in my top 20, though I remember enjoying both of them. Happily, Carefree Theatre is very much a return to the heights of Pythons (18th in 2013), if not quite Astro Coast (6th in 2010).

The sunny Florida quartet still have a way with a simple melody, decorated with pretty harmonics, and a knack for undercutting it all with a weirdly twisted lyric or unexpected shift in the tune (eg. the way the guitar line finds an unexpected low note on ‚ÄòParkland (Into Silence)‚Äô). I‚Äôm aware that I may be being influenced by the fact they have a song referencing the director, but there‚Äôs a Lynchian twist at play here: a dive from the white picket vista to the squirming bugs in the soil. It‚Äôs the gambit Pixies perfected several decades ago, but it‚Äôs nice to hear a different take on it.

I haven‚Äôt done the work of going back to the third and fourth records, but I expect I would find that they were weakened relatively by virtue of Surfer Blood stretching to expand their sound. Simplicity is this band‚Äôs friend, and seems key to the bright three-minute pieces they‚Äôre capable of crafting. On this record they‚Äôre embracing it with great results, even if album closer ‚ÄòRose Bowl‚Äô makes for disconcerting listening at the end of 2020:

On the first day of the New Year
Morning, January first
This past year wasn‚Äôt great
And I think it‚Äôs getting worse

14. Biffy Clyro ‚Äî A Celebration of Endings

Previously on this list: 9th in 2007 with Puzzle; 3rd in 2013 with Opposites and, of course, 1st in 2009 with Only Revolutions. Notable for its absence in that list is 2016‚Äôs Ellipsis, which I found to be uneven at best and did not get played much after the first couple of listens. For that reason I approached A Celebration of Endings with both hope and caution. I was very pleased to find that it was the former that was warranted.

‚ÄòNorth is No South‚Äô is a statement of intent, and then it gives way to a run of four tracks (‚ÄòThe Champ‚Äô ‚Äì ‚ÄòWorst Type of Best Possible‚Äô) as strong as anything the Scots have ever committed to tape. ‚ÄòSpace‚Äô is the kind of ballad that probably has Matt Cardle dreaming of another Christmas number 1, and then ‚ÄòEnd Of‚Äô hits you over the head with a blackjack. As was the case with the previous three Biffy albums to make this list there‚Äôs not a bad track here. There are weaker moments (‚ÄòThe Pink Limit‚Äô doesn‚Äôt totally work for me), but they‚Äôre hugely outnumbered by consistently arresting songwriting and the band‚Äôs knack for finding strange new ways to twist a riff or subvert a time signature.

That‚Äôs true from the the bruiser of an opening track, right until ‚ÄòCop Syrup‚Äô plays the record out like a weird update of Nirvana‚Äôs ‚ÄòBeeswax‚Äô (1992).

13. The Beths ‚Äî Jump Rope Gazers

There were so many good records two years ago that I ended up appending a ‚Äònext best 30‚Äô list to the main top 20 ‚Äì¬†that‚Äôs how I know that The Beths‚Äô fuzzed-up guitars and playful percussion only just missed a spot on the 2018 list for their debut Future Me Hates Me. The follow-up is a stronger record on which the New Zealand quartet have honed their formidable sense of melody to a fine point.

I‚Äôm hearing some that dog. in here, only Elizabeth Stokes‚Äôs voice is warmer and lighter than Anna Waronker‚Äôs delivery often was. Moments like the vocal somersaults on opener ‚ÄòI‚Äôm Not Getting Excited‚Äô still thrill me on each listen.

There‚Äôs a little dip in quality at the middle of the running order, but it picks right back up with the cheerily plaintive ‚ÄòDon‚Äôt Go Away‚Äô, before heading into album highlight ‚ÄòMars, The God of War‚Äô: a sub-three-minute pop rock gem and the best song I know to include the word ‚Äòoptometry‚Äô.

12. Deftones ‚Äî Ohms

As I type this there is a newly released version of Deftones‚Äô best record sat, as yet unheard, on my hard drive. White Pony / Black Stallion is a remaster and a set of remixes in celebration of the 20th anniversary of an album that I would still pack for a desert island.

Deftones are one of the very few bands for whom every one of their records has made my list over the years, so let‚Äôs review placements:

White Pony 3rd in 2000 ‚ò®
Deftones 12th in 2003;
Saturday Night Wrist 9th in 2006;
Diamond Eyes 9th in 2010;
Koi No Yokan 1st in 2012;
Gore 20th in 2016

When I looked back on the preceding decade in 2005 I also retroactively had their debut Adrenaline 1st for 1995, and the follow-up Around the Fur 3rd for 1997.

But what of the new offering? After flirtations with Bob Ezrin, Nick Raskulinecz, & Matt Hyde on their last four albums, Deftones reunite here with Terry Date: the producer on their first four albums. The result is a record that sounds every bit as brutal and sonically deep as their masterpiece. There‚Äôs proof on every track of Ohms that this is a band still able to wrangle cacophony like no one else, threading it through with both taut wires of urgent passion and flowing ribbons of melody.

‚ÄòUrantia‚Äô is a Pantera riff being absorbed into a great lost Soundgarden song; ‚ÄòRadiant City‚Äô is restless water chopped up by a sea monster moving slowly in the deep. And, title track and closer ‚ÄòOhms‚Äô, is the best song they‚Äôve written in two decades.

‚ò® I‚Äôm relatively confident that if I reviewed this year now White Pony would take 2nd from Eminem‚Äôs The Marshall Mathers LP and would be snapping at the heels of Radiohead‚Äôs Kid A for the top spot.

11. Fiona Apple ‚Äî Fetch the Bolt Cutters

I don‚Äôt know where to begin with this record. After having listened to it dozens of times I still feel like I‚Äôm barely finding my way into it. And yet it‚Äôs mesmerising and breathtaking in new ways each time I give it the attention it deserves ‚Äì¬†which is to say, when I can lie down with headphones on and do nothing else.

Apple‚Äôs previous album (The Idler Wheel‚Ä¶) ended up 17th on my list in 2012, but only four other records on that list have lasted for me over the eight years since. I‚Äôm old friends with that album now, I know the raucous ‚ÄòEvery Single Night‚Äô and the dizzying ‚ÄòHot Knife‚Äô like old friends. But I still recall when I first encountered the album, and how it took time before confusion gave way to awe. Fiona Apple doesn‚Äôt make easily digestible, parseable music. But just as years spent loving Extraordinary Machine (2005) were inadequate preparation for Idler Wheel‚Ä¶, eight years spent in the company of that album wasn‚Äôt enough to get my brain ready for Fetch the Bolt Cutters.

That‚Äôs two paragraphs of preamble to mask the fact that I still don‚Äôt really know how to talk about this record, except to say that by the time Apple starts making dolphin noises in the last 20 seconds of opener ‚ÄòI Want You To Love Me‚Äô, you‚Äôre likely either in or out. I, evidently, was in all the way: through the anthem to self belief ‚ÄòShameika‚Äô, the self confidence mantra ‚ÄòUnder the Table‚Äô, or the howl in the face of depression ‚ÄòHeavy Balloon‚Äô.

There is a book to be written about the instrumentation on Fetch the Bolt Cutters, the way it‚Äôs layered, the way Apple‚Äôs voice (often in duplicate or triplicate) weaves in and out of it, the way it seems to fly in the face of conventional time signatures to create music that keeps you guessing even on the fifteenth listen. I‚Äôm not music scholar enough to attempt anything close to the analysis this record deserves. This is the best way I can find to phrase it: nothing sounds like a Fiona Apple record, and no other Fiona Apple record sounds quite like this.

10. Four Tet ‚Äî Sixteen Oceans

It will be no surprise to find Kieran Hebden occupying a place on this list: previous appearances include There is Love in You (17th in 2010); Pink (10th in 2012); & New Energy (7th in 2017), and I have a feeling that if I were to rewrite the 2013 list now Beautiful Rewind would make an appearance ‚Äì¬†it‚Äôs certainly had more staying power for me than a number of records on that list. Heck, I still play 2003‚Äôs Rounds and 2005‚Äôs Everything Ecstatic at least a couple of times each year.

Sixteen Oceans displays the same delicate balances with which Four Tet has been playing for more than two decades: electronic / acoustic; played / sampled; digital / human. These levels shift pleasingly and subtly throughout the runtime of the record, in a manner which made it for me very much an album as opposed to a collection of disparate tracks. As I replayed it, even the four shorter interstitial pieces came to feel like necessary, brilliantly judged transitional moments.

Highlights for me are the singular pulse of ‚ÄòTeenage Birdsong‚Äô, and the glowing swell of (the otherwise admittedly slight) ‚Äò4T Recordings‚Äô. Arguably there‚Äôs less innovation on Sixteen Oceans than there has been on previous Four Tet albums, but I don‚Äôt necessarily miss it. I still find Hebden‚Äôs work captivating, moving, and worthy of frequent revisiting.

9. Caribou ‚Äî Suddenly

Caribou previously appeared on one of these lists when he took 11th place in 2014 with Our Love. That was a record that tapped into hazy house music vibes to great effect, and there are still notes of that in evidence on this year‚Äôs release. Overall, however, Suddenly is more wide-ranging. It borrows from all over the dance / electronica spectrum, and unifies the results by threading the patchwork through with Dan Snaith‚Äôs falsetto.

Album highlight ‚ÄòHome‚Äô is as soulful and warm as opener ‚ÄòSister‚Äô is cool and stand-offish: both are sub-three minute musical jewels. Each track here has been painstakingly constructed from a broad array of influences, such that each sounds different from one another and yet uniquely like Caribou. It‚Äôs a similar art to that practiced by (former tour mates) Radiohead: somehow you know a piece of music is theirs even when it sounds unlike anything they‚Äôve made before. Amongst my favourite tracks on the record, ‚ÄòNever Come Back‚Äô & ‚ÄòRavi‚Äô are imbued with the kind of warmth that just glows through your headphones.

8. HAIM ‚Äî Women in Music Pt. III

HAIM‚Äôs last album ‚Äî Something To Tell You ‚Äî didn‚Äôt find a spot on my 2017 list. Despite a handful of very good tracks, and no outright bad ones, it never seemed to reach anything like the heights of the debut: Days Are Gone, which was awarded 6th place back in 2013. Even on first listen it was clear to me that on Women in Music Pt. III HAIM had recaptured the magic of their debut.

The formula should be familiar now: three gifted musicians who also hold the unfair advantage of being sisters, which seems to explain why their voices harmonise so perfectly. Using those tools, and a great ear for melodic hooks, they produce a more thoroughly Californian update of Fleetwood Mac‚Äôs blues-infused pop-rock.

And on their third LP they‚Äôre making some of their best music. ‚ÄòThe Steps‚Äô is forthright and foot-stomping; its younger sister ‚Äì album closer ‚ÄòFUBT‚Äô ‚Äì is a more vulnerable lament. And HAIM are happy and able to play anywhere along that spectrum. Album highlight ‚ÄòDon‚Äôt Wanna‚Äô is both achingly sweet and vulnerable whilst its percussion and soaring chorus project a core of strength.

There are also a couple of surprises that work surprisingly well: chief amongst them ‚Äò3am‚Äô, which sounds like it fell off a Jennifer Lopez record a couple of decades ago, and which I couldn‚Äôt get enough of.

7. Georgia ‚Äî Seeking Thrills

Only two of the dozen nominees for this year‚Äôs Mercury Music Prize also has the (no less prestigious) honour of being awarded a place in my top 20.

Seeking Thrills is one of the year‚Äôs most optimistic records; it‚Äôs awash with infectious positivity. There are certainly downtempo moments, such as the coy, understated self-belief mantra ‚ÄòTill I Own It‚Äô, but there are several tracks obviously destined to soundtrack late night and early hours on dancefloors. The chorus of ‚ÄòNever Let You Go‚Äô is a burst of beautiful euphoria set in a polyrhythmic bed that‚Äôs urging you to dance at two different tempos at once; ‚ÄòFeel It‚Äô has the DNA of an MIA track, but with a dance twist; ‚Äô24 Hours‚Äô evolves masterfully into an effervescent gem.

The first half of the album is stronger than the latter half, but there are no weak tracks. Since its release in the second week of the year this has been an easy-listening pleasure that I‚Äôve yet to tire of replaying.

6. Taylor Swift ‚Äî evermore

This has been the year of disrupted plans and unforeseen twists. Thus it‚Äôs fitting that I had this whole list written before Taylor Swift decided to celebrate her birthday by surprise releasing an album, with ~16 hours' notice, on 11 December. Hence, two weeks‚Äô later, here I am on Boxing Day re-writing things to give this record its rightful place.

As with her other quarantine album (July‚Äôs folklore) this is Swift in a storytelling mode, delicately and precisely teasing out the emotional truths of any situation she turns her attention to: failed proposals on ‚Äòchampagne problems‚Äô, imbalances of affection within relationships on ‚Äòtolerate it‚Äô . She‚Äôs telling the story of her own grandmother on ‚Äòmarjorie‚Äô, and spinning a tale of murder and revenge on the HAIM-featuring ‚ÄòNo Body, No Crime‚Äô ‚Äì both the most fun Swift had on record this year, and her catchiest song of 2020.

Sonically though, there‚Äôs more of a sense of exploration here than on Swift‚Äôs other 2020 release. The template of simply arranged, delicately composed folk pop that was set on folklore is pulled here into slightly different shapes. There‚Äôs a drum machine on ‚Äòone story short‚Äô, and skittering beats and whooshes underneath the outro of ‚Äòhappiness‚Äô, and again throughout ‚Äòclosure‚Äô. There‚Äôs one of the clearest nods to her country music roots since Speak Now (2010) on ‚Äòcowboy like me‚Äô.

You can probably tell from how this entry is written that, with five entries left to go, we‚Äôre not done with Taylor Swift in 2020. I‚Äôll have more to say then.

(Also: shout out to the Detroit post-hardcore quartet Dogleg who held the 20th spot on this list before Taylor dropped a last minute bombshell, necessitating a re-write; their debut Melee is officially my twenty-first favourite LP of 2020.)

5. Hayley Williams ‚Äî Petals for Armor

The last three Paramore records have been at four year intervals (not that I‚Äôm counting down), and they‚Äôve reliably taken their place in the middle of my lists: 8th in 2009 for Brand New Eyes, 12th in 2013 for Paramore, and 10th in 2017 with After Laughter. As such it‚Äôs a welcome surprise to find frontwoman Hayley Williams so far up this list when she‚Äôs out on her own.

Musically this solo work is less vibrantly bombastic than Paramore‚Äôs more recent output, but no less catchy or endearing. Despite deeply personal subject matter (including depression, divorce, and recovery) Williams has crafted a collection of electronic-tinged pop-rock that it‚Äôs impossible not to fall for. Over the course of 15 tracks she explores some more experimental percussion and production (such as on the stuttering-then-flowing, Fiona Apple-esque ‚ÄòCinnamon‚Äô) as well as showcasing her ear for a hook, such as on the powerful earworm ‚ÄòDead Horse‚Äô and the Sunday-afternoon radio ballad ‚ÄòPure Love‚Äô. The result is an hour of consistently arresting, energising music that draws from an impressively wide emotional range.

Few would deny that the defining characteristic of Paramore as a band is Hayley Williams‚Äôs unmistakable voice. Whisper to roar, and across a truly impressive tonal range, few rock singers can match her. Unsurprisingly that is also the strength of her first solo outing, though her consistently evolving songwriting is a close second.

4. Beach Bunny ‚Äî Honeymoon

This record is nine tracks and 25 minutes of relentless, sunny pop-rock. It‚Äôs proof if proof was needed that throwing four kids into a rehearsal room with a couple of guitars and a drum set can still result in something life-affirming and marvellous.

Opener ‚ÄòPromises‚Äô is first light and bubbly, and then strident and anthemic; it‚Äôs followed up with the sing-along whilst you dance-along ‚ÄòCuffing Season‚Äô, then we drop a couple of gears for the raw, earnest ‚ÄòApril‚Äô. And we‚Äôre off to the races on a giddy whirlwind tour of three-chords-and-hummable-choruses pop. By the time you reach cartwheeling closer, and album high point, ‚ÄòCloud 9‚Äô you‚Äôre ready to do it all again. Go on, treat yourself. You can find 25 minutes.

I‚Äôm a simple man, and Weezer‚Äôs self-titled debut is my seventh-favourite record of all time. I needed something this bright and uncomplicated this year, and my thanks go out to this Chicago quartet for delivering it so effectively.

3. Taylor Swift ‚Äî folklore

Last year‚Äôs number one released this record with 24 hours‚Äô notice back in July, and it has been a staple on my headphones ever since. A very different-sounding record to 2019‚Äôs Lover, working (for the most part) in a more subdued register, folklore is another showcase for a phenomenal songwriting talent. There are no anthemic, danceable pop explosions here, but the more muted tone and stripped back instrumentation allow for Swift‚Äôs vocals to shine, and for her lyricism to take centre stage.

Whether it‚Äôs (on ‚ÄòThe Last Great American Dynasty‚Äô) telling the story of Rebekah Harkness, who used to live in the home Swift now owns, or laying out the dynamics of a love triangle over the course of three songs (‚ÄòCardigan‚Äô, ‚ÄòAugust‚Äô, & ‚ÄòBetty‚Äô), Swift displays a songwriting touch as light and dextrous as the voice with which she brings those songs to life. Album highlight for me (at least at present) is Swift‚Äôs duet with Bon Iver‚Äôs Justin Vernon on ‚ÄòExile‚Äô - a lyrically exquisite heartbreaker wherein the two voices play with and against one another perfectly.

Following the surprise release of the album, Swift also put out a combination making-of documentary / live performance on Disney+ which offered insight on how the record came to be, and how her collaboration with The National‚Äôs Aaron Dessner came to bear this fruit. It also serves as an interesting document of how an artist usually wrapped in layers of hype and marketing, found freedom in isolation to make something intimate. The record is a fascinating balance: it represents the furthest Swift has gone into telling others‚Äô stories (fictional and otherwise), yet each song is imbued with deeply personal feeling.

Swift‚Äôs work in 2020 has been, frankly, stunning - as evidenced by her having performed the unprecedented feat of securing two spots in the top six places of this list. Having stepped outside of both the aesthetic trappings and sonic bombast usually expected of pop‚Äôs reigning queen, she has made a strong case for being recognised as a generational songwriting talent.

2. Halsey ‚Äî Manic

When you open your third record on a song titled with your given name (‚ÄòAshley‚Äô) you‚Äôre making a statement: I‚Äôm here to share something; this is coming from the heart. When you close that track with a snippet of audio from Eternal Sunshine of the Spotless Mind, you‚Äôre signalling an emotional register of earnest vulnerability. Carrying off that conversation over the course of 16 pop songs is a tall order, and yet Manic is an unbridled success.

Someone smarter than me could probably take the musical DNA of ‚ÄòForever ‚Ä¶ (is a long time)‚Äô / ‚ÄòDominic‚Äôs Interlude‚Äô / ‚ÄòI HATE EVERYBODY‚Äô, examine it under an electron microscope, and figure out why it makes me feel the same way as sections of My Chemical Romance‚Äôs The Black Parade (2006). I‚Äôm not equipped to work out the reasons, I can just tell you that it happens. The first track uses piano to effect a shift from major to minor key; the second is an organ-backed, multi-tracked, 76 second opera; the third is a series of crescendos hitting like waves on a beach. It‚Äôs a masterful seven minutes at the centre of a bewilderingly good record.

Oh, and then the second half of the record kicks off with the barnstorming pop-rock ‚Äò3am‚Äô, and then the dimly lit, sultry ‚ÄòWithout Me‚Äô, then the lost KT Tunstall track I didn‚Äôt know I wanted: ‚ÄòFinally // beautiful stranger‚Äô. By the time Halsey is singing an LGBT empowerment duet with Alanis Morissette you feel it‚Äôs company they should feel comfortable keeping.

Folk, pop, indie rock, R&B, Korean rap - this record includes a lot, and some reviews read that as coming at the expense of depth. For me it all works seamlessly almost without exception, making Manic read like a personal, and deeply felt record, that also happens to be a pop gem.

1. Dua Lipa ‚Äî Future Nostalgia

Here‚Äôs the other Mercury nominee, and (I have just learned) Spotify‚Äôs most played female artist of 2020. So firmly is the 2020 pop crown sat atop Dua‚Äôs head that one of her best tracks of the year isn‚Äôt even on this record, it‚Äôs over on Miley Cyrus‚Äôs Plastic Hearts - the high point of an album that very nearly made this list.

Whilst Taylor Swift was writing folk ballads in a woodland cabin it seems Dua was channeling the attentions of the pop gods to teach a neon-soaked masterclass in funk and disco-infused bangers. This is music designed in a lab to destroy radios, dance floors, and TikTok alike. All of which would be for nothing if it wasn‚Äôt, from start to finish, an unmitigated success. You cannot fail to smile, you absolutely will nod along, sing along, and feel some of these beats in your bones.

The Pitchfork review of Future Nostalgia has a good line in which they say that the album ‚Äòsounds like three Madonna eras at once‚Äô. As someone who has a huge amount of affection for pretty much all of Madonna‚Äôs eras (not you American Life, you can sit down) this is a recipe for success in my mind. Providing, that is, that you can walk in Madonna‚Äôs shadow ‚Äì not an easy thing to do. Dua comes armed with the disco beats of peak Kylie, and a faultless ear for both a groove and a beat. The result is a remarkable pop record that samples White Town on ‚ÄòLove Again‚Äô, and channels John Deacon on ‚ÄòBreak My Heart‚Äô, but also sounds entirely cohesive and possessed of limitless self-confidence.

The title track, ‚ÄòDon‚Äôt Start Now‚Äô, ‚ÄòPhysical‚Äô, ‚ÄòHallucinate‚Äô, and ‚ÄòBreak My Heart‚Äô could each be career-defining encores for a lot of artists. As it stands, I get the feeling that this is just the beginning of what Dua Lipa is capable of.

This is the second year that my list has been topped by a thoroughbred pop record, and there are more albums elsewhere on the list this year than ever before which fall in that category. What I find particularly interesting is that the great bulk of my music-listening year is taken up with records from all over the genre map. At the time of writing I‚Äôve listened to 213 records released in 2020 at least once through. From ambient and drone to jazz and metal I found records this year that I really enjoyed. But when the chips are down and I have to pick the records that genuinely gave me the most pleasure, increasingly it‚Äôs pop music that I turn to. Perhaps two years in a row is a coincidence, but even if the 2021 list doesn‚Äôt end up having a pop album on top I‚Äôll be shocked if there isn‚Äôt a handful of them in the mix.
