items.title: Apple Data
items.content_html:
It‚Äôs a near certainty that over the last few weeks you‚Äôve received several emails asking you to consent to companies‚Äô amended privacy policies. The short version of the story is that this shift in how companies handle your data has been inspired by the advent of a new piece of EU legislation: the General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR). It‚Äôs not a panacea ‚Äì and goodness knows the raft of emails it inspired was irritating ‚Äì but it‚Äôs a step forward in data privacy, and notably it establishes a European position even further advanced beyond the US one than was previously the case.

Several of the bigger operators in online services (ie. those companies whose main business is the providing of online services, as opposed to companies who do other things but have a web presence) have offered a data export service for some time. Google Takeout was the first I had any cause to interact with, and I found it an admirably simple and transparent process. As part of the fallout from the Cambridge Analytica scandal, more people seemed to be made aware of Facebook‚Äôs data export service. Requesting one‚Äôs data from these companies, and receiving it in a giant ZIP file, can be quite overwhelming ‚Äì particularly if you‚Äôve been a heavy user of their products for some time. But it‚Äôs also fascinating. The cache of information you might readily associate with your interactions with the company makes up a small portion of the total: a visible peak of the proverbial data iceberg. The rest of the folder is full of stuff you had either known at some point that they were collecting, but had forgotten, or that you had no idea was being collected in the first place. I recommend doing it if only for the weird feeling of being presented with a box of facts about yourself that someone else has taken note of.

Whether directly inspired by GDPR or not, Apple recently started offering a data export service. So, out of nothing more than sheer curiosity, I requested everything they have on me. Excavating the folder that came back has been super-interesting. Here are a few select pieces of what‚Äôs included.

‚Ä¢ Every Apple device ever associated with my account, and every firmware version that has ever been installed on each.

‚Ä¢ Every email address, physical address, and payment option ever associated with my account.

‚Ä¢ Every device from which I have ever logged into my account. This included items like ‚ÄòRIVERSIDE22‚Äô: my work PC at a job I had in 2009, and listings such as ‚ÄòMendicant Bias‚Äô and ‚ÄòPenitent Tangent‚Äô from when I used to name my machines using embarrassingly nerdy references (2011).

‚Ä¢ Predictably, every purchase I have ever made from iTunes, starting with my first: ‚ÄòKiss Me‚Äô by Sixpence None the Richer on 5 Aug 2005.

‚Ä¢ Also, every free item I‚Äôve downloaded from an Apple digital store.

‚Ä¢ Every song and album I‚Äôve played on Ô£øMUSIC; how many times I‚Äôve listened to it; when I first played it, and when I last played it.

‚Ä¢ A complete catalogue of every song or album I have expressed a binary opinion about on Ô£øMUSIC.

‚Ä¢ Hilariously, a subfolder containing a separate document that simply lists the tracks from the U2 album Songs of Innocence, which Apple infamously forced upon everybody with an internet connected iOS device in 2014, and which the majority of us deleted instantly.

‚Ä¢ Every item for which I have engaged in the dubious practice of pre-ordering a digital good.

‚Ä¢ Every item I‚Äôve ever watched on my Ô£øTV, including a timestamp of where I left off. (A playcount is also included, revealing my worrying Mr Robot viewing habits.)

‚Ä¢ A colossal spreadsheet listing every episode of every podcast I have ever listened to, the date I listened to it, a timestamp of where I left off, and whether or not I am subscribed to the podcast in question.

‚Ä¢ A list of all my iBooks purchases, alongside separate documents that mark the position I‚Äôve reached in each book, any highlighting I‚Äôve done, and any annotations that I‚Äôve added.

‚Ä¢ Every review I‚Äôve left for an item in an Apple digital store, including the rating out of 5 and any comments I made.

‚Ä¢ Every time I‚Äôve complained about another customer‚Äôs review of a product in an Apple digital store!

‚Ä¢ Every app I‚Äôve beta tested via Apple‚Äôs Testflight.

‚Ä¢ Every store item I‚Äôve ever gifted, and every gift card I‚Äôve ever redeemed (including date of redemption and value).

‚Ä¢ PDF copies of all of the email receipts sent to me following in-person purchases at an Apple retail store. These go back to the time I bought a blue ‚Äòbumper‚Äô for my iPhone 4 in June 2013.

‚Ä¢ Every product for which I‚Äôve taken out AppleCare+.

‚Ä¢ Every interaction I‚Äôve had with AppleCare support.

‚Ä¢ The transcript of every chat I‚Äôve had with AppleCare support. Interestingly these also include the text of chats between Apple employees relating to the support ticket.

‚Ä¢ All of my responses to surveys regarding my customer service experiences.

‚Ä¢ All of my earned achievements and leaderboard positions for GameCenter enabled iOS games.

‚Ä¢ Safari browsing history and bookmarks are empty folders in my case (because I routinely purge them), but they‚Äôre in there.

‚Ä¢ Details of recent FaceTime calls and message recipients are also blank in my case because I have a habit of erasing the histories every week. But, it would all otherwise be there.

‚Ä¢ Map locations I‚Äôve marked as favourites.

‚Ä¢ Copies of all iCloud calendars and Reminder lists (both as .ics files).

‚Ä¢ Copies of all my iCloud contacts as vCards.

‚Ä¢ Plaintext copies of all items kept in iCloud folders in Notes, with rich media attachments in separate folders. Also, a list of any shared notes, with whom they are shared, and the applicable permission structure.

‚Ä¢ Every correction I‚Äôve submitted to the Apple Maps team, including screenshots.

‚Ä¢ An .xml file of every wifi network I‚Äôve connected to and chosen to remember the login credentials for.

‚Ä¢ Finally, in a folder named ‚ÄòOther Data‚Äô, an absolutely colossal spreadsheet listing every action involving my iCloud storage. It‚Äôs a chronological list of every photo / video I‚Äôve uploaded to iCloud, and every time it‚Äôs been downloaded on another device; every time I‚Äôve deleted a file from iCloud storage; every time I‚Äôve recovered a recently deleted file; every time I‚Äôve uploaded, downloaded, and deleted a photo from my Photo Stream; every interaction I‚Äôve had with photos / videos in a shared album; every document added to iCloud Drive, and every time I‚Äôve modified one or deleted one; every time I‚Äôve applied a tag to a file in iCloud Drive; every time I‚Äôve enabled or disabled an app to work with iCloud Drive‚Ä¶ basically any time anything I‚Äôve done has touched my iCloud storage. Interestingly it‚Äôs named ‚ÄòiCloudUsageData Set1.csv‚Äô and contains entries only for the last couple of months (it‚Äôs still thousands and thousands of rows).

Awe is not something one expects to feel when looking at a series of spreadsheets, but I‚Äôm in awe of the engineering it must take to build a system like this. Notably absent from this trove of data is the more personal stuff. I‚Äôm an Ô£øWatch user, and none of the data around my heart rate, exercise habits etc. is here. I also use the Health app and Medical ID on iPhone, and so those apps have information on my weight, blood type, medical history etc. That data is also not included here. Apple has made clear from the launch of those products that user privacy is paramount, and (outside of your devices) that data is only contained in backups the user creates locally and chooses to have encrypted. Similarly the text of iMessage chats is not part of the data that Apple keeps; those are encrypted end-to-end and unreadable by anyone but the sender and recipient, including Apple.

It‚Äôs also worth thinking for a moment about why Apple keeps the data that it does. In the vast majority of cases it is kept in order to improve the user‚Äôs experience. If I download a film or a podcast episode to a new device and it picks up where I last stopped playing it, I don‚Äôt think about the giant spreadsheet that made that possible ‚Äì I‚Äôm just delighted that it works that way. All of the ratings I‚Äôve given items on Ô£øMUSIC are used to generate custom playlists more to my liking. And, don‚Äôt forget the small miracle of logging into a brand new device with one‚Äôs AppleID and having all of one‚Äôs data available effortlessly: contacts, calendars, notes, music, photos etc. etc. etc. Depending on your age you might recall the stressful, laborious processes involved in transferring all of this stuff before the ubiquity of the cloud.

In short, there‚Äôs nothing here that I disagree with Apple retaining. And a large part of that is because I know it is not part of Apple‚Äôs business model to leverage this data for their own gain. The data that Facebook and Google retain on you is certainly used to improve your experience with their products, but it is also used to enable their business models, which are reliant almost exclusively on advertising. Despite its growing array of products (digital and physical) 86% of Google‚Äôs revenue still comes from advertisers. In Facebook‚Äôs case the figure is 98%.

Perhaps the most striking omission is the fact that there is no record of purchases I‚Äôve made using Ô£øPay. Such data points would likely be too potentially rich a seam of information for an advertiser-dependent company to resist collecting, speaking directly as it would to my purchasing habits, preferred brands, and so on.

items.title: The List 2017
items.content_html:
At the end of each year I make a list of the twenty albums I enjoyed the most. To be eligible, a record has to be of album length (at least ~30 mins), and contain entirely (or almost entirely) new material; live albums, cover records, and compilations are ineligible.

20. Run The Jewels ‚Äî Run the Jewels 3

As I write this Kendrick Lamar‚Äôs Damn is topping year-end lists left and right and I‚Äôm wondering what I missed on an album I just didn‚Äôt connect with. Of the hip-hop that passed through my headphones this year I had a good time with Vince Staples‚Äôs Big Fish Theory, really liked Open Mike Eagle‚Äôs Brick Body Kids Still Daydream (but spent too little time with it), and bounced off most of the big hitters to one degree or another: as well as Damn, Jay-Z‚Äôs lukewarm 4:44 and Drake‚Äôs More Life did little for me, and I‚Äôve never clicked with the Migos thing.

That leaves room for only one rap record on this year‚Äôs list, but it‚Äôs a doozy. RTJ remain a complete enigma to me: I don‚Äôt know how they came together, I don‚Äôt know why they give every record away instead of selling them, and I don‚Äôt know why their combo of braggadocio, political engagement, and downright silliness works (this is a mix that only seems to work in hip-hop, with Beastie Boys as perhaps the flag-bearers) ‚Äì I‚Äôm just grateful for it all.

Highlight: ‚ÄòLegend Has It‚Äô is one of my most quoted songs of the year (for better or worse). It‚Äôs just the right mix of all the magic elements that make RTJ special. The moment when El P‚Äôs girlfriend interrupts to stop him completing one particularly crude line makes me smile, if not laugh, every time.

19. Portico Quartet ‚Äî Art in the Age of Automation

There were three records this year that I returned to time and again for a dose of calm, reflective ambience: one didn‚Äôt quite make the list (Andrew Bird‚Äôs Echolocations: River), one is further up this list, and the latest from Portico Quartet is the third. Once again a four-piece following the departure of founding member Nick Mulvey and one record as a trio (renamed, simply Portico), AitAoA finds the band taking another progressive step with their sound. When they took 8th spot on my list in 2012 (with their eponymous LP), I ended my write-up by saying I was excited to see what was next. Actually, 2015‚Äôs Living Fields didn‚Äôt quite chime for me ‚Äì essentially an electronica album, with some guest vocals I could live without, it felt like a band deliberately trying to make a clean break with the past, and ignoring their strengths to do so. This year‚Äôs record (following the addition to the roster of Kier Vine) feels like a very deliberate further sonic evolution, which brings back the more organic instrumentation and cuts the vocals. It‚Äôs precisely what I wanted from the follow up to Portico Quartet, and perhaps their strongest album to date.

Highlight: ‚ÄòCurrent History‚Äô takes as its base an effervescent, Amnesiac-style percussion pattern and layers tones and loops on top.

18. Death From Above ‚Äî Outrage! Is Now

Here‚Äôs something I wrote when DFA‚Äôs The Physical World took top spot in my list for 2014:

It‚Äôs been a long decade since that incredible debut, and the mere existence of this second record is something like a miracle; that it lives up to the standard of the first record is a second-order miracle; and that it also finds ways to evolve the band‚Äôs unmistakable sound without sacrificing its authenticity or its power is a kind of compound triptych miracle.

Who knows what kind of albums this band could have made in the decade-long interval between their studio debut and its follow-up? Perhaps it took that time, and the up & down intra-bandmate relationship, to make that second record. Whatever the case, I‚Äôm glad we didn‚Äôt have to wait so long for a third LP.

Sebastien Grainger is a great drummer and Jesse F. Keeler is a great bassist; both have a great ear for infectious hooks, and they share a willingness to push their compositions as far as they‚Äôll go: harder, faster, heavier, groovier. Perhaps the least talked about weapon in the band‚Äôs arsenal is Grainger‚Äôs voice; it‚Äôs a passionate, vaulting, wonderfully tuneful thing that serves as a solid third pillar in their song-craft.

Outrage! Is Now sounds like DFA. It sounds like someone lent them a couple of synths, but it‚Äôs unmistakably the same racket they made on the previous records. And man does it still get me!?

Highlight: ‚ÄòNvr 4Evr‚Äô is classic DFA; the kind of track that bands like Black Rebel Motorcycle Club wish they‚Äôd written.

17. Beck ‚Äî Colors

Do you remember that part in Superman Returns where Lex Luther explains to Kitty Kowalski that crystals take on the properties of the elements that surround them? I feel that Beck operates in a similar fashion: whatever given sound or vibe he turns his attention to, he‚Äôs able to produce music that feels authentic. Sometimes it‚Äôs meditative (eg. Sea Change (2002)), sometimes a little sombre (eg. Morning Phase (2014)), and sometimes poppy and easygoing (eg. Odelay (1996) & Guero (2005)). And no matter which category he‚Äôs playing in, Beck‚Äôs consistently doing something interesting with it. Whether it‚Äôs Brazilian influences on Guero, or the hip-hop touches to The Information (2006), Beck is a restlessly inventive artist in the same mould as Madonna or Bj√∂rk (perhaps it‚Äôs something to do with the mononyms?). Colors is Beck in full-on pop assault mode. And he‚Äôs happy to pull from anywhere and everywhere to make it happen. Shamelessly detuned guitars and anthemic choruses; jaunty Beatles-esque piano; ‚ÄôNo Distraction‚Äô sounds like Sting collaborating with The Killers. In sum it‚Äôs the same trick that Daniel Johns et al managed to pull off with Young Modern (2007): the making of a pop album on one‚Äôs own artistic terms. It‚Äôs not quite as strange (or as sublime) as that Silverchair record, but both are unmistakably the work of diversely-talented musicians making a direct assault on whatever part of the brain responds to catchy pop music.

Highlight: The panpipe melody that runs through title track ‚ÄòColors‚Äô ‚Äì anything that can make me love the sound of an instrument I previously hated has to be doing something right.

16. The xx ‚Äî I See You

To my ears the third album from The xx sounds like a natural progression of a sound that started off very simple and somewhat reserved, and has blossomed into a form somewhat brighter, self-assured, and colourful. It‚Äôs only natural, in fact, that the band‚Äôs third album as a trio takes notes from In Colour, Jamie xx‚Äôs vibrant, dance-floor friendly solo album of 2015 (#8 on that year‚Äôs List). The blaring horns that start the record were called out by several reviewers as a shock departure for The xx‚Äôs sound; but the shock was far less if you‚Äôd allowed Jamie‚Äôs solo LP to work its magic on you a couple of years previously.

All of which is not to say that I See You sounds entirely different from its predecessors. The heart of the record is still the haunted, sleek blend of trip-hop and the lighter side of the EDM spectrum. And the songwriting is still coming from somewhere intensely personal. It‚Äôs not necessary to know about the friction between bandmates that sits behind tracks like ‚ÄòSay Something Loving‚Äô, and ‚ÄòTest Me‚Äô in order to feel that these are songs crafted by people who felt them intensely.

Highlight: ‚ÄòOn Hold‚Äô seemed a bit divisive when it was released ahead of the album, as it calls out the departures that The xx‚Äôs sound was taking on the record. Some reacted with shock or disappointment, but I was onboard immediately.

15. Submerse ‚Äî Are You Anywhere

For my money Are You Anywhere represents as strong a set of tracks as Submerse has released since I‚Äôve been listening to him, starting with Slow Waves ‚Äì which was my number 5 album of 2014. (Stay Home just missed out on a spot in 2015, and in 2016 he grabbed 13th for Awake.) Both the mix of organic & electronic elements, and the dazed-sounding production, are familiar from previous albums, and the spell that‚Äôs cast here is just as effective on me as ever.

In four albums and a couple of EPs over the last four years Submerse hasn‚Äôt really made much of a departure from his core sound. However, it‚Äôs a sound that I can‚Äôt get enough of, and my only complaint here is that 31 minutes is too short a time to spend in this sonic space.

Highlight: ‚ÄòToo Many Sidequests‚Äô makes use of Submerse‚Äôs knack for incorporating video game sound effects into alien soundscapes.

14. INHEAVEN ‚Äî INHEAVEN

What happened to The Subways? Wikipedia says they‚Äôre still extant, but nothing‚Äôs been released in 5 years, and I don‚Äôt remember hearing anything in nearly a decade. Anyway: INHEAVEN have made a pretty great record in the same mould, with perhaps a bit more Pixies influence (hence the name, I guess), and a bit more lightness in its step. It‚Äôs loud, it‚Äôs brash, and it‚Äôs unashamedly fun more-or-less from start to finish.

Songs like ‚ÄòTreats‚Äô & ‚ÄòVulture‚Äô are designed for chanting along to, and I can‚Äôt listen to them without imagining what they would do to the front half of Brixton Academy. But this is a band that does have at least one gear above ‚Äòsimple crowd-pleasing stomper‚Äô and it‚Äôs telling that several of the tracks here very quickly feel as though you‚Äôve known them for a long time.

Highlight: ‚ÄòStupid Things‚Äô is half sickly-sweet pop song and half tender-hearted confession.

13. Toro y Moi ‚Äî Boo Boo

Chaz Bear took fourth spot in 2015 with What For?, and it‚Äôs largely the same formula of dreamy tones, soft beats, and lightly-treated vocals that has him back on the list this time. ‚ÄòMirage‚Äô kicks off the album as it means to go on, and when it pauses three minutes in for Chaz to intone ‚ÄúOh, hello. I didn‚Äôt see you there‚Äù, I 100% believe that this music is just the soundtrack to his life, and we‚Äôre just showing up to peep in for another 50 minute dose.

The sound palate that Boo Boo shares with What For? is pretty singular ‚Äì it‚Äôs identifiable within a couple of bars as TyM ‚Äì and, as such, it‚Äôs likely to be a take-it-or-leave-it proposition. Personally I find the relaxed, pastel-infused vibes on these records to be borderline medicinal.

Highlight: ‚ÄòGirl Like You‚Äô sounds like an 80s chart pop song (which I absolutely do not intend as a pejorative) fed through Chaz‚Äôs particular filter, and it comes out sounding no less sweet but perhaps a bit more interesting.

12. Charly Bliss ‚Äî Guppy

Remember that dog. (mandatory lower case and full stop) ‚Äì 90s grunge-influenced, optimismcore / original recipe emo LA outfit who released at least one and maybe two masterpieces on Geffen? There‚Äôs still a part of me that identifies strongly with late 90s cartoon misanthrope Daria, and in that guise I love both that dog. and, now, Charly Bliss. They‚Äôre from the other coast, and they‚Äôre 20 years late, but there‚Äôs no doubting they‚Äôre playing from the heart, and maybe that‚Äôs all you need to rekindle an old sound. It certainly worked on me instantly; there are guitar sounds on this record I haven‚Äôt heard since Pinkerton and, turns out, I‚Äôve been missing them dearly.

Infectious; exuberant; wilfully, naively upbeat‚Ä¶ I need more of this sound in my life. There‚Äôs not much depth to what‚Äôs on offer here, but there doesn‚Äôt have to be. At least for a couple of records let‚Äôs just close our eyes and pretend it‚Äôs a couple of decades ago.

Highlight: ‚ÄòRuby‚Äô just might be my favourite song of the year. Pixies bass, vintage Weezer guitar, and one of the album‚Äôs best lilting, acrobatic vocals. If you‚Äôll forgive the pun, it‚Äôs kind of blissful.

11. Shigeto ‚Äî The New Monday

When I grow up I want to be Jason Heyward, five-time Gold Glove winner and flawless right-fielder for the Chicago Cubs. One of the many problems with that is that Heyward is eight years younger than me. So my second choice is Zachary Shigeto Saginaw. (I‚Äôm pretty sure Shigeto is also younger than me, but I don‚Äôt know that for a fact!)

My first Shigeto record was No Better Time Than Now, 17th spot on this list for 2013, and I‚Äôve been captivated ever since by his particular blend of electronica, hip-hop, and jazz. He‚Äôs endlessly inventive, effortlessly cool, and seemingly always able to capture a new sound or put a new spin on an old one. He‚Äôs also a ridiculous drummer. (I highly recommend watching some videos of his live performances.)

The New Monday is right up there with No Better Time‚Ä¶ for me. I‚Äôm still listening to the earlier record, and I have no trouble believing I‚Äôll still be playing this in five years.

Highlight: Opener ‚ÄòDetroit Pt II‚Äô is an evolution of one of No Better Time Than Now‚Äôs strongest tracks: ‚ÄòDetroit Pt I‚Äô.

(Side note: Shigeto isn‚Äôt flawless. He put out another record this year as a duo with vocalist ZelooperZ, as ZGTO. I did not get on with that album at all! Still, even Jason Heyward drops a ball now and then.)

10. Paramore ‚Äî After Laughter

On 2013‚Äôs list I excused Paramore‚Äôs inclusion at number 12 by joking that I am, in fact, a 15-year old girl. Quite why one tends to feel some form of guilt or shame for liking certain things, I don‚Äôt know. So in that spirit, though I might like to make another joke, I have to hold my hand up now and say that this band makes really good pop-rock albums, and I love them without reservation.

There is likely nothing here to win over new fans. But, that said, there are some new departures in terms of sound. Overall the instrumentation feels more heavily weighted to electronic drums and synths where it would have been more uniformly guitars previously. Several of the tracks have a synthy, 80s vibe to them, telegraphed upfront by the Kraftwerk outro to opener ‚ÄòHard Times‚Äô. Hayley Williams‚Äôs voice remains the group‚Äôs distinguishing factor, and is in fine form throughout here: by turns angry, soothing, empowered & empowering, and never less than note-perfect.

More of this please. Thanks.

Highlight: ‚ÄòFake Happy‚Äô begins as an acoustic sketch and blossoms into a Cyndi Lauper-esque stomper straight from the heart.

9. Arcade Fire ‚Äî Everything Now

I don‚Äôt know how they do it, but every time a new Arcade Fire album comes out I go through a period of disappointment, which lasts a few listens, before ultimately it wins me over completely and captures top spot on my year-end list. Well, everything except the final part of that process happened this time around also.

I think there‚Äôs something about AF‚Äôs music that has this polarising effect on listeners. Spin called Everything Now ‚Äúdeeply cynical‚Äù and ‚Äújoyless‚Äù; Pitchfork termed it ‚Äúpale‚Äù and ‚Äújoyless‚Äù, and yet I honestly don‚Äôt know what they‚Äôre hearing that I‚Äôm not, or what I‚Äôm hearing that they‚Äôre not. There are at least three tracks here that rank among the most musically euphoric the band have ever recorded. Which is maybe why just as many reviewers gave opinions similar to that of Slant, who thought Everything Now ‚Äúby far Arcade Fire’s most upbeat‚Ä¶ album to date‚Äù.

It‚Äôs one thing to disagree on the quality of an album, but in my experience this level of disparity on something like a record‚Äôs tone is very unusual. Maybe this is a band that makes emotionally confusing music, that takes the listener a while to catch up to. In short, this is still a band without a bad song in their catalogue. ‚ÄòEverything Now‚Äô, ‚ÄòCreature Comfort‚Äô, and ‚ÄòPut Your Money on Me‚Äô are some of the best songs they‚Äôve recorded, and yet this is their weakest album as a whole. After White Blood Cells and Elephant sometimes there‚Äôs an Icky Thump; after OK Computer and Kid A you‚Äôre allowed to make The King of Limbs. In both cases, as here, those are very strong records outshone by all their siblings.

Highlight: The slow build of the ABBA-indebted ‚ÄòPut Your Money on Me‚Äô is masterly. How something can sound simultaneously sad and like an 80s disco classic is‚Ä¶ confusing.

8. Lusine ‚Äî Sensorimotor

Back in March I was taking an early morning flight to the UK. It was due to depart Iceland at just after 06:00, which meant arriving at the airport sometime around 04:00; and to get to the airport there‚Äôs a ~45 minute coach ride from Reykjavik. That‚Äôs too early to pay attention to a podcast, or to concentrate on a book under some tiny, ineffective reading light. So I pressed play on a record I‚Äôd added to my library simply because I add everything that Ghostly International release to my library. It seems probable to me that Sensorimotor will always remind me of that drive out to the airport in the early morning dark. That‚Äôs just what the album sounds like to me now. The backbone of the record is a collection of bass beats and superior electronic sweeps. Out of which are composed a series of haunted sonic landscapes that feel monochromatic and restless, like a brain roused too early from sleep it would prefer to return to.

Highlight: ‚ÄòSlow Motion‚Äô is a bundle of nervous energy laid over a kick that sounds like a skipping heartbeat.

7. Four Tet ‚Äî New Energy

I‚Äôve been listening to Four Tet now for a little less than 15 years. In that time there have been some notable shifts in focus for the music that Kieran Hebden is creating. Rounds (2003) was the record that kicked off my interest, and is still held as the epitome of a certain (now possibly extinct?) sub-sub-genre somewhat awkwardly termed ‘folktronica’. Everything Ecstatic (2005) was vibrant and urgent, and in some ways presaged the shift that followed it. There is Love in You (2010) & Pink (2012) felt more like collections of tracks designed for the dance-floor. Not that they weren‚Äôt enjoyable coming through headphones or home speakers, just that the records themselves felt a little less cohesive even if they still retained the power to excite and move. This period was capped off with Beautiful Rewind (2013), which felt like the culmination of that particular sound for Hebden. The bifurcated nature of the EP Morning / Evening (2015) was a leading sign of the next shift that Four Tet‚Äôs music would take.

To me, even on first listen, New Energy feels like that latest sound‚Äôs full arrival. Unmistakably there are call-backs to what has come before ‚Äì in fact the sound might best be thought of as a seamless amalgamation of everything Four Tet has released to this point. And that‚Äôs some feat. This is a complex, multi-layered work that bears repeated listening, but which engages the listener on a very human level. Warm, open, and never less than a joy to listen to.

Highlight: Tough to pick one, but right now the steady, hypnotic ebb of ‚ÄòDaughter‚Äô is my favourite. That will change tomorrow.

6. St. Vincent ‚Äî MASSEDUCTION

Annie Clark nabbed second spot in 2014 with her previous, eponymous album; I‚Äôve been waiting impatiently ever since to find out what would come next. The answer, it seems, is another very fine collection of postmodern agit-pop that contains more ideas in each song than many bands have on a record.

For me, there‚Äôs no ‚ÄòDigital Witness‚Äô here, and perhaps not quite a ‚ÄòBirth in Reverse‚Äô, but this is one of those cases where comparison purely to the artist‚Äôs own catalogue gives a misleading picture. Simply put: not many musicians are making music like Annie Clark. Maybe it feels particularly acute in the post-Bowie / post-Prince world, but I find myself at pains to find and applaud this kind of brave, soul-searching, uncomfortable artistry. St. Vincent is an artist working in rarified air, way up there on the art-rock mountain. I will gladly continue to receive any and every transmission she sends down to us.

Highlight: ‚ÄôPills‚Äô is the off-kilter, whirligig result of Clark processing the modern condition, both her own and society‚Äôs. It‚Äôs wild-eyed and sarcastic, but also compassionate. (I recommend Clark‚Äôs appearance on The New Yorker Radio Hour, where she talks about the record and this song in particular.)

5. Sampha ‚Äî Process

I knew Sampha‚Äôs voice from no fewer than three 5-star tracks on SBTRKT‚Äôs 2014 record Wonder Where We‚Äôll Land (#3 on my list that year), and a feature on Kanye‚Äôs ‚ÄòSaint Pablo‚Äô. Additionally, though the exact vector escapes me now, somehow I heard Sampha‚Äôs track ‚ÄòBlood on Me‚Äô toward the end of last year, and knew I had to look out for the album. That song has lost none of its power for me, and is surrounded here by immaculate pieces of songwriting that balance strength and tenderness both sonically and lyrically. Warm beats matched with soft tones play host to Sampha‚Äôs voice, which is perhaps the album‚Äôs most singular instrument as it floats above the music and dips down into it to play amongst the melodies. Throughout it‚Äôs a spectacularly accomplished and self-assured debut, clearly the product of a phenomenally talented musician bringing forth precisely the sound that‚Äôs in his head.

Highlight: ‚Äò(No One Knows Me) Like the Piano‚Äô is one of those tracks where a musician strips everything back to voice and one instrument and leaves you in awe. As emotionally raw as it is stark in its composition; it‚Äôs a striking moment at the centre of the album.

4. Fazerdaze ‚Äî Morningside

There are some albums that you want to live inside. Imbued with warmth and brightness throughout, and a sense of weightless flow, Morningside joins my shortlist. There are elements of shoegaze to the sound, particularly in the way the vocals are treated, but the relative sparseness of the instrumentation and lightness of the production leaves the record feeling open and inviting. It‚Äôs notable that several of the tracks get their pace from prominent bass lines that are very effective despite (or perhaps because of) their simplicity. There‚Äôs not a great variety to the sound, but the record is only just over the half-hour mark and at ~3 minutes per song it can feel as though each track is a variation on a theme. The result is an understated gem of an indie pop record that I expect to be playing for some time to come.

Highlight: ‚ÄòLucky Girl‚Äô is perhaps the most distilled form of the record‚Äôs sound, and eminently danceable.

3. Bing & Ruth ‚Äî No Home of the Mind

I know very little about the artist(s) behind this record, and I realise that I‚Äôve unconsciously been safeguarding that ignorance so as not to spoil the mystique. This is ambient, post-classic music of precisely the kind I feel most in tune with. By turns haunting, uplifting, and meditative, these are pieces of tremendously adroit, understated composition. The piano is at each track‚Äôs centre, but is often found drifting in a sea of warm, shifting tones. The more I listened to it I started to feel as though this album sits somewhere halfway between the Radiohead of ‚ÄòVideotape‚Äô & ‚ÄòGive Up the Ghost‚Äô, and William Basinski‚Äôs The Disintegration Loops. It‚Äôs a more abstracted version of the former, which retains more of its formal integrity than that latter. And, similar to Basinski‚Äôs pieces, I‚Äôd be quite happy to play this for hours.

Highlight: ‚ÄòThe How of it Sped‚Äô sounds as though it is accompanying some moment of heartbreak from an unseen film.

2. Joywave ‚Äî Content

I don‚Äôt know what to do with this record. It snuck up on me. Joywave have one previous album to their name, which remains unknown to me because I have enough on my plate trying to digest this one.

Comprising an eclectic sound palate (including, but not limited to: math rock, electronica, dance, soul‚Ä¶) Content is mercurial in the extreme. The post-nu-metal riff that closes the otherwise danceable paean to lost innocence ‚ÄòRumors‚Äô doesn‚Äôt belong on the same album as the quiet, solo-piano lament of ‚ÄòConfidence‚Äô. But they‚Äôre actually sequenced right next to each other. And the latter is 48 seconds long. And it works! There are obvious allusions to Radiohead circa OK Computer (1997) here, but Joywave occupy a dancier, groovier space than the Oxford set. Lyrically though, they‚Äôre dealing with similar themes ‚Äì technology and its effect on humanity, feelings of self-doubt and loss of self-worth ‚Äì and, being something like 25 years younger, coming at them from a different point of view.

I find this record fascinating, and this band very exciting if they‚Äôre going to keep making music this inventive and urgent.

Highlight: ‚ÄòGoing to a Place‚Äô sounds like Keane got trapped in another dimension and sent a cry for help‚Ä¶ and then it completely switches up half-way through and becomes something transportive.

1. Jay Som ‚Äî Everybody Works

Not infrequently it still amazes me what can come out of one person‚Äôs bedroom. Speaking personally for a moment, as someone who has spent the past year coming to terms with their own artistic limitations, it‚Äôs nothing short of astounding to me that one person, skilled in the use of the tools of a craft, can bring something as beautiful as Everybody Works forth from nothing.

I could list some presumed influences on this record (shoegaze & post-rock for example) but there‚Äôs at least a half-dozen distinct genres in the blend here. The result is an album that feels truly singular and of a piece to me: a 36 minute work of artistic expression, filled with human warmth, colour, and feeling.

Highlight: ‚ÄòOne More Time, Please‚Äô is a perfect microcosm of the record in some respects. A disarming vocal, shining keys, and subtle low-key percussion, which all builds to a crescendoing guitar solo. Every note of every instrument performed by a 22 year old in her bedroom, sending something remarkable out into the world.

I feel that Beck operates in a similar fashion: whatever given sound or vibe he turns his attention to, he‚Äôs able to produce music that feels authentic. Sometimes it‚Äôs meditative (eg. *Sea Change* (2002)), sometimes a little sombre (eg. *Morning Phase* (2014)), and sometimes poppy and easygoing (eg. *Odelay* (1996) & *Guero* (2005)). And no matter which category he‚Äôs playing in, Beck‚Äôs consistently doing something interesting with it. Whether it‚Äôs Brazilian influences on *Guero*, or the hip-hop touches to *The Information* (2006), Beck is a restlessly inventive artist in the same mould as Madonna or Bj√∂rk (perhaps it‚Äôs something to do with the mononyms?). *Colors* is Beck in full-on pop assault mode. And he‚Äôs happy to pull from anywhere and everywhere to make it happen. Shamelessly detuned guitars and anthemic choruses; jaunty Beatles-esque piano; ‚ÄôNo Distraction‚Äô sounds like Sting collaborating with The Killers. In sum it‚Äôs the same trick that Daniel Johns et al managed to pull off with *Young Modern* (2007): the making of a pop album on one‚Äôs own artistic terms. It‚Äôs not quite as strange (or as sublime) as that Silverchair record, but both are unmistakably the work of diversely-talented musicians making a direct assault on whatever part of the brain responds to catchy pop music. Highlight: The panpipe melody that runs through title track ‚ÄòColors‚Äô ‚Äì anything that can make me love the sound of an instrument I previously hated has to be doing something right. ### 16. The xx ‚Äî *I See You* To my ears the third album from The xx sounds like a natural progression of a sound that started off very simple and somewhat reserved, and has blossomed into a form somewhat brighter, self-assured, and colourful. It‚Äôs only natural, in fact, that the band‚Äôs third album as a trio takes notes from *In Colour*, Jamie xx‚Äôs vibrant, dance-floor friendly solo album of 2015 (#8 on that year‚Äôs List). The blaring horns that start the record were called out by several reviewers as a shock departure for The xx‚Äôs sound; but the shock was far less if you‚Äôd allowed Jamie‚Äôs solo LP to work its magic on you a couple of years previously. All of which is not to say that *I See You* sounds entirely different from its predecessors. The heart of the record is still the haunted, sleek blend of trip-hop and the lighter side of the EDM spectrum. And the songwriting is still coming from somewhere intensely personal. It‚Äôs not necessary to know about the friction between bandmates that sits behind tracks like ‚ÄòSay Something Loving‚Äô, and ‚ÄòTest Me‚Äô in order to feel that these are songs crafted by people who felt them intensely. Highlight: ‚ÄòOn Hold‚Äô seemed a bit divisive when it was released ahead of the album, as it calls out the departures that The xx‚Äôs sound was taking on the record. Some reacted with shock or disappointment, but I was onboard immediately. ### 15. Submerse ‚Äî *Are You Anywhere* For my money *Are You Anywhere* represents as strong a set of tracks as Submerse has released since I‚Äôve been listening to him, starting with *Slow Waves* ‚Äì which was my number 5 album of 2014. (*Stay Home* just missed out on a spot in 2015, and in 2016 he grabbed 13th for *Awake*.) Both the mix of organic & electronic elements, and the dazed-sounding production, are familiar from previous albums, and the spell that‚Äôs cast here is just as effective on me as ever. In four albums and a couple of EPs over the last four years Submerse hasn‚Äôt really made much of a departure from his core sound. However, it‚Äôs a sound that I can‚Äôt get enough of, and my only complaint here is that 31 minutes is too short a time to spend in this sonic space. Highlight: ‚ÄòToo Many Sidequests‚Äô makes use of Submerse‚Äôs knack for incorporating video game sound effects into alien soundscapes. ### 14. INHEAVEN ‚Äî *INHEAVEN* What happened to The Subways? Wikipedia says they‚Äôre still extant, but nothing‚Äôs been released in 5 years, and I don‚Äôt remember hearing anything in nearly a decade. Anyway: INHEAVEN have made a pretty great record in the same mould, with perhaps a bit more Pixies influence (hence the name, I guess), and a bit more lightness in its step. It‚Äôs loud, it‚Äôs brash, and it‚Äôs unashamedly fun more-or-less from start to finish. Songs like ‚ÄòTreats‚Äô & ‚ÄòVulture‚Äô are designed for chanting along to, and I can‚Äôt listen to them without imagining what they would do to the front half of Brixton Academy. But this is a band that does have at least one gear above ‚Äòsimple crowd-pleasing stomper‚Äô and it‚Äôs telling that several of the tracks here very quickly feel as though you‚Äôve known them for a long time. Highlight: ‚ÄòStupid Things‚Äô is half sickly-sweet pop song and half tender-hearted confession. ### 13. Toro y Moi ‚Äî *Boo Boo* Chaz Bear took fourth spot in 2015 with *What For?*, and it‚Äôs largely the same formula of dreamy tones, soft beats, and lightly-treated vocals that has him back on the list this time. ‚ÄòMirage‚Äô kicks off the album as it means to go on, and when it pauses three minutes in for Chaz to intone ‚ÄúOh, hello. I didn‚Äôt see you there‚Äù, I 100% believe that this music is just the soundtrack to his life, and we‚Äôre just showing up to peep in for another 50 minute dose. The sound palate that *Boo Boo* shares with *What For?* is pretty singular ‚Äì it‚Äôs identifiable within a couple of bars as TyM ‚Äì and, as such, it‚Äôs likely to be a take-it-or-leave-it proposition. Personally I find the relaxed, pastel-infused vibes on these records to be borderline medicinal. Highlight: ‚ÄòGirl Like You‚Äô sounds like an 80s chart pop song (which I absolutely do not intend as a pejorative) fed through Chaz‚Äôs particular filter, and it comes out sounding no less sweet but perhaps a bit more interesting. ### 12. Charly Bliss ‚Äî *Guppy* Remember that dog. (mandatory lower case and full stop) ‚Äì 90s grunge-influenced, optimismcore / original recipe emo LA outfit who released at least one and maybe two masterpieces on Geffen? There‚Äôs still a part of me that identifies strongly with late 90s cartoon misanthrope Daria, and in that guise I love both that dog. and, now, Charly Bliss. They‚Äôre from the other coast, and they‚Äôre 20 years late, but there‚Äôs no doubting they‚Äôre playing from the heart, and maybe that‚Äôs all you need to rekindle an old sound. It certainly worked on me instantly; there are guitar sounds on this record I haven‚Äôt heard since *Pinkerton* and, turns out, I‚Äôve been missing them dearly. Infectious; exuberant; wilfully, naively upbeat‚Ä¶ I need more of this sound in my life. There‚Äôs not much depth to what‚Äôs on offer here, but there doesn‚Äôt have to be. At least for a couple of records let‚Äôs just close our eyes and pretend it‚Äôs a couple of decades ago. Highlight: ‚ÄòRuby‚Äô just might be my favourite song of the year. Pixies bass, vintage Weezer guitar, and one of the album‚Äôs best lilting, acrobatic vocals. If you‚Äôll forgive the pun, it‚Äôs kind of blissful. ### 11. Shigeto ‚Äî *The New Monday* When I grow up I want to be Jason Heyward, five-time Gold Glove winner and flawless right-fielder for the Chicago Cubs. One of the many problems with that is that Heyward is eight years younger than me. So my second choice is Zachary Shigeto Saginaw. (I‚Äôm pretty sure Shigeto is also younger than me, but I don‚Äôt know that for a fact!) My first Shigeto record was *No Better Time Than Now*, 17th spot on this list for 2013, and I‚Äôve been captivated ever since by his particular blend of electronica, hip-hop, and jazz. He‚Äôs endlessly inventive, effortlessly cool, and seemingly always able to capture a new sound or put a new spin on an old one. He‚Äôs also a ridiculous drummer. (I highly recommend watching some [videos of his live performances](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=DduNRXh3h3o).) *The New Monday* is right up there with *No Better Time‚Ä¶* for me. I‚Äôm still listening to the earlier record, and I have no trouble believing I‚Äôll still be playing this in five years. Highlight: Opener ‚ÄòDetroit Pt II‚Äô is an evolution of one of *No Better Time Than Now‚Äôs* strongest tracks: ‚ÄòDetroit Pt I‚Äô. (Side note: Shigeto isn‚Äôt flawless. He put out another record this year as a duo with vocalist ZelooperZ, as ZGTO. I did not get on with that album at all! Still, even Jason Heyward drops a ball now and then.) ### 10. Paramore ‚Äî *After Laughter* On 2013‚Äôs list I excused Paramore‚Äôs inclusion at number 12 by joking that I am, in fact, a 15-year old girl. Quite why one tends to feel some form of guilt or shame for liking certain things, I don‚Äôt know. So in that spirit, though I might like to make another joke, I have to hold my hand up now and say that this band makes really good pop-rock albums, and I love them without reservation. There is likely nothing here to win over new fans. But, that said, there are some new departures in terms of sound. Overall the instrumentation feels more heavily weighted to electronic drums and synths where it would have been more uniformly guitars previously. Several of the tracks have a synthy, 80s vibe to them, telegraphed upfront by the Kraftwerk outro to opener ‚ÄòHard Times‚Äô. Hayley Williams‚Äôs voice remains the group‚Äôs distinguishing factor, and is in fine form throughout here: by turns angry, soothing, empowered & empowering, and never less than note-perfect. More of this please. Thanks. Highlight: ‚ÄòFake Happy‚Äô begins as an acoustic sketch and blossoms into a Cyndi Lauper-esque stomper straight from the heart. ### 9. Arcade Fire ‚Äî *Everything Now* I don‚Äôt know how they do it, but every time a new Arcade Fire album comes out I go through a period of disappointment, which lasts a few listens, before ultimately it wins me over completely and captures top spot on my year-end list. Well, everything except the final part of that process happened this time around also. I think there‚Äôs something about AF‚Äôs music that has this polarising effect on listeners. Spin called *Everything Now* ‚Äúdeeply cynical‚Äù and ‚Äújoyless‚Äù; Pitchfork termed it ‚Äúpale‚Äù and ‚Äújoyless‚Äù, and yet I honestly don‚Äôt know what they‚Äôre hearing that I‚Äôm not, or what I‚Äôm hearing that they‚Äôre not. There are at least three tracks here that rank among the most musically euphoric the band have ever recorded. Which is maybe why just as many reviewers gave opinions similar to that of Slant, who thought *Everything Now* ‚Äúby far Arcade Fire's most upbeat‚Ä¶ album to date‚Äù. It‚Äôs one thing to disagree on the quality of an album, but in my experience this level of disparity on something like a record‚Äôs tone is very unusual. Maybe this is a band that makes emotionally confusing music, that takes the listener a while to catch up to. In short, this is still a band without a bad song in their catalogue. ‚ÄòEverything Now‚Äô, ‚ÄòCreature Comfort‚Äô, and ‚ÄòPut Your Money on Me‚Äô are some of the best songs they‚Äôve recorded, and yet this is their weakest album as a whole. After *White Blood Cells* and *Elephant* sometimes there‚Äôs an *Icky Thump*; after *OK Computer* and *Kid A* you‚Äôre allowed to make *The King of Limbs*. In both cases, as here, those are very strong records outshone by all their siblings. Highlight: The slow build of the ABBA-indebted ‚ÄòPut Your Money on Me‚Äô is masterly. How something can sound simultaneously sad and like an 80s disco classic is‚Ä¶ confusing. ### 8. Lusine ‚Äî *Sensorimotor* Back in March I was taking an early morning flight to the UK. It was due to depart Iceland at just after 06:00, which meant arriving at the airport sometime around 04:00; and to get to the airport there‚Äôs a ~45 minute coach ride from Reykjavik. That‚Äôs too early to pay attention to a podcast, or to concentrate on a book under some tiny, ineffective reading light. So I pressed play on a record I‚Äôd added to my library simply because I add everything that Ghostly International release to my library. It seems probable to me that *Sensorimotor* will always remind me of that drive out to the airport in the early morning dark. That‚Äôs just what the album sounds like to me now. The backbone of the record is a collection of bass beats and superior electronic sweeps. Out of which are composed a series of haunted sonic landscapes that feel monochromatic and restless, like a brain roused too early from sleep it would prefer to return to. Highlight: ‚ÄòSlow Motion‚Äô is a bundle of nervous energy laid over a kick that sounds like a skipping heartbeat. ### 7. Four Tet ‚Äî *New Energy* I‚Äôve been listening to Four Tet now for a little less than 15 years. In that time there have been some notable shifts in focus for the music that Kieran Hebden is creating. *Rounds* (2003) was the record that kicked off my interest, and is still held as the epitome of a certain (now possibly extinct?) sub-sub-genre somewhat awkwardly termed 'folktronica'. *Everything Ecstatic* (2005) was vibrant and urgent, and in some ways presaged the shift that followed it. *There is Love in You* (2010) & *Pink* (2012) felt more like collections of tracks designed for the dance-floor. Not that they weren‚Äôt enjoyable coming through headphones or home speakers, just that the records themselves felt a little less cohesive even if they still retained the power to excite and move. This period was capped off with *Beautiful Rewind* (2013), which felt like the culmination of that particular sound for Hebden. The bifurcated nature of the EP *Morning / Evening* (2015) was a leading sign of the next shift that Four Tet‚Äôs music would take. To me, even on first listen, *New Energy* feels like that latest sound‚Äôs full arrival. Unmistakably there are call-backs to what has come before ‚Äì in fact the sound might best be thought of as a seamless amalgamation of everything Four Tet has released to this point. And that‚Äôs some feat. This is a complex, multi-layered work that bears repeated listening, but which engages the listener on a very human level. Warm, open, and never less than a joy to listen to. Highlight: Tough to pick one, but right now the steady, hypnotic ebb of ‚ÄòDaughter‚Äô is my favourite. That will change tomorrow. ### 6. St. Vincent ‚Äî *MASSEDUCTION* Annie Clark nabbed second spot in 2014 with her previous, eponymous album; I‚Äôve been waiting impatiently ever since to find out what would come next. The answer, it seems, is another very fine collection of postmodern agit-pop that contains more ideas in each song than many bands have on a record. For me, there‚Äôs no ‚ÄòDigital Witness‚Äô here, and perhaps not quite a ‚ÄòBirth in Reverse‚Äô, but this is one of those cases where comparison purely to the artist‚Äôs own catalogue gives a misleading picture. Simply put: not many musicians are making music like Annie Clark. Maybe it feels particularly acute in the post-Bowie / post-Prince world, but I find myself at pains to find and applaud this kind of brave, soul-searching, uncomfortable artistry. St. Vincent is an artist working in rarified air, way up there on the art-rock mountain. I will gladly continue to receive any and every transmission she sends down to us. Highlight: ‚ÄôPills‚Äô is the off-kilter, whirligig result of Clark processing the modern condition, both her own and society‚Äôs. It‚Äôs wild-eyed and sarcastic, but also compassionate. (I recommend [Clark‚Äôs appearance on The New Yorker Radio Hour](https://www.newyorker.com/podcast/the-new-yorker-radio-hour/st-vincents-seduction-and-my-mothers-career-at-playboy), where she talks about the record and this song in particular.) ### 5. Sampha ‚Äî *Process* I knew Sampha‚Äôs voice from no fewer than three 5-star tracks on SBTRKT‚Äôs 2014 record *Wonder Where We‚Äôll Land* (#3 on my list that year), and a feature on Kanye‚Äôs ‚ÄòSaint Pablo‚Äô. Additionally, though the exact vector escapes me now, somehow I heard Sampha‚Äôs track ‚ÄòBlood on Me‚Äô toward the end of last year, and knew I had to look out for the album. That song has lost none of its power for me, and is surrounded here by immaculate pieces of songwriting that balance strength and tenderness both sonically and lyrically. Warm beats matched with soft tones play host to Sampha‚Äôs voice, which is perhaps the album‚Äôs most singular instrument as it floats above the music and dips down into it to play amongst the melodies. Throughout it‚Äôs a spectacularly accomplished and self-assured debut, clearly the product of a phenomenally talented musician bringing forth precisely the sound that‚Äôs in his head. Highlight: ‚Äò(No One Knows Me) Like the Piano‚Äô is one of those tracks where a musician strips everything back to voice and one instrument and leaves you in awe. As emotionally raw as it is stark in its composition; it‚Äôs a striking moment at the centre of the album. ### 4. Fazerdaze ‚Äî *Morningside* There are some albums that you want to live inside. Imbued with warmth and brightness throughout, and a sense of weightless flow, *Morningside* joins my shortlist. There are elements of shoegaze to the sound, particularly in the way the vocals are treated, but the relative sparseness of the instrumentation and lightness of the production leaves the record feeling open and inviting. It‚Äôs notable that several of the tracks get their pace from prominent bass lines that are very effective despite (or perhaps because of) their simplicity. There‚Äôs not a great variety to the sound, but the record is only just over the half-hour mark and at ~3 minutes per song it can feel as though each track is a variation on a theme. The result is an understated gem of an indie pop record that I expect to be playing for some time to come. Highlight: ‚ÄòLucky Girl‚Äô is perhaps the most distilled form of the record‚Äôs sound, and eminently danceable. ### 3. Bing & Ruth ‚Äî *No Home of the Mind* I know very little about the artist(s) behind this record, and I realise that I‚Äôve unconsciously been safeguarding that ignorance so as not to spoil the mystique. This is ambient, post-classic music of precisely the kind I feel most in tune with. By turns haunting, uplifting, and meditative, these are pieces of tremendously adroit, understated composition. The piano is at each track‚Äôs centre, but is often found drifting in a sea of warm, shifting tones. The more I listened to it I started to feel as though this album sits somewhere halfway between the Radiohead of ‚ÄòVideotape‚Äô & ‚ÄòGive Up the Ghost‚Äô, and William Basinski‚Äôs *The Disintegration Loops*. It‚Äôs a more abstracted version of the former, which retains more of its formal integrity than that latter. And, similar to Basinski‚Äôs pieces, I‚Äôd be quite happy to play this for hours. Highlight: ‚ÄòThe How of it Sped‚Äô sounds as though it is accompanying some moment of heartbreak from an unseen film. ### 2. Joywave ‚Äî *Content* I don‚Äôt know what to do with this record. It snuck up on me. Joywave have one previous album to their name, which remains unknown to me because I have enough on my plate trying to digest this one. Comprising an eclectic sound palate (including, but not limited to: math rock, electronica, dance, soul‚Ä¶) *Content* is mercurial in the extreme. The post-nu-metal riff that closes the otherwise danceable paean to lost innocence ‚ÄòRumors‚Äô doesn‚Äôt belong on the same album as the quiet, solo-piano lament of ‚ÄòConfidence‚Äô. But they‚Äôre actually sequenced right next to each other. And the latter is 48 seconds long. And it works! There are obvious allusions to Radiohead circa *OK Computer* (1997) here, but Joywave occupy a dancier, groovier space than the Oxford set. Lyrically though, they‚Äôre dealing with similar themes ‚Äì technology and its effect on humanity, feelings of self-doubt and loss of self-worth ‚Äì and, being something like 25 years younger, coming at them from a different point of view. I find this record fascinating, and this band very exciting if they‚Äôre going to keep making music this inventive and urgent. Highlight: ‚ÄòGoing to a Place‚Äô sounds like Keane got trapped in another dimension and sent a cry for help‚Ä¶ and then it completely switches up half-way through and becomes something transportive. ### 1. Jay Som ‚Äî *Everybody Works* Not infrequently it still amazes me what can come out of one person‚Äôs bedroom. Speaking personally for a moment, as someone who has spent the past year coming to terms with their own artistic limitations, it‚Äôs nothing short of astounding to me that one person, skilled in the use of the tools of a craft, can bring something as beautiful as *Everybody Works* forth from nothing. I could list some presumed influences on this record (shoegaze & post-rock for example) but there‚Äôs at least a half-dozen distinct genres in the blend here. The result is an album that feels truly singular and of a piece to me: a 36 minute work of artistic expression, filled with human warmth, colour, and feeling. Highlight: ‚ÄòOne More Time, Please‚Äô is a perfect microcosm of the record in some respects. A disarming vocal, shining keys, and subtle low-key percussion, which all builds to a crescendoing guitar solo. Every note of every instrument performed by a 22 year old in her bedroom, sending something remarkable out into the world. ‚èé Return to the [index of lists](/thelists)

items.title: 'Who Goes Nazi?' ‚Äî Dorothy Thompson (1941)
items.content_html:
Recently I was tipped to an excellent essay from a 1941 issue of Harper’s Magazine: ‘Who Goes Nazi?' by Dorothy Thompson. By way of imagining a series of guests at a dinner, Thompson interrogates the traits that incline¬†someone towards fascism.

His code is not his own; it is that of his class‚Äîno worse, no better, He fits easily into whatever pattern is successful. That is his sole measure of value‚Äîsuccess. Nazism as a minority movement would not attract him. As a movement likely to attain power, it would.

The cumulative effect of the essay’s¬†construction is impressive; it’s a brilliant piece of social anthropology, and perhaps even more so considering when it was written and published.

Kind, good, happy, gentlemanly, secure people never go Nazi. They may be the gentle philosopher whose name is in the Blue Book, or Bill from City College to whom democracy gave a chance to design airplanes‚Äîyou‚Äôll never make Nazis out of them. But the frustrated and humiliated intellectual, the rich and scared speculator, the spoiled son, the labor tyrant, the fellow who has achieved success by smelling out the wind of success‚Äîthey would all go Nazi in a crisis.

In¬†the modern¬†political climate of emboldened, far-right / alt-right nationalism¬†it’s impossible to read the piece¬†and not mentally extrapolate Thompson’s¬†exercise into our current circumstance.

Recently I was tipped to an excellent essay from a 1941 issue of *Harper's Magazine*: ['Who Goes Nazi?'](https://harpers.org/archive/1941/08/who-goes-nazi/) by Dorothy Thompson. By way of imagining a series of guests at a dinner, Thompson interrogates the traits that incline¬†someone towards fascism.

> His code is not his own; it is that of his class‚Äîno worse, no better, He fits easily into whatever pattern is successful. That is his sole measure of value‚Äîsuccess. Nazism as a minority movement would not attract him. As a movement likely to attain power, it would.

The cumulative effect of the essay's¬†construction is impressive; it's a brilliant piece of social anthropology, and perhaps even more so considering when it was written and published.

> Kind, good, happy, gentlemanly, secure people never go Nazi. They may be the gentle philosopher whose name is in the Blue Book, or Bill from City College to whom democracy gave a chance to design airplanes‚Äîyou‚Äôll never make Nazis out of them. But the frustrated and humiliated intellectual, the rich and scared speculator, the spoiled son, the labor tyrant, the fellow who has achieved success by smelling out the wind of success‚Äîthey would all go Nazi in a crisis.

In¬†the modern¬†political climate of emboldened, far-right / alt-right nationalism¬†it's impossible to [read the piece](https://harpers.org/archive/1941/08/who-goes-nazi/)¬†and *not* mentally extrapolate Thompson's¬†exercise into our current circumstance.

items.title: Moderation
items.content_html:
Possibly in light of the weaponising of fake news during the 2016 American presidential election, and the increasing frequency with which acts of violence are being livestreamed,¬†the debate around methods of moderation on the internet has seemingly heated up again. The crux of the problem is that more content is uploaded to popular platforms every minute than can be screened by even an army of human moderators, and the algorithms aren’t yet capable of parsing the nuances in text (let alone images or video) that would be required for them to make determinations on context, intent, and suitability.¬†Add in the The Guardian’s¬†recent reporting on Facebook’s policies for its human moderators, and the problem seems ever more intractable. On the flipside, I’m noticing the case being made more frequently that the seeming necessity of turning over more control to algorithms is in fact actively worsening the standard of content and the experience of internet¬†use. In his recent talk at re:publica¬†‘17 in Berlin (titled ‘Notes from an Emergency’) Maciej Ceglowski phrased it this way:

The danger facing us is not Orwell, but Huxley. The combo of data collection and machine learning is too good at catering to human nature, seducing us and appealing to our worst instincts. We have to put controls on it. The algorithms are amoral; to make them behave morally will require active intervention.

This suggestion, that the algorithms are exacerbating the problem rather than assisting in eliminating it, is also echoed in this recent piece on Ev Williams in The New York Times:

The trouble with the internet, Mr. Williams says, is that it rewards extremes. Say you‚Äôre driving down the road and see a car crash. Of course you look. Everyone looks. The internet interprets behavior like this to mean everyone is asking for car crashes, so it tries to supply them.
