items.title: The List 2016
items.content_html:
At the end of each year I make a list of the twenty albums I enjoyed the most. To be eligible, a record has to be of album length (at least ~30 mins), and contain entirely (or almost entirely) new material; live albums, cover records, and compilations are ineligible.

20. Deftones ‚Äî Gore

Deftones topped 2012‚Äôs List with Koi No Yokan after a stretch of three albums in ten years that didn’t live up to the promise of 2000‚Äôs career-defining White Pony. Four years later I‚Äôm happy to find Gore again hitting all of the right notes and innovating a little further sonically to keep them where they belong (as pretty much the only heavy rock act I pay attention to any more). Gore is the first album to be released since the death of original bassist Chi Cheng in 2013 (following the car crash in 2008 that left him in a coma). As such it is necessarily coloured (particularly lyrically) by Chino Moreno dealing with the final loss of his friend and bandmate. As with much of Deftones‚Äô previous work, there is an expert blending of darkness & anger with lighter, more emotionally nuanced elements that allow the band to access a lot of places that other acts in the same space can’t or don‚Äôt. There‚Äôs a finesse to their art, with Moreno‚Äôs voice still setting the tone, and the instrumentation as adept as ever in supporting the emotional direction(s) of the songs.

Following Cheng‚Äôs death there has been talk of releasing the now legendary Eros, the album that was near-complete at the time of his accident. It would be very interesting to know what a Deftones album recorded in 2008 would sound like were it released now. As it is, I‚Äôm just happy that the band are still making new music of this standard.

19. Honeyblood ‚Äî Babes Never Die

After a swelling intro, the title track establishes quickly exactly what kind of record Honeyblood have made: post-bubblegum garage pop, and throughout a dozen tracks it‚Äôs delivered here in excellent form. Album high-point ‚ÄòReady for the Magic‚Äô has detuned bass, handclaps, and a chorus to die for or dance to (take your pick). There are a couple of down-tempo moments (such as the Melvins-meet-Breeders dirge of ‚ÄòLove is a Disease‚Äô), but the main vibe is a kind of slant coyness, showcased in various attitudes from the sweeping ‚ÄòGangs‚Äô to the low thrum of ‚ÄòWalking at Midnight‚Äô. Honeyblood know how to craft a bridge, and at 39 minutes they also know how to get in and get out having delivered a few body blows.

18. Chance the Rapper ‚Äî Coloring Book

Spoilers: you‚Äôre not going to find Kanye West‚Äôs The Life of Pablo on this list. That record is overly long, very self-indulgent (as you might expect), occasionally transcendently masterful, but often frustratingly pedestrian or confused. As events surrounding its release may have hinted, and events since have confirmed, Kanye isn‚Äôt in a great place right now, and personally I think that contributed to ‚Ä¶Pablo being a bit of a mess.

Chance‚Äôs Coloring Book is the record I wish Kanye still feels he could make. It‚Äôs the record that Late Registration-era Kanye could have put together in two weeks, but its relaxed attitude, sunny vibes, and good humour now seem (temporarily at least) beyond Chicago‚Äôs first son of rap; that baton has been passed, and Chance is running with it. Perhaps ironically it picks up precisely where Chance‚Äôs contribution to Kanye‚Äôs best track of 2016 ‚Äî ‚ÄòUltralight Beam‚Äô ‚Äî left off, and from there it soars through bouncy floor-fillers and relaxed summer jams, rarely pausing to take a breath. With ‚ÄòBlessings‚Äô Chance has fashioned perhaps what amounts to a sonic calling card: humble, not overworked, relaxed, and fairly glowing right out the speakers.

17. Thao & The Get Down Stay Down ‚Äî A Man Alive

30 seconds or so into album opener ‚ÄòAstonished Man‚Äô one thinks ‚Äòthis sounds kinda like tUnE-yArDs‚Äô, and one is not wrong: produced by Merrill Garbus, this set of quirky dark-pop belays her ear for space and gain, for fuzz and weird editing choices and for simple, driving percussion that holds down something otherwise less grounded. (‚ÄòAstonished Man‚Äô was also the subject of an excellent episode of Song Exploder this year, which reveals the song‚Äôs deeply-personal roots.) Thao‚Äôs voice is an instrument perfectly-suited to switching from conversational to plaintive to innocent and sing-songy. It‚Äôs in particularly good form somersaulting all over the Pixies-ish ‚ÄòThe Evening‚Äô, which just about loses out on album-highlight honours in favour of the catchy moodswing of ‚ÄòNobody Dies‚Äô, which is possessed of the kind of chorus you‚Äôll sing the first time, hum for days, and then just bellow out the next time you hear it. Every part of the band gets a moment to shine on A Man Alive, but I found that my favourite moments were often the Regina Spektor-esque confessional moments, such as on ‚ÄòGuts‚Äô (the second-best song with that title in 2016). Come for the pop, stay for the barrage of interesting ideas and left- of-centre hooks. 

16. Beyonce ‚Äî Lemonade

To this point Beyonce hasn‚Äôt been an album artist for me. There have been a handful of singles through the years that have lit up my radar and caught in my mind, but it hasn‚Äôt been enough to convince me to spend an hour with her music. The 65 minute music video that accompanied the release of Lemonade was more than enough to change my mind: beautiful, inventive, and extraordinarily accomplished, the first watch of that film remains one of my cultural high-points of 2016. It also serves as an excellent showcase of what a diverse collection of music is to be found on the album itself. Hip-hop, R&B, soul-flavours, a little country on ‚ÄòDaddy Lessons‚Äô, a pure-bred ballad like ‚ÄòSandcastles‚Äô, whatever garage rock-vibed thing Jack White‚Äôs helping bring forth on ‚ÄòDon‚Äôt Hurt Yourself‚Äô… there‚Äôs a lot here. And it‚Äôs all delivered with energy to spare and immaculately produced. There‚Äôs also the much- publicised matter of the album‚Äôs central subject: her husband‚Äôs infidelity. It‚Äôs a theme that provides the emotional fuel for all of the music here, and keeps it feeling honest, and it‚Äôs also the joining thread that runs through what otherwise may have felt like a disparate collection of tracks. It should also be noted that ‚ÄòFreedom‚Äô is top 5 songs of the year material, and felt increasingly prophetic and necessary as 2016 wore on.

15. Olafur Arnalds & Nils Frahm ‚Äî Trance Frendz

Arnalds‚Äôs solo record …And They Have Escaped the Weight of Darkness places 12th on my List in 2010, and represents both my serious introduction to his work and the reason I‚Äôve followed him since. Nils Frahm took a deserved 12th spot with Solo last year (a record given some new life this year by the release of a kind of director‚Äôs cut edition: Solo Remains). Their working together is the kind of partnership that seems so inevitable that it must surely have been a case of when as opposed to whether. Pleasingly, the fruits of the partnership, whilst familiar-sounding, are different enough that they seem unlikely to have ever emerged from one or other of the artists alone. Spare and delicate in composition as they both are they have taken obvious care not to do too much here, and to facilitate one another where it would have been easy for toes to be trodden upon. An ill-fitting title (it would have been incredible if they‚Äôd made a trance record though), inscrutable track names, and an album cover that looks like something they decided wasn‚Äôt quite interesting enough to go on Instagram, is all par for the course, and all meaningless once ‚Äò20:17‚Äô begins and you can forget everything else in the world for three-quarters of an hour. Beautiful stuff.

14. Flume ‚Äî Skin

The last few years I‚Äôve seemingly latched on to at least one album of bright, warm electronica that stays on heavy rotation for months. Fort Romeau‚Äôs Insides played the role last year, and it was SBTRKT‚Äôs sublime Wonder Where We’ll Land in 2014; this year the task falls to Flume. Similarly to that SBTRKT record this is a set of songs that benefit from a host of guest vocalists lending distinct flavours to a number of tracks throughout, but it‚Äôs all underpinned with the a softly undulating blanket of pastel-coloured warmth that ebbs and flows to its own hypnotising rhythm. Album-opener ‚ÄòHelix‚Äô crests with a minute to go, and sets the relaxed tempo, then picked up by highlight track ‚ÄòNever Be Like You‚Äô. Raekwon makes a notable appearance, and the record closes on a mellow high with Beck lending vocals to ‚ÄòTiny Cities‚Äô, but what kept this playing for me was the soundscape that Flume conjures throughout.

13. Submerse ‚Äî Awake

Submerse took 5th spot in 2014 with the wonderful Slow Waves, and whilst I enjoyed the follow-up (2015‚Äôs Stay Home) it just missed out on last year‚Äôs list. Awake finds Submerse back on The List and further securing his place as one of my desert island artists. Ethereal opener ‘Too Late, They‚Äôre Already Here‚Äô is transportive, and gives way to perhaps my favourite Submerse track, ‚ÄòSidequests‚Äô: a shimmering pool of muted pops, shining chimes, and a mellow synth are met by a minimal refrain in a climbing register. Like many of his tracks, it blends the electronic and the acoustic seamlessly into something unique-feeling and oddly alive. I listened to this set of tracks dozens of times this year and found new things on each play through. At this point it would be a shock if the next Submerse release sounded dramatically different to this, since his recent output is all quite similar, but I‚Äôm excited for it regardless. This is a sonic space I’ll happily return to time and time again.

12. Solange ‚Äî A Seat at the Table

Here‚Äôs something I‚Äôve struggled with a bit this year: a prevailing sense that some of the music I got the most enjoyment from is not intended for me. Whilst sensitive to cultural heritage I‚Äôm not a believer that such broad distinctions as ‚Äòwhite music‚Äô and ‚Äòblack music‚Äô exist; I don‚Äôt subscribe to the reductive idea that entire genres of music are the province of one set of people or another. However, when an album like A Seat at the Table comes along, and speaks in large part about the black experience, there‚Äôs a reflexive guilt and fear of cultural appropriation that rises in me at claiming it as one of my favourite albums of the year. Oddly, this isn‚Äôt something that seems to translate to other media: I have no problem saying that Ta-Nehisi Coates‚Äôs Between the World and Me was one of the very best books I read this year, or that The Get Down and Atlanta were two of my favourite TV shows of 2016 - all exemplary pieces of art that deal directly, primarily with black cultural history. Still, in the final analysis it would be disingenuous of me to leave Solange off this list. A Seat at the Table is a collection of beautifully crafted, soul-infused R&B songs that mix the deeply personal with insightful social commentary like few records I‚Äôve heard the last couple of years. It is bold and vital, and despite all the ways in which it‚Äôs not for me it gave me too much not to recognise the important role it played in my listening in 2016.

11. Angel Olsen ‚Äî MY WOMAN

What drew me to the (obligatorily fully capped-up) MY WOMAN in the first place was catching the track ‚ÄòShut Up Kiss Me‚Äô being played on Beats1. Had the album been a wash that still would have been fine, since that one track ‚Äî with it‚Äôs endearing mix of bokeh warmth and aching longing ‚Äî ended up being probably my favourite song of 2016. Fortunately there are plenty of other treats in store on an album that puts garage pop-rock through its paces, whilst bending it to all of its intended purposes: exciting, yearning, commiserating, celebrating, and the painting of personal stories of loss and misunderstanding in love. Olsen‚Äôs voice is the right balance between emotionally affected and lackadaisical, and her guitar is usually found in a similar (Ben Kweller-esque) attitude, moving between relaxed strum and energised pounding of the three or four chords that make up each song.

This is an easygoing album full of memorable, hummable, sing-alongable songs. It spawned a couple of the year‚Äôs stickiest tracks as far as my inner ear was concerned, with ‚ÄòShut Up Kiss Me‚Äô not the only song from the collection that continued spinning ad infinitum in my mind. (PS The roller-skating video to that song is also a lot of fun.)

10. Ryo Fukui ‚Äî Mellow Dream

I listened to a bit more jazz this year than has been the case the last couple, and whilst there have been a few records I‚Äôve enjoyed (shouts to Takuya Kuroda‚Äôs Zigzagger and Shabaka & the Ancestors‚Äô Wisdom of Elders) only one really got its hooks into me in a serious must-play-every-other-day kind of way. Mellow Dream is aptly titled, and I never got tired of closing my eyes and revisiting Fukui‚Äôs lively, colourful compositions. Some of the absolute best, most energetic and surprising piano playing I‚Äôve heard in years over the top of a bass and percussion line that always knows just what‚Äôs required to keep each piece flowing. The title track / opener and follow-up ‚ÄòMy Foolish Heart‚Äô are light and breezy, where ‚ÄòBaron Potato Blues‚Äô has a bit more of a swagger, and the closing rendition of ‚ÄòMy Funny Valentine‚Äô is a little sad and demure. Throughout it‚Äôs impossible not to be impressed by Fukui‚Äôs playing, but taken holistically the album is an equally impressive achievement.

9. Gold Panda ‚Äî Good Luck and Do Your Best

The charming friendliness of this album‚Äôs title is carried over into its welcoming ambience. Though occasionally employing some harder edges (such as on the haunting ‚ÄòSong for a Dead Friend‚Äô), the album‚Äôs overall vibe is of easygoing acceptance. Acoustic instruments layer upon drum patterns and sparingly-employed synth to make beautiful sculptures of sound like the meditative and hypnotic ‚ÄòTime Eater‚Äô, and the resigned, good-natured ‚ÄòAutumn Fall‚Äô. At the album‚Äôs centre is a track called ‚ÄòI Am Real Punk‚Äô which despite its title displays a kind of measured grace; its a microcosm of this self- assured, slightly odd collection of electronica.

8. Lone ‚Äî Levitate

I find it difficult to believe now that Lone‚Äôs 2014 record Reality Testing didn’t make my top 20 for that year, but there you go: times change. Much like on that record Lone has here put together a dazzling set of breakbeats over and through which he weaves hard-edged synth in deeply rhythmic patterns. Very few tracks swung harder for me this year than ‚ÄòBacktail Was Heavy‚Äô, and it has a couple of nice counterpoints here in the frenetic ‚ÄòTriple Helix‚Äô and the slowly imploding ‚ÄòSleepwalkers‚Äô. Levitate is a record that finds that sweet spot: at 34 minutes (good portions of which push the BPMs) it doesn‚Äôt outstay its welcome, but it also never runs out of ideas. As the closing moments of ‚ÄòHiraeth‚Äô ebb away I almost always wanted to loop back to the start and take the journey again.

7. Holy Fuck ‚Äî Congrats

Holy Fuck are one of those bands that I‚Äôve been hearing about for years, and have never taken the time to get to know. When I finally saw too many recommendations for Congrats to ignore, and tuned in, I was immediately glad that I did. For one thing ‚Äî speaking a bit reductively ‚Äî in a year with no Liars LP and no Battles LP this helped fill a requirement for a particular type of over-energised, spiralling, de-tuned noise. Taken on its own merits though (as it should be) Congrats is raucous, sonically all-encompassing, and endlessly inventive: it keeps you off balance throughout in the same way the better Mars Volta records do. Album high point ‚ÄòHouse of Glass‚Äô takes turns at being punishing, then jaunty, then punishing again as it unleashes a central bass-heavy refrain that sounds like a heart attack. There are certainly subtler moments, such as on the interlude ‚ÄòShimmering‚Äô and the rather poppier ‚ÄòNeon Dad‚Äô, but this isn‚Äôt pretending to be a pop album. It‚Äôs an odd thing, which challenges you to wrestle with it and in doing so dig out some hidden treasures. It‚Äôs well worth the effort.

6. Tegan & Sara ‚Äî Love You To Death

A new T&S album will likely always remain a landmark release for me purely on the strength of 2004‚Äôs near-flawless So Jealous. But it would be wrong to think of the Quins as still riding the wake of one great album as they‚Äôve consistently found ways to experiment with their own sound in new and impressive ways. The Con (2007) managed to find a way out of So Jealous‚Äôs shadow by virtue of being odder, exhibiting rougher textures and sharper angles; Sainthood in 2009 took a larger step towards synth-based compositions, and Heartthrob doubled down on that in 2013. If anything I feel like I was a little behind the curve on those last two records, feeling a little disappointed by them in the first instance before being won over by their infectious charms. I felt more prepared for Love You To Death, and sure enough I was on board from Ô£øMusic‚Äôs first plays of ‚ÄòBoyfriend‚Äô, ‚Äò100x‚Äô and personal favourite ‚ÄòStop Desire‚Äô that preceded the albums release. 32 minutes, 10 tracks, not a bad one in sight (despite some occasionally questionable half-rhyme lyrics here and there) and this record takes its place amongst my top 5 Tegan & Sara albums. It‚Äôs testament to their enduring excellence that that is rare company to be in. 

5. Explosions in the Sky ‚Äî The Wilderness

The short way to encapsulate how I feel about The Wilderness is to say that it‚Äôs EitS‚Äôs best LP since 2003‚Äôs The Earth is Not a Cold, Dead Place, which pretty much defined my personal understanding of post-rock. They‚Äôve made very good albums since, but this is the first to light up my synapses like the album that introduced me to them. Built largely of the same stuff as previous albums ‚Äî percussion that has the force of weather events, and great, snaking rivers of melody carving through canyon walls of guitar ‚Äî this record also finds places to introduce some muted electronic elements; never in a way that radically alters the band‚Äôs now-signature sound, but certainly in ways that complement and tweak it in subtle ways, surely make long-term listeners to EitS prick up their ears. My favourite of the record‚Äôs tracks is a toss-up between the propulsive, evangelic currant of ‚ÄòTangle Formations‚Äô, and the darker, Basinski-referencing first single ‚ÄòDisintegration Anxiety‚Äô. Nothing here is going to change anyone‚Äôs mind about the band (I wonder sometimes whether their rapturous live show might have the power to do so), but it is a welcome thing to find a band 17 years on from their formation still making compelling music that is very much their own. 

4. Bloc Party ‚Äî Hymns

In some respects the most quietly revolutionary album of 2016. After a four year break following Intimacy it didn‚Äôt feel like a sure thing that we‚Äôd see another Bloc Party album. And even after the successes of Four (2012) the four year break that followed that album had a ring of finality about it. In some bands (even four-pieces) it would be no big thing to replace the drummer and bassist; not so with Bloc Party, where Matt Tong and Gordon Moakes‚Äôs contributions were always beyond the average. Sure enough Hymns isn‚Äôt showcase to the same kind of frenetic, self-perpetuating drum patterns as previous of the band‚Äôs albums, and there are perhaps fewer truly memorable bass lines. However, that is at least in part down to the way in which the band‚Äôs sound has reconfigured itself here. The tempos are often more forgiving (certainly than was the case on Four), there is greater emphasis on Kele‚Äôs voice (with which he seems to feel increasingly comfortable). What remains is songwriting split fairly evenly between confessional and social commentary, and equally strong at each. But the textures that are new to Bloc Party offer an opportunity to reach into new spaces: the unsettled oddness of ‚ÄòDifferent Drugs‚Äô; the romantic swell of ‚ÄòMy True Name‚Äô undercut by a haunting choral vocal; the proto-gospel euphoria of ‚ÄòOnly He Can Heal Me‚Äô, which takes its place amongst the band‚Äôs best tracks. I remain happy just to have this band around, I‚Äôm always excited to see what Bloc Party do next, and for the first time I don‚Äôt really have a good idea what it might sound like. 

3. Elohim ‚Äî Elohim

Elohim was the discovery of 2016 for me, and several months on this record remains just as alluring and confounding as when I first ran across it. Opener ‚ÄòSensations‚Äô is all you need in order to know whether this will be a record for you; it hooked me after a single verse and chorus and hasn‚Äôt let go since. Poppier than Bat for Lashes and less angular than Grimes, this is still defiantly odd alt-pop music and with a dark edge that‚Äôs reflected in the performer‚Äôs penchant for wearing masks onstage and in her videos. (It‚Äôs worth mentioning that one of Elohim‚Äôs strongest tracks from 2016 ‚Äî‚ÄôHallucinations‚Äô ‚Äîisn‚Äôt on this album, but was released on a subsequent EP and is also accompanied by perhaps my favourite (single-track) music video of the year.) ‚ÄòShe Talks Too Much‚Äô is winking and a little giddy; ‚ÄòXanax‚Äô is aptly washed out and dreamlike, and feature‚Äôs one of 2016‚Äôs most memorable refrains (‚Äúevery day of my day of my day of my life‚Äù); ‚ÄòGuts‚Äô, though, squeaks into the album-highlight spot by somehow channeling both Robyn and Jim Guthrie. Singular but all the more magnetic for it, I couldn‚Äôt get enough of this. 

2. Rihanna ‚Äî ANTI

As I wrote above in relation to Beyonc√©, despite a set of jewel-perfect singles I had not previously thought of Rihanna as an album artist. Like the rest of the world then (if for different reasons), I wasn‚Äôt prepared for ANTI. Long in coming though it has been, when the album finally arrived at the tail end of the kind of wilfully obfuscatory social-media marketing campaign that is seemingly now de rigueur (see also The Life of Pablo, Views, Lemonade, Blond(e)) the reaction from music press and listening public alike was a near- universal: ‚Äòwha?‚Äô. I lost track of the number of times people pointed out there was no ‚ÄòUmbrella‚Äô here, no ‚ÄòTake a Bow‚Äô or ‚ÄòOnly Girl‚Äô, as though a pop artist is expected to work to a quota of one banger per x number of other songs, with which they can do what they like. On ANTI Rihanna is plainly not interested in working to the one-for-me-one-for-the-dancefloor model. Instead she‚Äôs happy to be flirtatious and demanding on ‚ÄòWork‚Äô, coy on ‚ÄòKiss it Better‚Äô, and somewhat terrifying on ‚ÄòNeeded Me‚Äô, all the while delivering flawless vocal performances (seriously, ‚ÄòHigher‚Äô alone remains near-unbelievable after 100+ listens) over the top of immaculate, captivating beats. If you need something else you can go listen to those Calvin Harris tracks that she makes into pop masterpieces just by showing up. I‚Äôll be here swaying to ‚ÄòLove on the Brain‚Äô or crying to ‚ÄòClose to You‚Äô. 

1. Radiohead ‚Äî A Moon Shaped Pool

I honestly don‚Äôt know where to start when talking about Radiohead. Perhaps it‚Äôs enough to say that I‚Äôve been on a quest for about 10 years to find anyone who makes music that sounds anything like theirs, and I haven‚Äôt come up with anything. Radiohead, at this point, is a one-band genre, but one that shifts and re-colours itself to always remain stunningly relevant and new-seeming. A Moon Shaped Pool isn‚Äôt so much an album of music as it is the latest dispatch in the cataloguing of the British liberal psyche: this is who we are at the moment, and how we feel, it seems to say. Still concerned about our lonelinesses and our failures, still preoccupied with finding a place in the world, but also increasingly overwhelmed by larger events, and frightened by the evanescence of hope.

Arcade Fire do voice and hope, and are similarly documentarian; Liars do complex and dense layers of confused feeling; Sigur Ros do rapture; Explosions in the Sky do overwhelm and exorcism‚Ä¶ only Radiohead consistently find a way to put all of those components together, and always in beautiful new ways that continue to awe me. We‚Äôre so very lucky to have them.

It‚Äôs in particularly good form somersaulting all over the Pixies-ish ‚ÄòThe Evening‚Äô, which just about loses out on album-highlight honours in favour of the catchy moodswing of ‚ÄòNobody Dies‚Äô, which is possessed of the kind of chorus you‚Äôll sing the first time, hum for days, and then just bellow out the next time you hear it. Every part of the band gets a moment to shine on *A Man Alive*, but I found that my favourite moments were often the Regina Spektor-esque confessional moments, such as on ‚ÄòGuts‚Äô (the second-best song with that title in 2016). Come for the pop, stay for the barrage of interesting ideas and left- of-centre hooks.  ### 16. Beyonce ‚Äî *Lemonade* To this point Beyonce hasn‚Äôt been an album artist for me. There have been a handful of singles through the years that have lit up my radar and caught in my mind, but it hasn‚Äôt been enough to convince me to spend an hour with her music. The 65 minute music video that accompanied the release of *Lemonade* was more than enough to change my mind: beautiful, inventive, and extraordinarily accomplished, the first watch of that film remains one of my cultural high-points of 2016. It also serves as an excellent showcase of what a diverse collection of music is to be found on the album itself. Hip-hop, R&B, soul-flavours, a little country on ‚ÄòDaddy Lessons‚Äô, a pure-bred ballad like ‚ÄòSandcastles‚Äô, whatever garage rock-vibed thing Jack White‚Äôs helping bring forth on ‚ÄòDon‚Äôt Hurt Yourself‚Äô... there‚Äôs a lot here. And it‚Äôs all delivered with energy to spare and immaculately produced. There‚Äôs also the much- publicised matter of the album‚Äôs central subject: her husband‚Äôs infidelity. It‚Äôs a theme that provides the emotional fuel for all of the music here, and keeps it feeling honest, and it‚Äôs also the joining thread that runs through what otherwise may have felt like a disparate collection of tracks. It should also be noted that ‚ÄòFreedom‚Äô is top 5 songs of the year material, and felt increasingly prophetic and necessary as 2016 wore on. ### 15. Olafur Arnalds & Nils Frahm ‚Äî *Trance Frendz* Arnalds‚Äôs solo record *...And They Have Escaped the Weight of Darkness* places 12th on my List in 2010, and represents both my serious introduction to his work and the reason I‚Äôve followed him since. Nils Frahm took a deserved 12th spot with *Solo* last year (a record given some new life this year by the release of a kind of director‚Äôs cut edition: *Solo Remains*). Their working together is the kind of partnership that seems so inevitable that it must surely have been a case of when as opposed to whether. Pleasingly, the fruits of the partnership, whilst familiar-sounding, are different enough that they seem unlikely to have ever emerged from one or other of the artists alone. Spare and delicate in composition as they both are they have taken obvious care not to do too much here, and to facilitate one another where it would have been easy for toes to be trodden upon. An ill-fitting title (it would have been incredible if they‚Äôd made a trance record though), inscrutable track names, and an album cover that looks like something they decided wasn‚Äôt quite interesting enough to go on Instagram, is all par for the course, and all meaningless once ‚Äò20:17‚Äô begins and you can forget everything else in the world for three-quarters of an hour. Beautiful stuff. ### 14. Flume ‚Äî *Skin* The last few years I‚Äôve seemingly latched on to at least one album of bright, warm electronica that stays on heavy rotation for months. Fort Romeau‚Äôs *Insides* played the role last year, and it was SBTRKT‚Äôs sublime *Wonder Where We'll Land* in 2014; this year the task falls to *Flume*. Similarly to that SBTRKT record this is a set of songs that benefit from a host of guest vocalists lending distinct flavours to a number of tracks throughout, but it‚Äôs all underpinned with the a softly undulating blanket of pastel-coloured warmth that ebbs and flows to its own hypnotising rhythm. Album-opener ‚ÄòHelix‚Äô crests with a minute to go, and sets the relaxed tempo, then picked up by highlight track ‚ÄòNever Be Like You‚Äô. Raekwon makes a notable appearance, and the record closes on a mellow high with Beck lending vocals to ‚ÄòTiny Cities‚Äô, but what kept this playing for me was the soundscape that Flume conjures throughout. ### 13. Submerse ‚Äî *Awake* Submerse took 5th spot in 2014 with the wonderful *Slow Waves*, and whilst I enjoyed the follow-up (2015‚Äôs *Stay Home*) it just missed out on last year‚Äôs list. *Awake* finds Submerse back on The List and further securing his place as one of my desert island artists. Ethereal opener 'Too Late, They‚Äôre Already Here‚Äô is transportive, and gives way to perhaps my favourite Submerse track, ‚ÄòSidequests‚Äô: a shimmering pool of muted pops, shining chimes, and a mellow synth are met by a minimal refrain in a climbing register. Like many of his tracks, it blends the electronic and the acoustic seamlessly into something unique-feeling and oddly alive. I listened to this set of tracks dozens of times this year and found new things on each play through. At this point it would be a shock if the next Submerse release sounded dramatically different to this, since his recent output is all quite similar, but I‚Äôm excited for it regardless. This is a sonic space I'll happily return to time and time again. ### 12. Solange ‚Äî *A Seat at the Table* Here‚Äôs something I‚Äôve struggled with a bit this year: a prevailing sense that some of the music I got the most enjoyment from is not intended for me. Whilst sensitive to cultural heritage I‚Äôm not a believer that such broad distinctions as ‚Äòwhite music‚Äô and ‚Äòblack music‚Äô exist; I don‚Äôt subscribe to the reductive idea that entire genres of music are the province of one set of people or another. However, when an album like *A Seat at the Table* comes along, and speaks in large part about the black experience, there‚Äôs a reflexive guilt and fear of cultural appropriation that rises in me at claiming it as one of my favourite albums of the year. Oddly, this isn‚Äôt something that seems to translate to other media: I have no problem saying that Ta-Nehisi Coates‚Äôs *Between the World and Me* was one of the very best books I read this year, or that *The Get Down* and *Atlanta* were two of my favourite TV shows of 2016 - all exemplary pieces of art that deal directly, primarily with black cultural history. Still, in the final analysis it would be disingenuous of me to leave Solange off this list. *A Seat at the Table* is a collection of beautifully crafted, soul-infused R&B songs that mix the deeply personal with insightful social commentary like few records I‚Äôve heard the last couple of years. It is bold and vital, and despite all the ways in which it‚Äôs not for me it gave me too much not to recognise the important role it played in my listening in 2016. ### 11. Angel Olsen ‚Äî *MY WOMAN* What drew me to the (obligatorily fully capped-up) MY WOMAN in the first place was catching the track ‚ÄòShut Up Kiss Me‚Äô being played on Beats1. Had the album been a wash that still would have been fine, since that one track ‚Äî with it‚Äôs endearing mix of bokeh warmth and aching longing ‚Äî ended up being probably my favourite song of 2016. Fortunately there are plenty of other treats in store on an album that puts garage pop-rock through its paces, whilst bending it to all of its intended purposes: exciting, yearning, commiserating, celebrating, and the painting of personal stories of loss and misunderstanding in love. Olsen‚Äôs voice is the right balance between emotionally affected and lackadaisical, and her guitar is usually found in a similar (Ben Kweller-esque) attitude, moving between relaxed strum and energised pounding of the three or four chords that make up each song. This is an easygoing album full of memorable, hummable, sing-alongable songs. It spawned a couple of the year‚Äôs stickiest tracks as far as my inner ear was concerned, with ‚ÄòShut Up Kiss Me‚Äô not the only song from the collection that continued spinning ad infinitum in my mind. (PS The roller-skating video to that song is also a lot of fun.) ### 10. Ryo Fukui ‚Äî *Mellow Dream* I listened to a bit more jazz this year than has been the case the last couple, and whilst there have been a few records I‚Äôve enjoyed (shouts to Takuya Kuroda‚Äôs *Zigzagger* and Shabaka & the Ancestors‚Äô *Wisdom of Elders*) only one really got its hooks into me in a serious must-play-every-other-day kind of way. *Mellow Dream* is aptly titled, and I never got tired of closing my eyes and revisiting Fukui‚Äôs lively, colourful compositions. Some of the absolute best, most energetic and surprising piano playing I‚Äôve heard in years over the top of a bass and percussion line that always knows just what‚Äôs required to keep each piece flowing. The title track / opener and follow-up ‚ÄòMy Foolish Heart‚Äô are light and breezy, where ‚ÄòBaron Potato Blues‚Äô has a bit more of a swagger, and the closing rendition of ‚ÄòMy Funny Valentine‚Äô is a little sad and demure. Throughout it‚Äôs impossible not to be impressed by Fukui‚Äôs playing, but taken holistically the album is an equally impressive achievement. ### 9. Gold Panda ‚Äî *Good Luck and Do Your Best* The charming friendliness of this album‚Äôs title is carried over into its welcoming ambience. Though occasionally employing some harder edges (such as on the haunting ‚ÄòSong for a Dead Friend‚Äô), the album‚Äôs overall vibe is of easygoing acceptance. Acoustic instruments layer upon drum patterns and sparingly-employed synth to make beautiful sculptures of sound like the meditative and hypnotic ‚ÄòTime Eater‚Äô, and the resigned, good-natured ‚ÄòAutumn Fall‚Äô. At the album‚Äôs centre is a track called ‚ÄòI Am Real Punk‚Äô which despite its title displays a kind of measured grace; its a microcosm of this self- assured, slightly odd collection of electronica. ### 8. Lone ‚Äî *Levitate* I find it difficult to believe now that Lone‚Äôs 2014 record *Reality Testing* didn't make my top 20 for that year, but there you go: times change. Much like on that record *Lone* has here put together a dazzling set of breakbeats over and through which he weaves hard-edged synth in deeply rhythmic patterns. Very few tracks swung harder for me this year than ‚ÄòBacktail Was Heavy‚Äô, and it has a couple of nice counterpoints here in the frenetic ‚ÄòTriple Helix‚Äô and the slowly imploding ‚ÄòSleepwalkers‚Äô. Levitate is a record that finds that sweet spot: at 34 minutes (good portions of which push the BPMs) it doesn‚Äôt outstay its welcome, but it also never runs out of ideas. As the closing moments of ‚ÄòHiraeth‚Äô ebb away I almost always wanted to loop back to the start and take the journey again. ### 7. Holy Fuck ‚Äî *Congrats* Holy Fuck are one of those bands that I‚Äôve been hearing about for years, and have never taken the time to get to know. When I finally saw too many recommendations for *Congrats* to ignore, and tuned in, I was immediately glad that I did. For one thing ‚Äî speaking a bit reductively ‚Äî in a year with no Liars LP and no Battles LP this helped fill a requirement for a particular type of over-energised, spiralling, de-tuned noise. Taken on its own merits though (as it should be) *Congrats* is raucous, sonically all-encompassing, and endlessly inventive: it keeps you off balance throughout in the same way the better Mars Volta records do. Album high point ‚ÄòHouse of Glass‚Äô takes turns at being punishing, then jaunty, then punishing again as it unleashes a central bass-heavy refrain that sounds like a heart attack. There are certainly subtler moments, such as on the interlude ‚ÄòShimmering‚Äô and the rather poppier ‚ÄòNeon Dad‚Äô, but this isn‚Äôt pretending to be a pop album. It‚Äôs an odd thing, which challenges you to wrestle with it and in doing so dig out some hidden treasures. It‚Äôs well worth the effort. ### 6. Tegan & Sara ‚Äî *Love You To Death* A new T&S album will likely always remain a landmark release for me purely on the strength of 2004‚Äôs near-flawless *So Jealous*. But it would be wrong to think of the Quins as still riding the wake of one great album as they‚Äôve consistently found ways to experiment with their own sound in new and impressive ways. *The Con* (2007) managed to find a way out of *So Jealous‚Äôs* shadow by virtue of being odder, exhibiting rougher textures and sharper angles; *Sainthood* in 2009 took a larger step towards synth-based compositions, and *Heartthrob* doubled down on that in 2013. If anything I feel like I was a little behind the curve on those last two records, feeling a little disappointed by them in the first instance before being won over by their infectious charms. I felt more prepared for *Love You To Death*, and sure enough I was on board from Ô£øMusic‚Äôs first plays of ‚ÄòBoyfriend‚Äô, ‚Äò100x‚Äô and personal favourite ‚ÄòStop Desire‚Äô that preceded the albums release. 32 minutes, 10 tracks, not a bad one in sight (despite some occasionally questionable half-rhyme lyrics here and there) and this record takes its place amongst my top 5 Tegan & Sara albums. It‚Äôs testament to their enduring excellence that that is rare company to be in.  ### 5. Explosions in the Sky ‚Äî *The Wilderness* The short way to encapsulate how I feel about *The Wilderness* is to say that it‚Äôs EitS‚Äôs best LP since 2003‚Äôs *The Earth is Not a Cold, Dead Place*, which pretty much defined my personal understanding of post-rock. They‚Äôve made very good albums since, but this is the first to light up my synapses like the album that introduced me to them. Built largely of the same stuff as previous albums ‚Äî percussion that has the force of weather events, and great, snaking rivers of melody carving through canyon walls of guitar ‚Äî this record also finds places to introduce some muted electronic elements; never in a way that radically alters the band‚Äôs now-signature sound, but certainly in ways that complement and tweak it in subtle ways, surely make long-term listeners to EitS prick up their ears. My favourite of the record‚Äôs tracks is a toss-up between the propulsive, evangelic currant of ‚ÄòTangle Formations‚Äô, and the darker, Basinski-referencing first single ‚ÄòDisintegration Anxiety‚Äô. Nothing here is going to change anyone‚Äôs mind about the band (I wonder sometimes whether their rapturous live show might have the power to do so), but it is a welcome thing to find a band 17 years on from their formation still making compelling music that is very much their own.  ### 4. Bloc Party ‚Äî *Hymns* In some respects the most quietly revolutionary album of 2016. After a four year break following *Intimacy* it didn‚Äôt feel like a sure thing that we‚Äôd see another Bloc Party album. And even after the successes of *Four* (2012) the four year break that followed that album had a ring of finality about it. In some bands (even four-pieces) it would be no big thing to replace the drummer and bassist; not so with Bloc Party, where Matt Tong and Gordon Moakes‚Äôs contributions were always beyond the average. Sure enough *Hymns* isn‚Äôt showcase to the same kind of frenetic, self-perpetuating drum patterns as previous of the band‚Äôs albums, and there are perhaps fewer truly memorable bass lines. However, that is at least in part down to the way in which the band‚Äôs sound has reconfigured itself here. The tempos are often more forgiving (certainly than was the case on *Four*), there is greater emphasis on Kele‚Äôs voice (with which he seems to feel increasingly comfortable). What remains is songwriting split fairly evenly between confessional and social commentary, and equally strong at each. But the textures that are new to Bloc Party offer an opportunity to reach into new spaces: the unsettled oddness of ‚ÄòDifferent Drugs‚Äô; the romantic swell of ‚ÄòMy True Name‚Äô undercut by a haunting choral vocal; the proto-gospel euphoria of ‚ÄòOnly He Can Heal Me‚Äô, which takes its place amongst the band‚Äôs best tracks. I remain happy just to have this band around, I‚Äôm always excited to see what Bloc Party do next, and for the first time I don‚Äôt really have a good idea what it might sound like.  ### 3. Elohim ‚Äî *Elohim* Elohim was the discovery of 2016 for me, and several months on this record remains just as alluring and confounding as when I first ran across it. Opener ‚ÄòSensations‚Äô is all you need in order to know whether this will be a record for you; it hooked me after a single verse and chorus and hasn‚Äôt let go since. Poppier than Bat for Lashes and less angular than Grimes, this is still defiantly odd alt-pop music and with a dark edge that‚Äôs reflected in the performer‚Äôs penchant for wearing masks onstage and in her videos. (It‚Äôs worth mentioning that one of Elohim‚Äôs strongest tracks from 2016 ‚Äî‚ÄôHallucinations‚Äô ‚Äîisn‚Äôt on this album, but was released on a subsequent EP and is also accompanied by perhaps my favourite (single-track) music video of the year.) ‚ÄòShe Talks Too Much‚Äô is winking and a little giddy; ‚ÄòXanax‚Äô is aptly washed out and dreamlike, and feature‚Äôs one of 2016‚Äôs most memorable refrains (‚Äúevery day of my day of my day of my life‚Äù); ‚ÄòGuts‚Äô, though, squeaks into the album-highlight spot by somehow channeling both Robyn and Jim Guthrie. Singular but all the more magnetic for it, I couldn‚Äôt get enough of this.  ### 2. Rihanna ‚Äî *ANTI* As I wrote above in relation to Beyonc√©, despite a set of jewel-perfect singles I had not previously thought of Rihanna as an album artist. Like the rest of the world then (if for different reasons), I wasn‚Äôt prepared for *ANTI*. Long in coming though it has been, when the album finally arrived at the tail end of the kind of wilfully obfuscatory social-media marketing campaign that is seemingly now de rigueur (see also *The Life of Pablo*, *Views*, *Lemonade*, *Blond(e)*) the reaction from music press and listening public alike was a near- universal: ‚Äòwha?‚Äô. I lost track of the number of times people pointed out there was no ‚ÄòUmbrella‚Äô here, no ‚ÄòTake a Bow‚Äô or ‚ÄòOnly Girl‚Äô, as though a pop artist is expected to work to a quota of one banger per x number of other songs, with which they can do what they like. On *ANTI* Rihanna is plainly not interested in working to the one-for-me-one-for-the-dancefloor model. Instead she‚Äôs happy to be flirtatious and demanding on ‚ÄòWork‚Äô, coy on ‚ÄòKiss it Better‚Äô, and somewhat terrifying on ‚ÄòNeeded Me‚Äô, all the while delivering flawless vocal performances (seriously, ‚ÄòHigher‚Äô alone remains near-unbelievable after 100+ listens) over the top of immaculate, captivating beats. If you need something else you can go listen to those Calvin Harris tracks that she makes into pop masterpieces just by showing up. I‚Äôll be here swaying to ‚ÄòLove on the Brain‚Äô or crying to ‚ÄòClose to You‚Äô.  ### 1. Radiohead ‚Äî *A Moon Shaped Pool* I honestly don‚Äôt know where to start when talking about Radiohead. Perhaps it‚Äôs enough to say that I‚Äôve been on a quest for about 10 years to find anyone who makes music that sounds anything like theirs, and I haven‚Äôt come up with anything. Radiohead, at this point, is a one-band genre, but one that shifts and re-colours itself to always remain stunningly relevant and new-seeming. *A Moon Shaped Pool* isn‚Äôt so much an album of music as it is the latest dispatch in the cataloguing of the British liberal psyche: this is who we are at the moment, and how we feel, it seems to say. Still concerned about our lonelinesses and our failures, still preoccupied with finding a place in the world, but also increasingly overwhelmed by larger events, and frightened by the evanescence of hope. Arcade Fire do voice and hope, and are similarly documentarian; Liars do complex and dense layers of confused feeling; Sigur Ros do rapture; Explosions in the Sky do overwhelm and exorcism‚Ä¶ only Radiohead consistently find a way to put all of those components together, and always in beautiful new ways that continue to awe me. We‚Äôre so very lucky to have them. ‚èé Return to the [index of lists](/thelists)

items.title: A Simple Sentence
items.content_html:
Michael Ondaatje‚Äôs novel In The Skin of a Lion (1987) is full of exquisite detail, used in bringing to life some beautifully crafted characters and extraordinary events. It‚Äôs a book that moves from a brilliantly rendered Canadian river to a palatial waterworks plant via a stolen yacht, a mushroom factory, a prison and a house aflame. Ondaatje‚Äôs command of language is absolute; no matter how unlikely the situation he does not fall into cartoonishness, and even though some of his more colourful characters risk caricature, he expertly keeps them from crossing that line. And yet for all this, the one sentence of the novel that caught me most off guard is simple and declarative, possessed of some less ornate form of the magic the author uses elsewhere. I stopped, copied the sentence out onto a notepad and stared at it for a while.1

The waitress with the tattoo gave him his coffee.

What was it about these nine words that had stopped me in my tracks? My immediate impression of the sentence was of its crystalline clarity; it gives the reader an action perfectly, and more than that it gives us a scene. We have been introduced to this waitress a couple of chapters before. She was the subject of four paragraphs in which Ondaatje gives us his protagonist‚Äôs impressions of her: she is silent, adept at her job, complete in and of herself, and harmoniously integrated with her workplace. She is the subject of Patrick‚Äôs somewhat melancholy attention only briefly on the page, though she represents something important to him: a part of his routine. The waitress‚Äôs constancy is reassuring to Patrick amid the absences and uncertainties elsewhere in his life. Her tattoo is mentioned only briefly, its primary purpose here being to serve as a hint of personal detail, enough to allow for the possibility that away from the Thompson Grill she leads a rich, unknowable life.

All that is required for Ondaatje to reprise those feelings a dozen pages later is the presence of this detail. He includes mention of the tattoo in the waitress‚Äôs one sentence appearance and all of Patrick‚Äôs feelings about what she represents arise again in the reader‚Äôs mind. It is a powerful trick that works so subtly in bringing extra colour to the later passage that the reader may not even be aware of it.

As well as performing this tonal function the sentence is also appealing because it’s structurally immaculate. There are the paired Ws of ‚Äòwaitress‚Äô and ‚Äòwith‚Äô, neatly mirrored by the symmetrically placed paired Hs of ‚Äòhim‚Äô and ‚Äòhis‚Äô. Then there is the cute match of paired consonants and paired vowels that occurs in both ‚Äòtattoo‚Äô and ‚Äòcoffee‚Äô. It looks great on the page, and gives the reader the little thrill of that elongated vowel sound at the middle and end of the sentence: ‚Äòoo‚Äô, ‚Äòee‚Äô.

And what about that word ‚Äòtattoo‚Äô? It‚Äôs the most unusual of the nine; the most exotic sounding; the most unlikely: just three Ts and a couple of vowels. Ondaatje has placed it dead center in terms of both word and syllable count, lending it a nice primacy. As it completes the description of the waitress it also marks a natural pause when read, separating the sentence into two pieces of seven and five syllables respectively. Coupled with this, the fact that the stress falls on the first syllable of each of the disyllabic words and that they are preceded by one, two and three monosyllabic words respectively, gives the sentence real rhythm. The staccato triplet of ‚Äògave him his‚Äô after the natural pause propels the reader towards the end of the sentence and that second elongated vowel sound.

It‚Äôs wonderful, poetic writing: a simple, finely crafted piece of description that has emotional colour to it and is rhythmically pleasing to the reader‚Äôs mind.

  1. The sentence in question is on page 128 of the 1988 Picador edition. ↩︎

items.title: Ta-Nehisi Coates ‚Äî Between the World and Me (2016)
items.content_html:
This book, which takes the form of an open letter from author Ta-Nehisi Coates to his young son, is without equivocation the most beautifully written non-fiction work I‚Äôve read in a decade. Unfailingly insightful in its dissection of troubling facts, as well as in the explication of the depth of feeling experienced as a direct result of those same facts, Coates‚Äôs voice presents hard emotional truths with peerless clarity and directness.

Much of the power of the work is derived from the author‚Äôs ability to find a way of viewing the universal through the lens of the intensely personal. The bridging of this dichotomy is exemplified in the fact that the text‚Äôs argument is centred not on something as intangible as the concept of ‘Liberty’ but on the more concrete half of the habeas corpus equation: the body. Coates returns time and again to the effects upon the black body of the rules, systems, histories, and environments he examines. No injustice is so abstract that it cannot be characterised‚Äîat least partially‚Äîby way of its effects upon the body. And no system can remain entirely impersonal when it is considered in relation to its effects upon the person.

Coates' interrogation succeeds primarily in the building of his argument fourth-dimensionally: the construction of a palimpsest which brings into focus the contemporary results of historic injustices. He calls out causal connections where they are too often forgotten or denied, and instructs the reader in the re-framing of slavery not as a discrete period of the American story but as part of a multi-generational and multi-national narrative; part of the narrative of capitalism; part of the narrative of “progress” in the first world; a colossal human endeavour with real and lasting effects in the present day. Here too Coates takes on the task of navigating between talk of people and talk of institutions. His gift is in relating one to the other: a conglomerate nothing more than an amalgamation of numerous individuals; individuals peculiarly susceptible to the unique power of collectives, and both in thrall to their inheritance of history’s lessons and codes.

That Coates has chosen to write this letter to his son as an open one is a gift to us; it‚Äôs our privilege to read it. I could not help but read it partly as a continuation of the autobiographical project in the vein of Narrative of the Life of Frederick Douglass, an American Slave (1845) and Richard Wright’s Black Boy (1945) (with which it shares interesting considerations of the authors‚Äô contemporary Chicago, and of their atheism). However, there is something immediate and important in reading a record of one‚Äôs own time and recognising in it the truth of the injustices of which it speaks.

The bridging of this dichotomy is exemplified in the fact that the text‚Äôs argument is centred not on something as intangible as the concept of 'Liberty' but on the more concrete half of the *habeas corpus* equation: the body. items.title: The List 2015
items.content_html:
At the end of each year I make a list of the twenty albums I enjoyed the most. To be eligible, a record has to be of album length (at least ~30 mins), and contain entirely (or almost entirely) new material; live albums, cover records, and compilations are ineligible.

20. The Necks ‚Äî Vertigo

Kicked off in 2006 when I fell hard for Chemist, and continuing through a dalliance with the peerless Silverwater (2009) as well as an unforgettable Barbican live performance, my love affair with The Necks continues. There have been a few releases in between, but the 44 minutes of Vertigo‚Äôs single track have been the first to stick firmly in my mind and find me consistently playing a Necks release in a little while.

If you‚Äôre familiar with the band‚Äôs sound this is exactly what you‚Äôd expect, and if you‚Äôre not it‚Äôs very difficult to describe. The tags you‚Äôd apply to it‚Äî‚Äôimprovised‚Äô & ‚Äòjazz‚Äô chief amongst them‚Äîare useful to a point, but not necessarily indicative of just how successfully this trio create a singular-feeling music: unrepeatable and yet entirely consistent in terms of the levels of interest and intrigue it sustains. All of which makes it even less palatable that I was in London on the final night of their CafeÃÅ Oto residency and did not manage to secure a ticket!

19. Battles ‚Äî La Di Da Di

When the new Battles line-up dropped Dross Glop in 2012, five years on and one member down from the glorious debut Mirrored (2007) I was super-excited, and then ‚Äî once the sugar rush had abated ‚Äî a little disappointed with the result. The album had its moments, but the loss of Tyondai Braxton was notable (indeed, in retrospect, Braxton‚Äôs solo album Central Market (2009) was the stronger post-Mirrored output). It‚Äôs gratifying then to find Battles, a couple of years into the new lineup, genuinely returned to their full strength. Opener here ‚ÄòThe Yabba‚Äô (the track titles make as little sense as ever) is as strong as anything on the debut; both ‚ÄòDot Net‚Äô and ‚ÄòFF Bada‚Äô repurpose drum patterns familiar from that first record but find new and inventive ways to use them - woven in with an instrumental palate that has the strange honour of now feeling totally familiar as well as distinctly off-kilter.

There‚Äôs certainly the odd moment when you wonder whether a line has been crossed (such as on the impenetrable opening minute of ‘Tricentennial‚Äô) but those can be waived in light of how good it is to hear this band back to their endlessly inventive best.

18. Florence + The Machine ‚Äî How Big, How Blue, How Beautiful

I haven‚Äôt paid all that much attention to Florence Welch since debut album Lungs arrived alongside debuts from Little Boots & La Roux in 2009. It was ‚ÄòBulletproof‚Äô & ‚ÄòIn For The Kill‚Äô from the latter that stuck with me that year, and then all three artists kind of faded from view for me.

After an underwhelming return by La Roux last year, it comes as a welcome surprise that F+TM‚Äôs record really got to me this time around. I read a review at the time that pointed out the symbolic importance of Welch‚Äôs facing forward on the album cover for the first time. And indeed this does feel like a more directly addressed, more personal set of songs. Less obtuse, adorned with less in the way of theatrics, the record embraces naked emotionality as its throughline. There are certainly poetic flourishes to the lyrics, and the album isn‚Äôt without bombast (‚ÄòQueen of Peace‚Äô rises and blooms like a firework display), but it feels somehow more personal than both the artist‚Äôs previous output and that of the majority of her contemporaries.

It should be mentioned also, that the 4-minute white rapids journey of opener ‚ÄòShip to Wreck‚Äô is quite possibly the best song I heard all year.

17. Squarepusher ‚Äî Damogen Furies

Over a 20+ year career I‚Äôve payed far too little attention to Squarepusher. The closest I got previously was a dip into 2010‚Äôs Shobaleader One: d‚ÄôDemonstrator - itself a kind of spin-off album featuring an expanded lineup. Damogen Furies is my first exposure to Squarepusher-prime, and it‚Äôs left me a little shaken but thrilled and hungry for more. Comprising a host of somewhat raw-sounding electronica elements, settled in a bed of off-kilter, low wind instruments, or 16-bit era videogame chiptune soundscapes, the overall tone of the album is somewhere between menacing and schizophrenic ‚Äî not dissimilar to Reznor‚Äôs OST for The Girl With The Dragon Tattoo.

At its most frenetic the drum patterning walks a line between highly measured and almost-freeform jazz, ricocheting all over the map and pulling the melodies into any number of new, convoluted forms. (One of my favourite examples of this is once ‚ÄòBaltang Ort‚Äô gets past the 4.30 mark and loses its composure a bit; that last minute is insane.) It‚Äôs a remarkable achievement to make something so mechanical seem at the same time organic - responsive to shifts in the music‚Äôs mood.

16. Will Butler ‚Äî Policy

Will Butler, here, has the same thing going for him as going against him: his membership of Arcade Fire. It‚Äôs doubtful ‚Äî or at least significantly less likely ‚Äî that I would have picked up this record without that background, and yet it comes freighted with a baggage that is entirely unfair. What Butler has produced is nothing more and nothing less than a collection of simple songs. Each one has an emotional directness familiar to listeners of his previous works, and they move between valences with aplomb. ‚ÄòFinish What I Started‚Äô is a two-minute plea from the heart, and then it‚Äôs straight into ‚ÄòSon of God‚Äô: something close to an understated call for revolution.

There‚Äôs a smattering of multi-instrumentalism, but it sounds more like one man jumping from piano to keyboard to guitar, and less like the glorious, polychromatic racket that the collective of which he‚Äôs an integral part are capable of building. There‚Äôs also the nagging fact of how close Will‚Äôs voice is to that of brother Win. In a year without an Arcade Fire album this was a welcome dose of some watered-down substitute. That‚Äôs a very unfair thing to say about a pretty great album of alt-pop songs, but it was the feeling I couldn‚Äôt shake on the many occasions I listened to it. Sorry Will.

15. Wolf Alice ‚Äî My Love is Cool

The list of bands I listened to religiously in the mid-to-late 90s and early 2000s that are obvious influences on Wolf Alice is long. And there‚Äôs no effort made to disguise that here, on an album that feels both a little familiar and oddly quaint in its delivery of a 20+ year old sound. Opener ‚ÄòTurn to Dust‚Äô is as pretty as it is alluring, with just a hint of sadness enough to make you wonder what other colours the band will paint with. It‚Äôs the sort of effortless conjuring of mood that Laura Marling displayed time and again on her first couple of albums. When, after just over 3 minutes, the album shifts into ‚ÄòBros‚Äô, the listener is assured that they‚Äôre in safe hands; I certainly didn‚Äôt hear a prettier straight-ahead, guitar-led pop song this year - so simple in its construction, yet executed beautifully enough to bring a tear to my eye on several listens.

I‚Äôm left with questions about what the future holds for Wolf Alice: another collection of easygoing pop-rock singalongs that risks diminishing returns, or the temptation to risk something that may be outside their comfort zone? For now though, we have a really solid debut that does one thing very well indeed.

14. Fort Romeau ‚Äî Insides

I‚Äôd made the decision before the start of the year to listen to every 2015 release that Ghostly International put out, so ‚Äì even if this hadn‚Äôt come recommended by Kieran Hebden ‚Äî I would have run across it eventually.

It‚Äôs easy to see why the man behind Four Tet likes what fellow Brit Mike Greene is doing here: it occupies largely the same space as Hebden‚Äôs own Rounds (2003): a kind of warm, comfortable, trancelike feeling somewhere between early morning tiredness and lazy sunbeam comfort. There are denser moments, such as the bass-driven ‚ÄòAll I Want‚Äô, but they are swells upon an otherwise even-tempered expanse of musical ocean.

(This ended up being my favourite eligible Ghostly release for the year, though Shigeto‚Äôs Intermission EP, would be way up there if it was a little longer than 6 tracks & ~20 minutes.)

13. Ibeyi ‚Äî Ibeyi

The two voices at the heart of Ibeyi‚Äôs self-titled debut are almost indistinguishable, belonging as they do to twins: Naomi & Lisa-KaindeÃÅ DiÃÅaz. Both are light, playful, and soulful, painting flowing lines over beds of minimal piano and simple beats. At times they‚Äôre also haunting, used to great effect in mirroring or weaving in and out of each other, such as on album highlight ‚ÄòRiver‚Äô where they hold a kind of conversation amid the waves of their own background harmonising.

It no doubt helps that I first heard this record when we were in Copenhagen in February, and it‚Äôs linked in my mind with a great week we spent out there. The album‚Äôs sonic warmth conjures for me, every time, the warmth of the apartment we were staying in, and to which we returned after days walking in biting cold.

12. Nils Frahm ‚Äî Solo

In much the same way that Ghostly International started to colonise great swathes of my listening time a couple of years ago, London-based label Erased Tapes have made a huge impact for me recently: I got a lot of listening out of Kiasmos‚Äôs self-titled LP last year; A Winged Victory for the Sullen provided me with an unforgettable live experience in a Danish church this February… and there‚Äôs another ET artist elsewhere on this list. Hence it‚Äôs fitting that I came to Frahm via labelmate OÃÅlafur Arnalds, a kindred spirit and sometime collaborator (they put out an EP together this year actually, which ‚Äî though ineligible for The List ‚Äî is a recommended listen also).

In terms of the album itself ‚Äî a collection of masterfully constructed piano pieces ‚Äîthere‚Äôs not too much to say. There is some variation: the slightness of ‚ÄòChant‚Äô and the swell of ‚ÄòWall‚Äô, but the album is best considered of a piece, and the mood it evokes is singular. The Pitchfork review phrased it this way:

“[I]t‚Äôs spare, it‚Äôs lyrical, it‚Äôs generally quiet, and it‚Äôs very pretty. Your mileage will vary based on whether that is enough.‚Äù

For me, it was, easily. On several occasions this year it was precisely the record I needed, and to which I turned when nothing else would do.

11. The Sidekicks ‚Äî Runners in the Nerved World

I‚Äôm not sure how I came to listen to this; a January release that has stuck around tenaciously to claim a spot on The List, and has done so by charm more than anything else. Touchstones here are bands like The Shins and Saves the Day, and this record firmly filled the same spot this year as Local Natives‚Äô Hummingbird a couple of years ago: the best example that happened to cross into my awareness of a musical style far more prevalent on these lists in the early 2000s and appearing with increasing rarity since. Nevertheless this is the real thing and faithfully delivered. Steve Ciolek‚Äôs voice is an empathetic through-line with a range between falsetto fragility and convincing moments of emotional conviction.

‘Blissfield, MI‚Äô is the record‚Äôs high point, though its driving bravado is something of an outlier on an album primarily comprising prettier pop-rock. The track also contains the album‚Äôs best lyric; the kind of glimpse into personal emotional-geography that late ‚Äò90s / early ‚Äô00s emo at its best did so well:

I feel like how the Bulls felt in 1993
I feel like how my head felt the last time you kissed me

10. Shamir ‚Äî Ratchet

Another debut album for The List, and another distinct vocal - Shamir Bailey‚Äôs performance is by turns fragile (in the manner of a Michael Jackson ballad), cocky, or occasionally fierce. Low-key opener ‚ÄòVegas‚Äô keys the listener into a couple of the record‚Äôs themes ‚Äî sin, pleasure ‚Äî but is quickly undercut in a piece of genius sequencing by ‚ÄòMake A Scene‚Äô: a none-more-pop chant littered with unidentifiable sound effects, something that sounds distinctly like cow-bell, and a vaulting laser effect that draws the listener‚Äôs ear up and over Bailey‚Äôs falsetto.

There are plenty of catchy ‚Äî if insubstantial ‚Äî pleasures on offer, but the best track on the album is inarguably ‚ÄòOn The Regular‚Äô, also probably 2015‚Äôs most infectious song. Its blend of lightness, self-assurance, and touches of thematic darkness are a good microcosm of the album in general. In the final analysis though, it was Shamir‚Äôs ear for a hook and the wit of his lyrics that brought me back to this time and again.

9. Purity Ring ‚Äî Another Eternity

For whatever reason Purity Ring‚Äôs debut (Shrines (2012)) didn‚Äôt make it onto my radar, and my introduction to the band came when I asked Siri to identify a song which turned out to be ‚ÄòBodyache‚Äô in a coffee shop this summer. Not long after that I was hooked on an album delicately balancing bright, dense synths and a similarly-toned female vocal. There are a few rhythm & blues touches here and there (the cadence of ‚ÄòRepetition‚Äô for example), but it‚Äôs one influence among a spectrum, all blended here amongst warm synth-swaths to produce an album it‚Äôs easy to submerge yourself in and not want to emerge from.

There‚Äôs nothing even slightly revolutionary here, but it‚Äôs an album ‚Äî like Metric‚Äôs Synthetica (2012) and SBTRKT‚Äôs Wonder Where We Land (2014) ‚Äî that builds a cohesive and vibrant world of sound that pulled me in and kept me entranced.

8. Jamie xx ‚Äî In Colour

There‚Äôs something very smart about Jamie xx‚Äôs marking this solo release by calling out in the title (and album cover) the contrast to The xx‚Äôs predominantly monochrome aesthetic. That relationship is carried through to the music also, with the record feeling more expansive, more energetic, and wider-ranging than the (superb) work Jamie‚Äôs put out alongside Romy Madley Croft & Oliver Sim. Touching on the same positive-vibes club scene sound as Four Tet‚Äôs recent output, the record moves at a pace and imparts a real warmth without ever moving much beyond third gear.

Opener ‚ÄòGosh‚Äô is a cheeky statement of intent. ‚ÄôStranger in a Room‚Äô is night-driving music; traffic-lights refracted through rain music - cool in tone and soporific. ‚ÄòHold Tight‚Äô is a helter-skelter, hypnotic headphone trip. ‚ÄôObvs‚Äô even manages to make good use of one of my least-favourite instruments: the steel drum.

I got a real kick out of this collection of assorted brighter, club-electronica sounds, and it‚Äôs left me even more excited for a third LP from The xx in 2016.

7. Rival Consoles ‚Äî Howl

And here‚Äôs that other member of the Erased Tapes roster alluded to earlier. Ryan Lee West‚Äôs set of constantly shifting soundscapes put a spell on me this year. As with Squarepusher earlier in this list, this is electronic music engaged in the exploration of what happens when a pattern is disrupted, complicated, and altered. Not as fraught as the music on Damogen Furies, but just as restless, this is an album for headphones not just because of its density and intricacy, but also because of its propulsiveness. It‚Äôs music to walk to, run to, and ride rails to.

Each track is distinct, none outstay their welcome, and West knows when he‚Äôs stretched a beat to its breaking point, and thus when to move on. There‚Äôs a melancholy to some of the album‚Äôs lower tones, but elsewhere there‚Äôs a playfulness, and energy to spare (such as displayed by the shuffling brush-played drums underneath album highlight ‚ÄòLow‚Äô). Closing track ‚ÄòLooming‚Äô is perhaps the collection‚Äôs tightest package; the euphoric shivers of synth that run through it ringing out like harbingers of a sunrise.

6. Nosaj Thing ‚Äî Fated

There‚Äôs a tone and a tempo of electronica that I‚Äôve been continuously hunting since Flying Lotus‚Äôs Cosmogramma put me under its spell in 2010. Shigeto‚Äôs No Better Time Than Now satisfied the itch in 2013, and last year the role was played by Submerse‚Äôs Slow Waves; in 2015 the honour goes to the third record by Jason Chung a.k.a. Nosaj Thing.

Laid back to the point of near-horizontality, and characterised by nothing so much as a pervading sense of warmth, this is a species of electronic music that finds soul and humanity within the machines - blood in the wires. If I could pick a record of 2015 to live inside, it might well be Fated. The cover image is a simple black & white photo of Chung holding up a fork by the tines, a butter knife suspended from it at 6 o‚Äôclock, pulled by gravity and held by some quirk of magnetism. The album somehow feels the same: a long, suspended moment, slightly magical, in tune with chance. For whatever reason I think of this sub-category as liminal electronica - and, considering that that‚Äôs a musical genre that doesn‚Äôt exist outside of my head, Chung does a remarkable job of getting it just right.

5. Metric ‚Äî Pagans in Vegas

This album‚Äôs a disappointment within the limited framework of comparison to its predecessor: the flawless Synthetica (2012). Still present are the sure-footedly executed balance of pop sensibilities and underlying electro menace, the flawless understanding of what a key-change or lyrical twist can accomplish, and the sense of a band exploring every corner of their alt-electro-synth-pop palate.

When the pace dipped I found myself losing interest just a little ‚Äî something that never happened throughout Synthetica ‚Äî and overall the quality is merely outstanding rather than genre-defining. There are exceptions: the effervescent ‚ÄòThe Shade‚Äô, and the sly, shifting ‚ÄôCascades‚Äô are every bit as good as I‚Äôd come to expect from Metric. In the final analysis this is a really solid continuation of the band‚Äôs sound, somewhat unfairly made to feel slight in comparison to a vastly superior previous album. And yet, these things must be put in context and this place in the top five is richly deserved.

4. Toro y Moi ‚Äî What For?

This is an album possessed of both a distinct sense of the mood it wants to invoke, and also a sense of humour about the single-mindedness with which it sets about the task. Smart, effortlessly cool, and rendered with a fresh clarity, the soul influences are worn as a badge of honour whilst the mismatch of laid-back delivery and sometimes heavier content is endlessly compelling.

The vocals are liberally treated with effects, but its done with such a holistic sense of the album‚Äôs sonic world that instead of risking distraction it instead echoes the warm distortion of the guitars, and serves to deepen the rich, swaying textures of the lower- tempo tracks. When the pace picks up on tracks like ‚ÄòEmpty Nesters‚Äô it takes the edge off the more cutting lyrics (‚ÄúCall Mom & Dad because their nest is empty, and so are you‚Äù) and keeps the mood light. Aaron Gold‚Äôs drums perform the same trick throughout, keeping things light and moving swiftly.

The record‚Äôs finest moment comes in the shape of ‚ÄòSpell It Out‚Äô: a three-minute sideswipe that comes off like a simultaneous slap and kiss to the cheek.

3. Grimes ‚Äî Art Angels

Rumour has it that after the unexpected level of attention garnered by 2012‚Äôs Visions, Clare Boucher made an album‚Äôs worth of material ‚Äî including ill-conceived single release ‚ÄôGo‚Äô ‚Äî before scrapping the whole thing and starting again. If true it‚Äôs perhaps indicative of how seriously Boucher sees the task of representing herself truthfully through her art in the glare of intensified media interest.

She starts, simply, on the introductory ‚ÄòLaughing and Not Being Normal‚Äô, by reminding us that she has a spectacular voice, sometimes overlooked in commentary that focusses on her layering techniques and beat-making. From there she progresses into the achingly-beautiful ‚ÄòCalifornia‚Äô, which contains perhaps Grimes‚Äôs clearest method statement: “I love this music / It sounds just like my soul”. And so unfolds a record democratic in its tastes, eclectic in its tone and tempo, and yet singularly focussed on the task of pure artistic expression. Whatever reception the release received it seems clear that the most important thing to the artist here was making a record she was happy with. And so she indulges every whim for the duration that it retains her attention: sweetness, savagery, choral melody, multi-layered spiral-staircase beats… and on.

‚ÄòKill V. Maim‚Äô is the album‚Äôs centrepiece, a crucible for all this particularly brilliant form of compositional madness, and ‚Äî by some miracle ‚Äî one of the best synth-pop anthems since Robyn‚Äôs Body Talk five years ago.

2. Sleater-Kinney ‚Äî No Cities to Love

Where did this come from?

I had a slight familiarity with S-K‚Äôs previous album: The Woods (2005), but that was a decade ago, and prior to that ‚Äî in the pre-streaming / pre-download era ‚Äî they‚Äôd never really crossed my radar other than as mentions in articles analysing the impact of grunge, listed alongside Belly and Sonic Youth, and a dozen other bands I never really connected with for whatever reason. So it comes as something of a surprise that I fell so hard for this album, having tuned in after hearing it compared to Wild Flag‚Äôs 2011 debut. (It‚Äôs pretty funny how clearly I had that influence the wrong way around.) Released not three weeks into the year it was immediately obvious that this album would stick around for a place on The List. ‚ÄòPrice Tag‚Äô might be the best opening track of any album this year, and like ‚ÄòSurface Envy‚Äô, ‚ÄòA New Wave‚Äô and… well, most of the album, it‚Äôs a ~3-minute masterpiece of concentrated energy driving forward a smart lyric. This collection of songs is near bursting at the seams with ideas, energy and new directionality; it‚Äôs possible that after 10 years away the three members of Sleater-Kinney came back together with so many ideas that No Cities to Love represents the finest 10 tracks of dozens recorded. Whatever the case, they‚Äôve produced a near-perfect rock album with just the right levels of enthusiasm, menace, sadness, and empowering anger. The title track deserves special mention for balancing these elements particularly flawlessly, whilst showcasing the poppy lightness that keeps the whole record effervescing.

1. Chvrches ‚Äî Every Open Eye

Chvrches‚Äô debut album reached number 4 on my 2013 list and so it‚Äôs fitting that this record, which represents a simultaneous strengthening and deepening of their sound, claims a higher spot. In truth the top three here came together pretty late. With Sleater-Kinney having been in pole position since release in Jan, and the Grimes LP not arriving until fairly late in the year, there was a bunch of late-in-the-day shuffling going on.

The Bones of What You Believe was one of those records that I loved but which left me with questions as to how it would be followed up. The answer Chvrches have elected to go with ‚Äî perhaps wisely ‚Äî is to double down on what they‚Äôre indisputably great at: a propulsive strain of synth-pop, underpinned by a strong rhythm section, and shot through with a hint of darkness. Lauren Mayberry‚Äôs voice remains the band‚Äôs secret weapon: sometimes fragile-seeming and bruised, it is uniquely suited to making anthemic vocals feel tender and personal. It is not Hayley Williams‚Äôs absolute siren of a vocal style, but matches it for its ability to make the synaptic connection between head and heart.

The album is near-flawless; even the questionable choice to leave vocals to Martin Doherty on ‘High Enough to Carry You Over‚Äô shifts the album temporarily into a slightly different tone, following which ‚ÄòEmpty Threat‚Äô (the record‚Äôs poppiest moment) feels something like the lifting of a headache or a low mood.

Perhaps the album‚Äôs signal moment comes just over two minutes into ‚ÄòClearest Blue‚Äô, when the tender build-up crescendos into a euphoric dance beat. Somehow the fact that it resembles nothing more closely than The Pet Shop Boys does nothing to dilute the sheer joy of it.

It‚Äôs telling that album number two has pushed Chvrches straight to the top of my list of acts to see live ASAP. Bright, sweet, imbued with boundless energy, and yet knowing and highly polished, this record is a confection but one over which I carry no guilt for adoring.
