The tags you‚Äôd apply to it‚Äî‚Äôimprovised‚Äô & ‚Äòjazz‚Äô chief amongst them‚Äîare useful to a point, but not necessarily indicative of just how successfully this trio create a singular-feeling music: unrepeatable and yet entirely consistent in terms of the levels of interest and intrigue it sustains. All of which makes it even less palatable that I was in London on the final night of their CafeÃÅ Oto residency and did not manage to secure a ticket! ### 19. Battles ‚Äî *La Di Da Di* When the new Battles line-up dropped *Dross Glop* in 2012, five years on and one member down from the glorious debut *Mirrored* (2007) I was super-excited, and then ‚Äî once the sugar rush had abated ‚Äî a little disappointed with the result. The album had its moments, but the loss of Tyondai Braxton was notable (indeed, in retrospect, Braxton‚Äôs solo album *Central Market* (2009) was the stronger post-*Mirrored* output). It‚Äôs gratifying then to find Battles, a couple of years into the new lineup, genuinely returned to their full strength. Opener here ‚ÄòThe Yabba‚Äô (the track titles make as little sense as ever) is as strong as anything on the debut; both ‚ÄòDot Net‚Äô and ‚ÄòFF Bada‚Äô repurpose drum patterns familiar from that first record but find new and inventive ways to use them - woven in with an instrumental palate that has the strange honour of now feeling totally familiar as well as distinctly off-kilter. There‚Äôs certainly the odd moment when you wonder whether a line has been crossed (such as on the impenetrable opening minute of 'Tricentennial‚Äô) but those can be waived in light of how good it is to hear this band back to their endlessly inventive best. ### 18. Florence + The Machine ‚Äî *How Big, How Blue, How Beautiful* I haven‚Äôt paid all that much attention to Florence Welch since debut album *Lungs* arrived alongside debuts from Little Boots & La Roux in 2009. It was ‚ÄòBulletproof‚Äô & ‚ÄòIn For The Kill‚Äô from the latter that stuck with me that year, and then all three artists kind of faded from view for me. After an underwhelming return by La Roux last year, it comes as a welcome surprise that F+TM‚Äôs record really got to me this time around. I read a review at the time that pointed out the symbolic importance of Welch‚Äôs facing forward on the album cover for the first time. And indeed this does feel like a more directly addressed, more personal set of songs. Less obtuse, adorned with less in the way of theatrics, the record embraces naked emotionality as its throughline. There are certainly poetic flourishes to the lyrics, and the album isn‚Äôt without bombast (‚ÄòQueen of Peace‚Äô rises and blooms like a firework display), but it feels somehow more personal than both the artist‚Äôs previous output and that of the majority of her contemporaries. It should be mentioned also, that the 4-minute white rapids journey of opener ‚ÄòShip to Wreck‚Äô is quite possibly the best song I heard all year. ### 17. Squarepusher ‚Äî *Damogen Furies* Over a 20+ year career I‚Äôve payed far too little attention to Squarepusher. The closest I got previously was a dip into 2010‚Äôs Shobaleader One: *d‚ÄôDemonstrator* - itself a kind of spin-off album featuring an expanded lineup. *Damogen Furies* is my first exposure to Squarepusher-prime, and it‚Äôs left me a little shaken but thrilled and hungry for more. Comprising a host of somewhat raw-sounding electronica elements, settled in a bed of off-kilter, low wind instruments, or 16-bit era videogame chiptune soundscapes, the overall tone of the album is somewhere between menacing and schizophrenic ‚Äî not dissimilar to Reznor‚Äôs OST for *The Girl With The Dragon Tattoo*. At its most frenetic the drum patterning walks a line between highly measured and almost-freeform jazz, ricocheting all over the map and pulling the melodies into any number of new, convoluted forms. (One of my favourite examples of this is once ‚ÄòBaltang Ort‚Äô gets past the 4.30 mark and loses its composure a bit; that last minute is insane.) It‚Äôs a remarkable achievement to make something so mechanical seem at the same time organic - responsive to shifts in the music‚Äôs mood. ### 16. Will Butler ‚Äî *Policy* Will Butler, here, has the same thing going for him as going against him: his membership of Arcade Fire. It‚Äôs doubtful ‚Äî or at least significantly less likely ‚Äî that I would have picked up this record without that background, and yet it comes freighted with a baggage that is entirely unfair. What Butler has produced is nothing more and nothing less than a collection of simple songs. Each one has an emotional directness familiar to listeners of his previous works, and they move between valences with aplomb. ‚ÄòFinish What I Started‚Äô is a two-minute plea from the heart, and then it‚Äôs straight into ‚ÄòSon of God‚Äô: something close to an understated call for revolution. There‚Äôs a smattering of multi-instrumentalism, but it sounds more like one man jumping from piano to keyboard to guitar, and less like the glorious, polychromatic racket that the collective of which he‚Äôs an integral part are capable of building. There‚Äôs also the nagging fact of how close Will‚Äôs voice is to that of brother Win. In a year without an Arcade Fire album this was a welcome dose of some watered-down substitute. That‚Äôs a very unfair thing to say about a pretty great album of alt-pop songs, but it was the feeling I couldn‚Äôt shake on the many occasions I listened to it. Sorry Will. ### 15. Wolf Alice ‚Äî *My Love is Cool* The list of bands I listened to religiously in the mid-to-late 90s and early 2000s that are obvious influences on Wolf Alice is long. And there‚Äôs no effort made to disguise that here, on an album that feels both a little familiar and oddly quaint in its delivery of a 20+ year old sound. Opener ‚ÄòTurn to Dust‚Äô is as pretty as it is alluring, with just a hint of sadness enough to make you wonder what other colours the band will paint with. It‚Äôs the sort of effortless conjuring of mood that Laura Marling displayed time and again on her first couple of albums. When, after just over 3 minutes, the album shifts into ‚ÄòBros‚Äô, the listener is assured that they‚Äôre in safe hands; I certainly didn‚Äôt hear a prettier straight-ahead, guitar-led pop song this year - so simple in its construction, yet executed beautifully enough to bring a tear to my eye on several listens. I‚Äôm left with questions about what the future holds for Wolf Alice: another collection of easygoing pop-rock singalongs that risks diminishing returns, or the temptation to risk something that may be outside their comfort zone? For now though, we have a really solid debut that does one thing very well indeed. ### 14. Fort Romeau ‚Äî *Insides* I‚Äôd made the decision before the start of the year to listen to every 2015 release that Ghostly International put out, so ‚Äì even if this hadn‚Äôt come recommended by Kieran Hebden ‚Äî I would have run across it eventually. It‚Äôs easy to see why the man behind Four Tet likes what fellow Brit Mike Greene is doing here: it occupies largely the same space as Hebden‚Äôs own *Rounds* (2003): a kind of warm, comfortable, trancelike feeling somewhere between early morning tiredness and lazy sunbeam comfort. There are denser moments, such as the bass-driven ‚ÄòAll I Want‚Äô, but they are swells upon an otherwise even-tempered expanse of musical ocean. (This ended up being my favourite eligible Ghostly release for the year, though Shigeto‚Äôs *Intermission* EP, would be way up there if it was a little longer than 6 tracks & ~20 minutes.) ### 13. Ibeyi ‚Äî *Ibeyi* The two voices at the heart of Ibeyi‚Äôs self-titled debut are almost indistinguishable, belonging as they do to twins: Naomi & Lisa-KaindeÃÅ DiÃÅaz. Both are light, playful, and soulful, painting flowing lines over beds of minimal piano and simple beats. At times they‚Äôre also haunting, used to great effect in mirroring or weaving in and out of each other, such as on album highlight ‚ÄòRiver‚Äô where they hold a kind of conversation amid the waves of their own background harmonising. It no doubt helps that I first heard this record when we were in Copenhagen in February, and it‚Äôs linked in my mind with a great week we spent out there. The album‚Äôs sonic warmth conjures for me, every time, the warmth of the apartment we were staying in, and to which we returned after days walking in biting cold. ### 12. Nils Frahm ‚Äî *Solo* In much the same way that Ghostly International started to colonise great swathes of my listening time a couple of years ago, London-based label Erased Tapes have made a huge impact for me recently: I got a lot of listening out of Kiasmos‚Äôs self-titled LP last year; A Winged Victory for the Sullen provided me with an unforgettable live experience in a Danish church this February... and there‚Äôs another ET artist elsewhere on this list. Hence it‚Äôs fitting that I came to Frahm via labelmate OÃÅlafur Arnalds, a kindred spirit and sometime collaborator (they put out an EP together this year actually, which ‚Äî though ineligible for The List ‚Äî is a recommended listen also). In terms of the album itself ‚Äî a collection of masterfully constructed piano pieces ‚Äîthere‚Äôs not too much to say. There is some variation: the slightness of ‚ÄòChant‚Äô and the swell of ‚ÄòWall‚Äô, but the album is best considered of a piece, and the mood it evokes is singular. The *Pitchfork* review phrased it this way: > "[I]t‚Äôs spare, it‚Äôs lyrical, it‚Äôs generally quiet, and it‚Äôs very pretty. Your mileage will vary based on whether that is enough.‚Äù For me, it was, easily. On several occasions this year it was precisely the record I needed, and to which I turned when nothing else would do. ### 11. The Sidekicks ‚Äî *Runners in the Nerved World* I‚Äôm not sure how I came to listen to this; a January release that has stuck around tenaciously to claim a spot on The List, and has done so by charm more than anything else. Touchstones here are bands like The Shins and Saves the Day, and this record firmly filled the same spot this year as Local Natives‚Äô *Hummingbird* a couple of years ago: the best example that happened to cross into my awareness of a musical style far more prevalent on these lists in the early 2000s and appearing with increasing rarity since. Nevertheless this is the real thing and faithfully delivered. Steve Ciolek‚Äôs voice is an empathetic through-line with a range between falsetto fragility and convincing moments of emotional conviction. 'Blissfield, MI‚Äô is the record‚Äôs high point, though its driving bravado is something of an outlier on an album primarily comprising prettier pop-rock. The track also contains the album‚Äôs best lyric; the kind of glimpse into personal emotional-geography that late ‚Äò90s / early ‚Äô00s emo at its best did so well: > I feel like how the Bulls felt in 1993 > I feel like how my head felt the last time you kissed me ### 10. Shamir ‚Äî *Ratchet* Another debut album for The List, and another distinct vocal - Shamir Bailey‚Äôs performance is by turns fragile (in the manner of a Michael Jackson ballad), cocky, or occasionally fierce. Low-key opener ‚ÄòVegas‚Äô keys the listener into a couple of the record‚Äôs themes ‚Äî sin, pleasure ‚Äî but is quickly undercut in a piece of genius sequencing by ‚ÄòMake A Scene‚Äô: a none-more-pop chant littered with unidentifiable sound effects, something that sounds distinctly like cow-bell, and a vaulting laser effect that draws the listener‚Äôs ear up and over Bailey‚Äôs falsetto. There are plenty of catchy ‚Äî if insubstantial ‚Äî pleasures on offer, but the best track on the album is inarguably ‚ÄòOn The Regular‚Äô, also probably 2015‚Äôs most infectious song. Its blend of lightness, self-assurance, and touches of thematic darkness are a good microcosm of the album in general. In the final analysis though, it was Shamir‚Äôs ear for a hook and the wit of his lyrics that brought me back to this time and again. ### 9. Purity Ring ‚Äî *Another Eternity* For whatever reason Purity Ring‚Äôs debut (*Shrines* (2012)) didn‚Äôt make it onto my radar, and my introduction to the band came when I asked Siri to identify a song which turned out to be ‚ÄòBodyache‚Äô in a coffee shop this summer. Not long after that I was hooked on an album delicately balancing bright, dense synths and a similarly-toned female vocal. There are a few rhythm & blues touches here and there (the cadence of ‚ÄòRepetition‚Äô for example), but it‚Äôs one influence among a spectrum, all blended here amongst warm synth-swaths to produce an album it‚Äôs easy to submerge yourself in and not want to emerge from. There‚Äôs nothing even slightly revolutionary here, but it‚Äôs an album ‚Äî like Metric‚Äôs *Synthetica* (2012) and SBTRKT‚Äôs *Wonder Where We Land* (2014) ‚Äî that builds a cohesive and vibrant world of sound that pulled me in and kept me entranced. ### 8. Jamie xx ‚Äî *In Colour* There‚Äôs something very smart about Jamie xx‚Äôs marking this solo release by calling out in the title (and album cover) the contrast to The xx‚Äôs predominantly monochrome aesthetic. That relationship is carried through to the music also, with the record feeling more expansive, more energetic, and wider-ranging than the (superb) work Jamie‚Äôs put out alongside Romy Madley Croft & Oliver Sim. Touching on the same positive-vibes club scene sound as Four Tet‚Äôs recent output, the record moves at a pace and imparts a real warmth without ever moving much beyond third gear. Opener ‚ÄòGosh‚Äô is a cheeky statement of intent. ‚ÄôStranger in a Room‚Äô is night-driving music; traffic-lights refracted through rain music - cool in tone and soporific. ‚ÄòHold Tight‚Äô is a helter-skelter, hypnotic headphone trip. ‚ÄôObvs‚Äô even manages to make good use of one of my least-favourite instruments: the steel drum. I got a real kick out of this collection of assorted brighter, club-electronica sounds, and it‚Äôs left me even more excited for a third LP from The xx in 2016. ### 7. Rival Consoles ‚Äî *Howl* And here‚Äôs that other member of the Erased Tapes roster alluded to earlier. Ryan Lee West‚Äôs set of constantly shifting soundscapes put a spell on me this year. As with Squarepusher earlier in this list, this is electronic music engaged in the exploration of what happens when a pattern is disrupted, complicated, and altered. Not as fraught as the music on *Damogen Furies*, but just as restless, this is an album for headphones not just because of its density and intricacy, but also because of its propulsiveness. It‚Äôs music to walk to, run to, and ride rails to. Each track is distinct, none outstay their welcome, and West knows when he‚Äôs stretched a beat to its breaking point, and thus when to move on. There‚Äôs a melancholy to some of the album‚Äôs lower tones, but elsewhere there‚Äôs a playfulness, and energy to spare (such as displayed by the shuffling brush-played drums underneath album highlight ‚ÄòLow‚Äô). Closing track ‚ÄòLooming‚Äô is perhaps the collection‚Äôs tightest package; the euphoric shivers of synth that run through it ringing out like harbingers of a sunrise. ### 6. Nosaj Thing ‚Äî *Fated* There‚Äôs a tone and a tempo of electronica that I‚Äôve been continuously hunting since Flying Lotus‚Äôs *Cosmogramma* put me under its spell in 2010. Shigeto‚Äôs *No Better Time Than Now* satisfied the itch in 2013, and last year the role was played by Submerse‚Äôs *Slow Waves*; in 2015 the honour goes to the third record by Jason Chung a.k.a. Nosaj Thing. Laid back to the point of near-horizontality, and characterised by nothing so much as a pervading sense of warmth, this is a species of electronic music that finds soul and humanity within the machines - blood in the wires. If I could pick a record of 2015 to live inside, it might well be *Fated*. The cover image is a simple black & white photo of Chung holding up a fork by the tines, a butter knife suspended from it at 6 o‚Äôclock, pulled by gravity and held by some quirk of magnetism. The album somehow feels the same: a long, suspended moment, slightly magical, in tune with chance. For whatever reason I think of this sub-category as liminal electronica - and, considering that that‚Äôs a musical genre that doesn‚Äôt exist outside of my head, Chung does a remarkable job of getting it just right. ### 5. Metric ‚Äî *Pagans in Vegas* This album‚Äôs a disappointment within the limited framework of comparison to its predecessor: the flawless *Synthetica* (2012). Still present are the sure-footedly executed balance of pop sensibilities and underlying electro menace, the flawless understanding of what a key-change or lyrical twist can accomplish, and the sense of a band exploring every corner of their alt-electro-synth-pop palate. When the pace dipped I found myself losing interest just a little ‚Äî something that never happened throughout *Synthetica* ‚Äî and overall the quality is merely outstanding rather than genre-defining. There are exceptions: the effervescent ‚ÄòThe Shade‚Äô, and the sly, shifting ‚ÄôCascades‚Äô are every bit as good as I‚Äôd come to expect from Metric. In the final analysis this is a really solid continuation of the band‚Äôs sound, somewhat unfairly made to feel slight in comparison to a vastly superior previous album. And yet, these things must be put in context and this place in the top five is richly deserved. ### 4. Toro y Moi ‚Äî *What For?* This is an album possessed of both a distinct sense of the mood it wants to invoke, and also a sense of humour about the single-mindedness with which it sets about the task. Smart, effortlessly cool, and rendered with a fresh clarity, the soul influences are worn as a badge of honour whilst the mismatch of laid-back delivery and sometimes heavier content is endlessly compelling. The vocals are liberally treated with effects, but its done with such a holistic sense of the album‚Äôs sonic world that instead of risking distraction it instead echoes the warm distortion of the guitars, and serves to deepen the rich, swaying textures of the lower- tempo tracks. When the pace picks up on tracks like ‚ÄòEmpty Nesters‚Äô it takes the edge off the more cutting lyrics (‚ÄúCall Mom & Dad because their nest is empty, and so are you‚Äù) and keeps the mood light. Aaron Gold‚Äôs drums perform the same trick throughout, keeping things light and moving swiftly. The record‚Äôs finest moment comes in the shape of ‚ÄòSpell It Out‚Äô: a three-minute sideswipe that comes off like a simultaneous slap and kiss to the cheek. ### 3. Grimes ‚Äî *Art Angels* Rumour has it that after the unexpected level of attention garnered by 2012‚Äôs *Visions*, Clare Boucher made an album‚Äôs worth of material ‚Äî including ill-conceived single release ‚ÄôGo‚Äô ‚Äî before scrapping the whole thing and starting again. If true it‚Äôs perhaps indicative of how seriously Boucher sees the task of representing herself truthfully through her art in the glare of intensified media interest. She starts, simply, on the introductory ‚ÄòLaughing and Not Being Normal‚Äô, by reminding us that she has a spectacular voice, sometimes overlooked in commentary that focusses on her layering techniques and beat-making. From there she progresses into the achingly-beautiful ‚ÄòCalifornia‚Äô, which contains perhaps Grimes‚Äôs clearest method statement: "I love this music / It sounds just like my soul". And so unfolds a record democratic in its tastes, eclectic in its tone and tempo, and yet singularly focussed on the task of pure artistic expression. Whatever reception the release received it seems clear that the most important thing to the artist here was making a record she was happy with. And so she indulges every whim for the duration that it retains her attention: sweetness, savagery, choral melody, multi-layered spiral-staircase beats... and on. ‚ÄòKill V. Maim‚Äô is the album‚Äôs centrepiece, a crucible for all this particularly brilliant form of compositional madness, and ‚Äî by some miracle ‚Äî one of the best synth-pop anthems since Robyn‚Äôs *Body Talk* five years ago. ### 2. Sleater-Kinney ‚Äî *No Cities to Love* Where did this come from? I had a slight familiarity with S-K‚Äôs previous album: *The Woods* (2005), but that was a decade ago, and prior to that ‚Äî in the pre-streaming / pre-download era ‚Äî they‚Äôd never really crossed my radar other than as mentions in articles analysing the impact of grunge, listed alongside Belly and Sonic Youth, and a dozen other bands I never really connected with for whatever reason. So it comes as something of a surprise that I fell so hard for this album, having tuned in after hearing it compared to Wild Flag‚Äôs 2011 debut. (It‚Äôs pretty funny how clearly I had that influence the wrong way around.) Released not three weeks into the year it was immediately obvious that this album would stick around for a place on The List. ‚ÄòPrice Tag‚Äô might be the best opening track of any album this year, and like ‚ÄòSurface Envy‚Äô, ‚ÄòA New Wave‚Äô and... well, most of the album, it‚Äôs a ~3-minute masterpiece of concentrated energy driving forward a smart lyric. This collection of songs is near bursting at the seams with ideas, energy and new directionality; it‚Äôs possible that after 10 years away the three members of Sleater-Kinney came back together with so many ideas that *No Cities to Love* represents the finest 10 tracks of dozens recorded. Whatever the case, they‚Äôve produced a near-perfect rock album with just the right levels of enthusiasm, menace, sadness, and empowering anger. The title track deserves special mention for balancing these elements particularly flawlessly, whilst showcasing the poppy lightness that keeps the whole record effervescing. ### 1. Chvrches ‚Äî *Every Open Eye* Chvrches‚Äô debut album reached number 4 on my 2013 list and so it‚Äôs fitting that this record, which represents a simultaneous strengthening and deepening of their sound, claims a higher spot. In truth the top three here came together pretty late. With Sleater-Kinney having been in pole position since release in Jan, and the Grimes LP not arriving until fairly late in the year, there was a bunch of late-in-the-day shuffling going on. *The Bones of What You Believe* was one of those records that I loved but which left me with questions as to how it would be followed up. The answer Chvrches have elected to go with ‚Äî perhaps wisely ‚Äî is to double down on what they‚Äôre indisputably great at: a propulsive strain of synth-pop, underpinned by a strong rhythm section, and shot through with a hint of darkness. Lauren Mayberry‚Äôs voice remains the band‚Äôs secret weapon: sometimes fragile-seeming and bruised, it is uniquely suited to making anthemic vocals feel tender and personal. It is not Hayley Williams‚Äôs absolute siren of a vocal style, but matches it for its ability to make the synaptic connection between head and heart. The album is near-flawless; even the questionable choice to leave vocals to Martin Doherty on 'High Enough to Carry You Over‚Äô shifts the album temporarily into a slightly different tone, following which ‚ÄòEmpty Threat‚Äô (the record‚Äôs poppiest moment) feels something like the lifting of a headache or a low mood. Perhaps the album‚Äôs signal moment comes just over two minutes into ‚ÄòClearest Blue‚Äô, when the tender build-up crescendos into a euphoric dance beat. Somehow the fact that it resembles nothing more closely than The Pet Shop Boys does nothing to dilute the sheer joy of it. It‚Äôs telling that album number two has pushed Chvrches straight to the top of my list of acts to see live ASAP. Bright, sweet, imbued with boundless energy, and yet knowing and highly polished, this record is a confection but one over which I carry no guilt for adoring. ‚èé Return to the [index of lists](/thelists)

items.title: As Apple Enters Streaming
items.content_html:
Ahead of Monday‚Äôs likely announcement of a streaming music service from Apple, I went back to read Steve Jobs‚Äôs blogpost from 2007 on DRM and the state of the digital music economy. Jobs writes clearly and his argument is sound, but his frustration is evident; the post is actually part attack on the “big four” record labels‚Äô shortsightedness, and part lobbying effort toward openness.

What would Jobs have thought of the prospect of streaming music? It seems like a half-way house between siloed ecosystems and platform agnosticism: you get to listen to whatever you like, but you don‚Äôt own any of it1, as a consequence of which it‚Äôs easy to up sticks and move to a competitor without losing anything apart from some easily recreated playlists. It feels like a compromise, and one in which neither the artists nor the listeners truly win. The labels continue to profit though, and that‚Äôs ultimately what made streaming services inevitable and the eradication of DRM an improbability.

  1. not even to the extent that you own the music you download or even buy on disc (check the EULA) ↩︎

items.title: Marathon
items.content_html:
It‚Äôs over. After months of training, and 308 minutes of running (and a little walking) on the streets of London yesterday, the marathon is no longer a milestone I‚Äôm headed towards but an accomplishment I can look back on.

It turns out that the night before a marathon ‚Äì especially, I presume, when it‚Äôs your first marathon ‚Äì you don‚Äôt sleep very well. I was a mix of nerves and a little bit of excitement, but whereas Elizabeth said it felt as though she was on the verge of going on holiday, it felt to me as though I was ill prepared for an exam or job interview the next day.

All of the prep was done ‚Äì clothes laid out, bags all packed ‚Äì and it was just a matter of getting up early, showering, eating a carb-heavy breakfast of peanut butter on wholemeal toast, and then walking up to the train. From the station to the starting line there was a good atmosphere. Practically the only other people getting a train to London at 7:30am on a Sunday were either fellow runners or friends and family accompanying them. Leaving the train at the other end we found ourselves walking amid a melange of people in running gear pinning numbers to themselves and attempting to shake out their nervous excitement.

Once I had some paracetamol in my system, ibuprofen gel on my knees, my knee support in place, and a little vaseline on my nipples‚Ä¶ I felt kind of ready. Kind of.

The start was a burst of nerves and good feeling as the music swelled and the noise of the crowds started. And it didn‚Äôt ever stop. The whole way around there was hardly a stretch of 50m that didn‚Äôt have people cheering, applauding, and urging runners on for hours and hours - it was quite a feeling and made me want to do something equally supportive for competitors in a similarly tough event in the future. I lost count of the number of people holding out offered half oranges and even slices of pizza. Reading the signs, meeting the eyes of encouraging spectators, it all helped even if it was just by giving my mind something else to do.

I think my attitude going into the event would have been more positive if I hadn’t failed to complete the three longest sessions prescribed in our training plan. As it was I literally didn‚Äôt know if I would be able to complete the course. That was what I found myself contending with about half way through. The toughest part was somewhere around 15 miles in: I started to feel nauseated, lightheaded as though I might pass out, and like running was the absolute last thing I wanted to be doing. I thought quite clearly at that point that not only didn‚Äôt I want to finish the marathon, but I could’nt do it. I remember thinking what a shame it was that all of the training had been for nothing. That was the first point at which I stopped to walk for a minute, and I managed to talk myself around. I switched isotonic drinks for water to calm my stomach, and switched my music off for a bit as it felt weirdly as though I didn‚Äôt have the mental capacity to process lyrics and melody as well as concentrate on running.

I honestly don‚Äôt know how I got through the next 4 or 5 miles. I remember hitting mile 18 knowing that was where Elizabeth’s family were watching from, and I amused myself momentarily by thwanging my sweat-soaked hat at her brother as I passed. It turns out that the night before a marathon ‚Äì especially, I presume, when it‚Äôs your first marathon ‚Äì you don‚Äôt sleep very well. I was a mix of nerves and a little bit of excitement, but whereas Elizabeth said it felt as though she was on the verge of going on holiday, it felt to me as though I was ill prepared for an exam or job interview the next day.

All of the prep was done ‚Äì clothes laid out, bags all packed ‚Äì and it was just a matter of getting up early, showering, eating a carb-heavy breakfast of peanut butter on wholemeal toast, and then walking up to the train. From the station to the starting line there was a good atmosphere. Practically the only other people getting a train to London at 7:30am on a Sunday were either fellow runners or friends and family  accompanying them. Leaving the train at the other end we found ourselves walking amid a melange of people in running gear pinning numbers to themselves and attempting to shake out their nervous excitement. 

Once I had some paracetamol in my system, ibuprofen gel on my knees, my knee support in place, and a little vaseline on my nipples‚Ä¶ I felt kind of ready. Kind of.

The start was a burst of nerves and good feeling as the music swelled and the noise of the crowds started. And it didn‚Äôt ever stop. items.title: Michael Cina
items.content_html:
My favourite album cover from a couple of years ago was for Shigeto‚Äôs No Better Time Than Now (2013): an abstract swath of neon colour descending to deep black via a middle third that appears liquid, almost swimming in front of your eyes. It‚Äôs the work of Michael Cina, an abstract artist (as well as a director, and typographer amongst other things) based in Minneapolis.

I started to seek out more of Cina‚Äôs work: other covers for artists on Ghostly International (eg. for Matthew Dear‚Äôs Beams (2012)); the series of desktop wallpapers he put together for the label; and his broader design work via his company Cina Associates. Cina‚Äôs became one of those names that once you‚Äôre looking out for it seems to pop up all over the place, mentioned by other artists whose work you admire, or dropped into an article associated with some cool project on the horizon.

An in depth interview at The Great Discontent last year revealed a lot about the breadth of Cina‚Äôs work‚Äîparticularly with regard to typography‚Äîand also allowed a glimpse into his practice and his admirable work ethic, and sometime after reading that I joined up to the artist‚Äôs mailing list. And it was via the mailing list that I learned a little more about Cina‚Äôs process when it comes to making abstract work. When starting on something new he first makes a series of studies, testing colours, sketching ideas - as Cina puts it:

Studies are smaller pieces that I create when I work. They are an integral part of my process. Sometimes they are just a sketch, sometimes an idea for a larger painting. Many of these have been sourced for larger works.

On a semi-regular basis Cina puts together a set of these studies and offers them for sale at a nominal price. I‚Äôd been watching the listings for a couple of months before I found a piece that grabbed me, but now I‚Äôm proud to say I own a unique piece of Michael Cina‚Äôs work: ‚ÄòSC 107‚Äô

Of the wide variety of works employing different styles & techniques, ‚ÄòSC 107‚Äô stood out to me for the simple reason that‚Äîwhether I was correct or not‚ÄîI immediately perceived that Cina had been sketching towards a human face. What caught my attention first was the eye just left of the image‚Äôs centre, and then another, smaller and too far offset from the other but there. A thin, rectangular nose doesn‚Äôt entirely match the position of either eye, and is too close to the beginnings of a lower lip. The pen marks themselves may not have been enough, but something about the colouration: a reddish shoulder and then a band of yellow moving up through the right side of the face keyed my eye into the image - made it solid for me.

It arrived this week and I couldn‚Äôt be happier with it. The next step is to find a frame that suits; in person the piece has subtle patches of translucency, and I‚Äôd like to find something that keeps that visible.

items.title: Dorthe Nors ‚Äî Minna Needs Rehearsal Space (2013)
items.content_html:
I haven‚Äôt read a lot of Nordic fiction, but having recently returned from a first trip to Denmark, encountering a review of this new volume of Dorthe Nors‚Äôs work, I felt compelled to check it out. The book Pushkin Press has put out is actually a combination of Nors‚Äôs 2008 short story collection‚ÄîKarate Chop‚Äîand a newer work: 2013‚Äôs prose-poem / novella, Minna Needs Rehearsal Space. I chose to dive into the latter first because I was intrigued by the form, and I remained so throughout its 89 pages.

Taken as a whole the work is decidedly more prosaic than poetic, although Nors nevertheless displays an assured understanding of rhythm and pace. To construct a narrative from largely declarative sentences, none of them long enough to break over two lines, demands a kind of discipline. Perhaps unavoidably, because of how the eye is drawn and how the language flows, the piece is quite propulsive. Nors exacerbates that by choosing to repeatedly start successive sentences with the same word. But within these constraints, she displays a great deal of tonal diversity:

One shouldn‚Äôt hurt others unnecessarily. One should above all be kind. Minna would rather not be anything but. Minna‚Äôs hardly anything but. The email thunders through the ether toward Karin. That‚Äôs as it should be, thinks Minna. The ether‚Äôs full of malicious messages. The ether hums with break-ups and loss. The ether is knives being thrown. The ether is blood surging back.

The text moves from Minna‚Äôs point of view to comment on her inner monologue and shifts so often and so fluidly that it sometimes occupies a position not readily identifiable to the reader.

Minna and Jette sit sans camouflage in the midst of it all. Jette‚Äôs eyes are insistent. Minna has a hard time relaxing. The legs biking. The arms warding off blows. The body full of vim. The soul supposed to sit still. It ain‚Äôt easy.

I read the bulk of Minna Needs Rehearsal Space in two large gulps. Partly because the text makes it so easy to slip into its stream and get pulled along, but also because it felt that at any one point I was learning something about the central character‚Äîeither by revelation or inference‚Äîthat reframed my understanding of the narrative, whilst drawing me forward to discover more. The writing is, in places, quite beautiful, and whilst it felt at the start that the odd format may be a distraction, that never proved to be the case; Nors‚Äôs economy of language always allowed the work‚Äôs ideas to shine all the more clearly, rather than diminishing them.

Dad‚Äôs hand and Minna‚Äôs. The blue delta of Dad‚Äôs hand. The sea rises in Minna. The sea finds fissures in Minna. Minna‚Äôs leaky. Minna opens her eyes and blinks. The sea tricks slowly. The sea reaches land. The beads of gravel rattle.

items.title: T-minus 4 Weeks
items.content_html:
The starting whistle for the 2015 London Marathon will blow at 10:10am on Sunday 26 April. Or it‚Äôs a gun they fire, or a klaxon that sounds, or someone drops a handkerchief‚Ä¶ I‚Äôm not sure how it starts, but I know when it starts: precisely four weeks from the publication of this blogpost. And I also know this: I‚Äôll be there, nervous, excited, the number 4011 pinned to my chest, ready to take on a new challenge.

Back in October I wrote about how and why I got into this in the first place. With 28 days to go I‚Äôm posting this as a pretty naked appeal for your help. Training has been hard work, and the most important thing in pulling me through it has been the kindness and support of my girlfriend ‚Äî also running her first marathon ‚Äî and of my friends & family. This is as good a place as any to say that there is no way I would have come this far without your encouragement, so thank you all.

We‚Äôre now in the home stretch, and I‚Äôm posting this as a reminder that when I lace up my shoes four Sundays from now I‚Äôm doing it partly for myself, yes, but also for two charities. If you‚Äôd like to learn more and maybe help me help them, please click on over to the fundraising page. [Update: link removed now that the event is over.]

Thank you for your support. There‚Äôs still a lot of work to do, but you‚Äôre helping make it so worthwhile.

items.title: Going (Half) The Distance
items.content_html:
Today we reached the end of week 11 of our training plan for this year‚Äôs London Marathon, and the order of the day was to go out and run a half marathon. Luckily, there was one being staged 30 minutes away, around the outskirts of Dartford. This was the 39th running of the Dartford Half Marathon, and the first year in which the event had been moved from its previous summer slot to a cooler time of year. This, and the fact that it now falls perfectly for those of us building up towards the big event in six weeks‚Äô time, had swollen the number of participants to more than 600.

The Dartford course ‚Äî a little research told me ahead of time ‚Äî is regarded as one of the toughest in the country, with three or four sizeable hills, the steepest of which comes about 10 miles into the race. Still, I was looking forward to the event. The previous three Sundays in the training plan had been beyond half marathon distance, with last Sunday being an 18 mile stretch that I‚Äôd found pretty punishing. I‚Äôd been having problems first with my right ankle and then ‚Äî perhaps owing to overcompensating ‚Äî my left knee, but the shorter runs during this week hadn‚Äôt posed any problems, and I felt good about the prospects of doing 13.1 miles at the pace I was aiming for ‚Äî despite the hills.

Yesterday, whilst doing a bit of final preparation ‚Äî checking I had the details of the day straight in my mind etc. ‚Äî I stumbled on an item in the FAQs that put a real kink in my race plans:

In view of a raised awareness of the threat to safety‚Ä¶ runners should not wear personal stereo equipment during this race. [A]nyone wearing such devices during the event will be disqualified.

I‚Äôve been running for a little over three years and I don‚Äôt think I‚Äôve ever gone out for longer than 30 minutes without some form of audio accompaniment: music, podcasts, or an audiobook on longer stints. For me this kind of companionship serves a couple of purposes: music is motivating and helps me keep a rhythm, and listening to conversational podcasts or (usually fiction) audiobooks gives me something to involve myself with mentally as the miles tick past. The most important function, however, is to stop me thinking too much about the run. I have a terrible habit, left to my own devices, of constantly calculating the time elapsed vs. the likely time remaining; the pace of the previous mile and the pace of the present one, how they compare and what overall time would result from carrying on at one pace or altering up or down a gear. The prospect of listening to myself think like this for something like 2.5 hours was exhausting in and of itself.

During the event however, there was something about running a route that was new to me (instead of my usual route, which I know very well), and being surrounded by other runners, which kept my mind occupied to some degree. There were still stretches, particularly in the latter half of the race when I found myself running alone for a while, that I caught myself doing the maths, but overall my mind felt relaxed and engaged.

I did find the endeavour of running an ostensibly competitive race to be a bit strange. I‚Äôve never really enjoyed playing competitive sports, and find my personality much more suited to running as I have sold it to myself: as a solo exercise, where my past self is my only competition. There is, however, still room for that conception whilst running within the framework of an organised, competitive event. I enjoyed the camaraderie that many of the competitors showed toward one another, and the encouragement of the course marshals, but when it came down to it I was by myself out there and had only myself to blame if I failed to meet the goals that I had set myself.

I had in mind the rather arbitrary-sounding finish time of 2h 23m (extrapolated out from the 11 minute miles I had decided upon as my average pace goal), and in the end came in with a time of 2h 14m. My knee hurt a great deal in the aftermath of the race, but I‚Äôm convinced that was a result not of the overall length of the course, but of the pounding I gave it in the final two miles as I really pushed towards the line. Had I stuck to putting in miles of between 10m 30s and 11m 30s as planned, I think I could have run on for quite a while without any complaint from my legs.

As I crossed the line and had the timing chip cut from my shoe, I was handed a medal for completing the race, and a ticket by a marshal who told me I‚Äôd won a spot prize: this turned out to be a big tub of chocolates, which were welcome, even if the set of stairs I had to traverse to claim them were not.

I had only run half marathon distance three times prior to this race, and 2h 14m is a personal best by some way; I‚Äôm pretty happy with the effort, especially over such a tough course. The last two miles were done at a pace that I now most likely won‚Äôt reach again until after the London Marathon is complete. What remains is another six weeks of slowly, steadily training my body to accept longer distances. Hopefully the ankle problem is truly behind me. Hopefully the knee will repair over the coming week and be stronger for it. Perhaps the most interesting thing I took from today was the idea that just maybe when I take my place at the start line in London on 26 April, I don‚Äôt necessarily need to have my earphones in.

I enjoyed the camaraderie that many of the competitors showed toward one another, and the encouragement of the course marshals, but when it came down to it I was by myself out there and had only myself to blame if I failed to meet the goals that I had set myself.

I had in mind the rather arbitrary-sounding finish time of 2h 23m (extrapolated out from the 11 minute miles I had decided upon as my average pace goal), and in the end came in with a time of 2h 14m. My knee hurt a great deal in the aftermath of the race, but I‚Äôm convinced that was a result not of the overall length of the course, but of the pounding I gave it in the final two miles as I really pushed towards the line. Had I stuck to putting in miles of between 10m 30s and 11m 30s as planned, I think I could have run on for quite a while without any complaint from my legs.
  
As I crossed the line and had the timing chip cut from my shoe, I was handed a medal for completing the race, and a ticket by a marshal who told me I‚Äôd won a spot prize: this turned out to be a big tub of chocolates, which were welcome, even if the set of stairs I had to traverse to claim them were not.

I had only run half marathon distance three times prior to this race, and 2h 14m is a personal best by some way; I‚Äôm pretty happy with the effort, especially over such a tough course. The last two miles were done at a pace that I now most likely won‚Äôt reach again until after the London Marathon is complete. What remains is another six weeks of slowly, steadily training my body to accept longer distances. Hopefully the ankle problem is truly behind me. Hopefully the knee will repair over the coming week and be stronger for it. Perhaps the most interesting thing I took from today was the idea that just maybe when I take my place at the start line in London on 26 April, I don‚Äôt necessarily need to have my earphones in.

items.title: ... Will Understand
items.content_html:
What was the last song you became obsessed with? Around this time last year I was playing St. Vincent‚Äôs ‚ÄòDigital Witness‚Äô a lot, and singing it, humming it, or running parts through in my mind even when the headphones weren‚Äôt in. I have a history of that: songs that hook into some recess in me and loop endlessly, happily away seemingly without much effort on my part to call them to mind. But they‚Äôre also always the songs to which I find myself returning when I launch Rdio or pick up my phone to play something.

I think last January‚Äôs semi-obsessive repetition of that St. Vincent track was the last time it happened for me, but right now there‚Äôs another song playing over-and-over in my mind, and which I play (usually just once, but sometimes a couple of times through) at least every other day at this point: Irma Thomas‚Äôs 1964 single ‚ÄòAnyone Who Knows What Love Is (Will Understand)‚Äô.

The song is a three-minute masterpiece of plaintive longing and understated resolve. The subtle echo on Thomas‚Äôs voice is haunting and perfectly pitched to lend a hint of loneliness to her plight, and the instrumentation is similarly restrained: a simple piano refrain that sounds like it‚Äôs coming from another room, the drumming little more than tempo kept with a brush, and a bright xylophone scale that glints over the verses like light through breeze-blown trees. The pure magic of the track, for me, is caught in one moment at the end of each of the two choruses, with the choice of how to deliver those bracketed words from the title. Every time I play the song I can hear the usual, easy line for the end of that phrase: it starts earlier than Thomas actually does and goes up on the first syllable of ‚Äòunderstand‚Äô before levelling off. It‚Äôs the line that a thousand soul and alt-soul songs choose, and keeps those two words in their parenthetical place. Instead Thomas dips subtly down on that syllable, and extends it, rising slightly, before touching the final two syllables in a soft staccato. Somehow it shifts the whole weight of the song, making it not solely another love song but also a paean for understanding - as vulnerable as it is beautiful.

items.title: In Praise of the Running Novelist
items.content_html:
I‚Äôve just finished re-reading Haruki Murakami‚Äôs What I Talk About When I Talk About Running (2008). The first time I read the book it was as a fan of Murakami‚Äôs work, and over the last couple of weeks I‚Äôve gone back through it as someone who is in training for their first marathon. It‚Äôs an odd book: a mix of autobiography, a kind of sports reportage, a little travel writing, and a healthy dose of something akin to philosophy. Murakami isn‚Äôt the kind of writer to present athletics in technicolour, super-sized with pomp and meaning; as with his fiction, he‚Äôs wonderful on the details: the rituals, the toll on the body, the workings of the mind during prolonged physical activity.

I just run. I run in a void. Or maybe I should put it the other way: I run in order to acquire a void. But as you might expect, an occasional thought will slip into this void. People‚Äôs minds can‚Äôt be a complete blank. Human beings‚Äô emotions are not strong or consistent enough to sustain a vacuum. What I mean is, the kinds of thoughts and ideas that invade my emotions as I run remain subordinate to that void. Lacking content, they are just random thoughts that gather around that central void.

These are my favourite passages of the book, when Murakami meditates on what running has meant to him ‚Äî what it has taught him. Murakami is a pretty strong and highly experienced runner, whereas I am currently that most dangerous of things: an advanced beginner. I have no aspirations to match the times or distances that he outlines in the book, but I do find much of Murakami‚Äôs psychological approach admirable.

When I‚Äôm criticised unjustly (from my point of view, at least), or when someone I‚Äôm sure will understand me doesn‚Äôt, I go running for a little longer than usual. By running longer it‚Äôs like I can physically exhaust that portion of my discontent. It also makes me realize again how weak I am, how limited my abilities are. I become aware, physically, of these low points. And one of the results of running a little father than usual is that I become that much stronger. If I‚Äôm angry, I direct that anger toward myself. If I have a frustrating experience, I use that to improve myself.

Here Murakami gets close to something I have also found, expressing it more eloquently than I could. To be engaged in something as simple as running, and yet to be confronted by this simple act with concrete proof of your limitations, is humbling. In a very concrete way you are presented with evidence of your mortality, your relative weakness, and you learn something about yourself that feels solid and true.

Writing from decades of experience as both a long-distance runner and the author of multiple lengthy novels, Murakami‚Äôs notes on concentrated effort and stamina have a ring of universality to them. As in his fiction it often seems that the simple object of his description is also being treated allegorically. This certainly makes the book worthy of re-reading, and I‚Äôm pleased to have been able to take from my second time through what I hope can be lessons, or at least aids the next time I lace up my shoes.

[Running] should add a few new elements to your inventory in understanding who you are. And as a result your view of your life, its colors and shape, should be transformed.

items.title: Birdman & Enemy
items.content_html:
2015 is off to a great start filmically: in just the first four days of the year I saw a pair of really interesting character studies that are also showpieces of meticulous direction. I thought I‚Äôd put together nothing more than a couple of paragraphs of encouragement to seek out these movies, as they‚Äôre both better seen without too much in the way of preconceptions.

Birdman dir. Alejandro G. I√±√°rritu (2014)

I‚Äôve been a Michael Keaton fan for a long while, and the run up to this film‚Äôs release was all about the excitement of getting to see him in a leading role that he could really get his teeth into. I found director I√±√°rritu‚Äôs Babel (2006) overlong and too ponderous, and the highly acclaimed Amores Perros (2000) remains a shameful blind spot in my recent cinema knowledge. However, the trailer for Birdman had an intriguing punk tone to it, and coupled with a really neat poster, I was also¬†going in interested to see how the movie would work visually.¬†

I was blown away on both counts. Keaton has perhaps never been better (though I remain a huge fan of the performances he delivers in Multiplicity (1996), Pacific Heights (1990) and, of course, Batman (1989) in particular), and I√±√°rritu‚Äôs direction (along with Emmanuel Lubezki‚Äôs DP work) is absolutely mesmerising throughout. The supposed trick here, of course, is that the whole 119 minutes appears to pass in one solid take - but the real trick is that I√±√°rritu & Lubezki find a way to do that which doesn‚Äôt feel like empty showboating, but rather a vital element of the film‚Äôs interrogation of the relationship between the sibling media of cinema & theatre.

Enemy dir. Denis Villeneuve (2013)

And then, just after having my head spun by Birdman I find that Denis Villeneuve‚Äôs latest is available for rental. I really enjoyed his previous movie‚Äî2013‚Äôs Prisoners‚Äîand had been looking forward to Enemy after seeing the trailer a while back.

Again, not to give too much away: Jake Gyllenhaal here plays two characters‚Äîa shy, somewhat withdrawn teacher, and a C-list movie actor‚Äîthe relationship between whom is unclear. They circle each other, their orbits each affected by the other, in trajectories that complicate and darken as the film goes on. Both of Gyllenhaal‚Äôs performances are really accomplished: it‚Äôs genuinely impressive how he‚Äôs able to distinguish the two characters through posture and gesture where a lesser actor would resort to caricature. And the film itself‚Äîits look, its feel, its oddities‚Äîhas really stayed in my thoughts. Immediately that it was finished I started looking around the internet for some explication of its more opaque corners, and I‚Äôve found myself returning in my mind to some of the really striking imagery that Villeneuve constructs. As with Birdman, I‚Äôm aching to see it again already.

If these two don‚Äôt end up in the top five movies I see this year then 2015 will have been an absolutely outstanding year at the cinema. There are plenty of good reviews for each out there (eg. Little White Lies on Birdman & The Dissolve on Enemy) but if you trust me enough I fully recommend going into these as cold as possible and having your head opened up a little. Enjoy.

items.title: The List 2014
items.content_html:
At the end of each year I make a list of the twenty albums I enjoyed the most. To be eligible, a record has to be of album length (at least ~30 mins), and contain entirely (or almost entirely) new material; live albums, cover records, and compilations are ineligible.

20. Deru ‚Äî 1979

I was introduced to Deru via his contributions to the Outliers: Volume 1 - Iceland project, in which his minimalist electronic soundscapes provided the perfect accompaniment to long, languorous shots of Iceland‚Äôs stark landscapes. Over the duration of an album the tone varies a little more, but retains a chill and a slight distance. I kept returning to this record to be present with it, simply because I like the colours it paints with and the patience with which it unfolds.

19. Kiasmos ‚Äî Kiasmos

Billed as √ìlafur Arnalds‚Äôs electronica side-project, Kiasmos sounds pretty much as that description would lead you to believe. Built around the basis of Arnalds‚Äôs sweeping strings and intricate, sensitive piano patterns, the augmentation provided here by synths and drum machines simply serves to lend another texture to the sound. Sometimes there‚Äôs a switch to a pace Arnalds rarely achieves in his solo work, but the majority of this record poses no surprises. Regardless, I found myself enjoying this again and again.

18. Thom Yorke ‚Äî Tomorrow‚Äôs Modern Boxes

Released by some unusual method ‚Äî as is now the usual ‚Äî and instantly familiar-feeling to anyone who listened to Radiohead‚Äôs The King of Limbs (2011) or Atoms for Peace‚Äôs AMOK (2013), Tomorrow‚Äôs Modern Boxes is nevertheless another fine set of glitchy, angsty, intricate clockworks wound up and let loose by a master craftsman and endlessly curious tinkerer. Particularly if you enjoyed the album versions of tracks from Yorke‚Äôs The Eraser (2006), before they morphed and grew slightly when Atoms for Peace came on board to play them live, you‚Äôll feel right at home with this understated collection of modest but accomplished work.

17. East India Youth ‚Äî Total Strife Forever

A complete mystery to me upon first listen, William Doyle‚Äôs set of glittering, swimming electronica eventually coalesced into something I felt I could get my hands around. Conversely, I learned the best way to do that was simply to allow it to wash over me. The titular quartet could have been released as a standalone work, but surrounding those tracks with more tonally-varied pieces really serves to bring them into relief as the spine of the album but not its flesh. I‚Äôm not a huge fan of Doyle‚Äôs falsetto vocal (which creeps in a few times here and there and is underwhelming rather than wholly off-putting), but his ear for the melodic throughline to a complex miasma of sound is impressive throughout.

16. Liars ‚Äî Mess

No two Liars albums are the same, and in the shape of Mess they‚Äôve released perhaps their best since the career high of Drum‚Äôs Not Dead (2006). Opener ‚ÄòMask Maker‚Äô seems like a deliberate attempt to forewarn the listener that they‚Äôre in for a rough ride, but if one can learn to lean into the swings and take the bumps there‚Äôs so much here to be infected by. The album‚Äôs best track ‚ÄòMess on a Mission‚Äô is perhaps the band‚Äôs best to date, not to mention the best theme tune for a non-existent, Warren Ellis-scripted, True Detective-on- amphetamines, HBO show I can imagine. Liars are talented at conjuring the sound of nightmares, and are not afraid of unleashing music that is at first seemingly incomprehensible. Learn to love it however, and you‚Äôll find a lot to love.

15. Tycho ‚Äî Awake

I caught up with this album so, so late in the year and have a feeling that given time to blossom in my mind it may float further up this list. Quickly my favourite release on label-of-the-year contender Ghostly International, Awake is a stunning collection of sur-ambient tracks that swell and sweep along lines that quickly seem familiar and yet continue to grow in the mind with each listen. I can foresee this being a record I return to for quite a while to come; I‚Äôm already kicking myself a little for not picking it up upon release.

14. Sisyphus ‚Äî Sisyphus

I‚Äôm not even sure how I came across this record ‚Äî perhaps via the Son Lux connection ‚Äî but even on first listen I was fascinated by its variety and by how singular so many of its elements felt. Opening track ‚ÄòCalm it Down‚Äô is doubtlessly one of my tracks of 2014, and Serengeti‚Äôs laid-back, self-assured flow was one of the discoveries of the year for me. The album as a whole is restlessly inventive - constantly trying on new styles, sometimes two or three within the space of a single track: soul, hip-hop, R&B, electronica - they‚Äôre all in the mix here, and the combination was consistently alluring to me. My favourite moment at the time of writing is on ‚ÄòBooty Call‚Äô: the delivery of the line ‚ÄúIm‚Äôa kiss you like a bubble in the brooks.‚Äù I don‚Äôt even need to know what that actually means.

13. Aphex Twin ‚Äî Syro

The last time Richard James put out an Aphex Twin album my interest in electronic music was very slight, but even then I knew the name and something of the reputation. Syro appeared amongst much fanfare in September, and hasn‚Äôt moved far down my ‚Äòrecently played‚Äô list since. I used the term ‚Äòrestlessly inventive‚Äô above to describe Sisyphus‚Äôs melange of styles, but it applies here too; I don‚Äôt think any two bars of Syro are identical; things are always shifting, different elements of a track taking momentary prominence and then being subverted or switched out for some other stem. Four months hasn‚Äôt scratched the surface of unlocking Syro in my mind, but there‚Äôs something special about a record that still feels ultimately unknowable after so much play.

12. Manic Street Preachers ‚Äî Futurology

At this point in their career it‚Äôs a wonder that the Manics are still able to surprise. But, whilst the vast majority of its component parts are drawn from elsewhere in their storied history, Futurology still manages to arrange the building-blocks into some wonderful new shapes. Billed as a poppier counterpart to last year‚Äôs Rewind the Film the album finds the band going straight ahead on some tracks (‚ÄôSex, Power, Love and Money‚Äô, ‚ÄòBetween the Clock and the Bed‚Äô) but still finding plenty of room for introspection (‚ÄòWalk me to the Bridge‚Äô) and edgier-sounding fare. ‚ÄòThe Next Jet to Leave Moscow‚Äô could only have been written by a band old enough to harbour regrets; their willingness to spill them and work them through like this is admirable, and to our benefit. When the sums are totalled up this is the fourth in a run of great, and very different-feeling, albums from The Manics since 2009.

11. Caribou ‚Äî Our Love

After a while spent in its company Our Love resolves into a beautiful collection of bright, spacious electronica. I found myself returning to it as a default album for lightening an afternoon, or to run to in the evenings. Perfectly paced, meticulously crafted rhythms are brought to life by an inventive instrumental palate that kept me guessing until it crept into my head completely. Album highlight ‚ÄòSecond Chance‚Äô takes a gamble on the kind of vocal that commonly renders tracks skippable for me, but for some indiscernible reason here makes it the song I returned to most often. That‚Äôs just one of a thousand impeccable decisions made by Dan Snaith in his production of a record that took up root on the brighter end of my electronica spectrum and stayed firmly planted through the darker months.

10. The Acid ‚Äî Liminal

‘Liminal’ is one of my favourite words, and one I perhaps over-used in poetry seminars. It‚Äôs also a word I apply mentally to certain albums and pieces of music. Deftones‚Äô White Pony (2000) feels that way to me, as does OK Computer (1997) for some reason. The Acid (of whom the only member I was previously familiar with is Adam Freeland) have chosen a good title for their debut LP however: the music on Liminal emerges and grows organically, fades, shifts, and evokes powerfully its own sense of place.

‚ÄòCreeper‚Äô is propulsive and straining at itself to break free. ‚ÄòBasic Instinct‚Äô is understated and makes good use of the vocal effect the record‚Äôs production relies on throughout to mask a relatively slight range. I found that with this record, perhaps because it is so successful in evoking a particular mood, I had to be in the right mood to play it - but when that mood hit there was little better than spending time inside the world it builds.

9. Nothing ‚Äî Guilty Of Everything

The closest stylistic analogue for what Nothing are doing on their debut is shoegaze, but various elements of their sound push at and perhaps tear the edges of that envelope. Whilst tracks like ‚ÄòEndlessly‚Äô are firmly within the tradition of My Bloody Valentine et al, ‚ÄòGet Well‚Äô is too rhythmic and danceable, and ‚ÄòSomersault‚Äô is closer to something from Hope of the States‚Äô The Lost Riots (2004).

Regardless, the production of the record understands well what the band‚Äôs ambition is: to flood the listener‚Äôs head with glorious, monochrome noise so that they feel subsumed by and imbued with it.

8. Taylor McFerrin ‚Äî Early Riser

For some reason I didn‚Äôt listen to much jazz this year (Otis Brown III‚Äôs The Thought of You perhaps the best jazz qua jazz LP I spent any significant time with), and even this is borderline. McFerrin‚Äôs modus operandi is to interweave soulful, understated electronica through elements of jazz (‚Äò4am‚Äô, ‚ÄòAlready There‚Äô), R&B (‚ÄòThe Antidote‚Äô), and back into soul itself (opener, and entrant on the track-of-the-year shortlist, ‚ÄòPostpartum‚Äô). Something about the resulting mix (perhaps the way it moves seamlessly from one sound to another) really worked for me. On weekend mornings and walks into work it was a pleasure to be accompanied by this album which, in all its forms, suffuses light and good feeling.

7. Run The Jewels ‚Äî Run The Jewels 2

Hip-hop didn‚Äôt come through for me this year either. The new Common album didn‚Äôt get close to the hype, the long-awaited Wu Tang Clan LP had its moments but was never going to be a classic, and the same goes for The Roots‚Äô ‚Ä¶And Then You Shoot Your Cousin. Kanye took a year off, Jay-Z took a year off, who knows if Yasiin Bey / Mos Def is working on anything?

Anyway, all of which set the stage for something new and Run The Jewels took full advantage. El-P is a decent rapper and a flat-out great beat-maker. With this record following up 2013‚Äôs R.A.P. Music Killer Mike is making a play for Kanye‚Äôs crown, with a knack for twisted, quotable, clever lyrics and an incredible, relaxed flow that drives the record.

The album is obviously conceived as a whole - it wouldn‚Äôt surprise me to find that El-P considered the sequencing as carefully as any individual beat. ‚ÄòJeapordy‚Äô comes with no warning, things build on ‚ÄòOh My Darling Don‚Äôt Cry‚Äô and when the beat drops on ‚ÄòBlockbuster Night Part 1‚Äô I just about lose it each time. But then it goes up another level on ‚ÄòClose Your Eyes‚Äô, which also happens to feature Zach de la Rocha‚Äôs best verse since he stepped out for Saul Williams in 2004.

6. The New Pornographers ‚Äî Brill Bruisers

I was a big fan of Twin Cinema (2005) but haven‚Äôt exactly flipped for the two New Pornographers records between then and now. Brill Bruisers, however, is an unqualified triumph. The opening track is bombastic and sing-along whilst also proving a great showcase for the band‚Äôs huge sound. I love the way ‚ÄòChampions of Red Wine‚Äô shimmers and builds, and ‚ÄòWar on the East Coast‚Äô pulls a bait and switch by flipping from dirge to glam in the blink of an eye.

Carl Newman refers to Brill Bruisers as “a celebration record” and certainly it sticks to the brighter, more upbeat end of the band‚Äôs spectrum. The production is outstanding, and having several male and female vocalists allows for a dialogue and a lyrical dynamic that works here as it does for Arcade Fire. Take for example album best ‚ÄòBorn With A Sound‚Äô, which could easily find a home on The Suburbs: when Amber Webber sings ‚ÄúI want you all of the time‚Äù by herself a shiver runs through me without fail.

5. Submerse ‚Äî Slow Waves

With the majority of what I listen to these days falling somewhere on the electronica spectrum, Submerse managed to pinpoint precisely where my head is with this stuff at the moment. Lushly-produced, infinitely warm soundscapes, and wonderfully balanced instrumentation helped make this probably my most-played album of 2014.

Other plaudits headed Slow Waves‚Äôs way include best album cover of the year and best opening track in the form of the stunning ‚ÄôLet‚Äôs Never Come Back Here Again‚Äô. Other highlights include the alluring wash of ‚ÄòSnorlax‚Äô and ‚ÄòVHS.chords‚Äô, which weaves circa‚Äì8-bit videogame sound effects subtly through its ebb and flow. I‚Äôve been struggling to pinpoint precisely what it is that Rob Orme (aka Submerse) does so well, and I think the key to this sound is the perfect balance of organic-seeming electronica: there‚Äôs nothing cold here, it all feels very much as though each of its musical capillaries is pulsing with warmth.

4. Spoon ‚Äî They Want My Soul

The narrative around the release of this record was all too concerned with the longevity of the band‚Äôs career. As someone with ‚Äî for better or worse ‚Äî limited prior connection with Spoon, I was able to look at the album objectively and found it to be nothing less or more complicated than a great rock record.

It‚Äôs a cleverly sequenced album: ‚ÄòRent I Pay‚Äô is a statement of intent to open with, ‚ÄòInside Out‚Äô is more ruminative, slightly poppier, and ‚ÄòRainy Taxi‚Äô serves to display a cutting edge. Most of these 10 tracks move between moods throughout their runtime, as though the band have too many great ideas for one album. Nothing feels forced or poorly-executed however - it‚Äôs clear without knowing the back catalogue that this is a group of musicians very assured in what they‚Äôre making.

The warm, just-fuzzy-enough production is outstanding, and is tweaked masterfully to fit around each song just perfectly. I‚Äôll be playing the title track and the bombastic, anthem to bravery ‚ÄôLet Me Be Mine‚Äô for a long while to come - as well as most of the rest of the album I should think.

3. SBTRKT ‚Äî Wonder Where We‚Äôll Land

Previous to this year my only knowledge of SBTRKT was via a couple of (pretty great) Radiohead remixes (of ‚ÄòEverything In Its Right Place‚Äô & ‚ÄòLotus Flower‚Äô). The path to changing that was an odd one: I picked up the single ‚ÄôNEW DORP. NEW YORK‚Äô via Ezra Koenig‚Äôs Twitter, and liked but didn‚Äôt love it. That was enough to get me to tune into the album via Rdio, and soon after I had purchased it and was playing a couple of tracks more-or-less daily. There‚Äôs a great variety of styles on display over the generous 15 track running order, but I started to get even more out of the record when it clicked for me that it had been built for consumption as a whole.

‚ÄòThe Light‚Äô sounds like it belongs on a sexier version of Hail To The Thief; ‚ÄôTemporary View‚Äô ‚Äî tinged with R&B ‚Äî is plaintive and uplifting; ‚ÄòHigher‚Äô features Raury delivering probably my favourite hip-hop vocal performance of the year.

For whatever reason even the outlets I‚Äôm usually fairly in sync with on music were relatively down on this record (Pitchfork: 55%; Resident Advisor: 5/10). That‚Äôs a puzzle to me as I continue to find new reasons to love a huge, warm album in which it‚Äôs a pleasure to get lost for a while.

2. St. Vincent ‚Äî St. Vincent

I really liked Annie Clark‚Äôs 2009 album Actor, but this record quickly inspired a whole new level of devotion. That was the case right from the release of ‚ÄòDigital Witness‚Äô on the sixth day of the year - a track I‚Äôm still playing regularly 12 months later and have not grown the slightest bit tired of.

‚ÄòBirth in Reverse‚Äô is all angular guitar and too-deep grooves, ‚ÄòBring Me Your Loves‚Äô makes something astounding out of the under-practiced sub-genre of lament-as-anthem. But it‚Äôs ‚ÄòDigital Witness‚Äô that still rings the clearest for me as the album‚Äôs centrepiece: in tone and subject matter a kissing-cousin to much of Arcade Fire‚Äôs Reflektor, and just as stirring to each the heart, head, and hips.

1. Death From Above 1979 ‚Äî The Physical World

I still remember the day in 2006 when I read the post on DFA1979‚Äôs website in which Jesse Keller used those fateful words: ‚ÄúWe decided to stop doing the band‚Ä¶‚Äù. That was two years after having released the singularly powerful You‚Äôre A Woman, I‚Äôm A Machine and thereby shifting my whole conception of how much noise two people could make, as well as altering the topography of the post-punk landscape.

It‚Äôs been a long decade since that incredible debut, and the mere existence of this second record is something like a miracle; that it lives up to the standard of the first record is a second-order miracle; and that it also finds ways to evolve the band‚Äôs unmistakable sound without sacrificing its authenticity or its power is a kind of compound triptych miracle.

(As an aside, a neat accompaniment to the album was also released this year in the form of Eva Michon‚Äôs insightful, up-close-and-personal doc Life After Death From Above 1979, which chronicles the tour cycle of the first record, the falling apart, and the reconstitution of the band.)

‚ÄòRight On, Frankenstein!‚Äô & ‚ÄòThe Physical World‚Äô are my favourite tracks here, but the whole thing is pretty outstanding from start to finish. Brutal, danceable, chantable, and full of great hooks - I couldn‚Äôt be happier to have DFA1979 back in the world.
